issue.summary: Crash on closing a window while page is loading
issue.description:
Repeat of bug 3608526, which has been closed although the problem still occurs and never stopped occurring.
If you set NS loading a page, and close the window while the page is loading, NS crashes. The attached crash log is from doing that with a page from the BBC's new web site with NS CI #1249 json and enabled but it's done it with hundreds of versions for a while now (the original report was with CI #985 and that was far from the first).
Fully repeatable, not site specific, AFAICS.
Iyonix, RO 5.18, 512 MiB.
issue.additional_information:
kyllikki1 added a note on Wed Jun 5 23:08:06 2013
This appears to be specific to RISC OS
From the log stacktrace: ( 652c28) pc: 77b4c lr: 9385c sp: 652c2c js_exec() ( 652c5c) pc: 93654 lr: 3aa74 sp: 652c60 ^convert_script_sync_cb() ( 652d30) pc: 3a754 lr: 3ad74 sp: 652d34 ^hlcache_migrate_ctx() ( 652dd8) pc: 3ab50 lr: 3bd8c sp: 652ddc ^hlcache_llcache_callback() ( 652e0c) pc: 3bc10 lr: 3c65c sp: 652e10 ^llcache_object_notify_users() ( 652e24) pc: 3c634 lr: 3ae20 sp: 652e28 llcache_poll() ( 652e34) pc: 3ae14 lr: 5ded4 sp: 652e38 hlcache_poll() ( 652e4c) pc: 5deac lr: b8f64 sp: 652e50 netsurf_main_loop() ( 652fe8) pc: b89f4 lr: 4bdd40 sp: 652fec main()
which seems to indicate that closing the window fails to abort the fetch correctly and when the script callback executes the script it goes bang for obvious reasons.
should convert_script_sync_cb() in handling CONTENT_MSG_DONE skip the execution if the parent content has been aborted? certainly I am unable to reproduce this on gtk or framebuffer frontends.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3614357 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: Can't override CFLAGS at command line
issue.description:
On OpenBSD/NetSurf 3.0, overriding CFLAGS at the command line (which should be allowed, as per "The client may also override all toolchain settings, including: ..." in Makefile.top) causes the build to fail.
Example:
$ cd /usr/ports/pobj/hubbub-0.2.0/libhubbub-0.2.0/ && gmake NSSHARED=/usr/local/share/netsurf-buildsystem CFLAGS="`pkg-config --cflags libparserutils`" COMPILE: src/parser.c In file included from src/parser.c:18: src/treebuilder/treebuilder.h:19:33: error: tokeniser/tokeniser.h: No such file or directory gmake: *** [build-OpenBSD-OpenBSD-release-lib-static/src_parser.o] Error 1
It seems that setting CFLAGS on the command line overrides the assignment on line 25 of hubbub's Makefile:
CFLAGS := -D_BSD_SOURCE -I$(CURDIR)/include/ \ -I$(CURDIR)/src $(WARNFLAGS) $(CFLAGS)
Note that similar things happen with all NetSurf projects, not just hubbub.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3612589 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.description:
http://www.ofcom.org.uk has a couple of problems: 1. The link text does not display over the top of the main image (currently it's something to do with internet traffic management), although it is identified as being a link. 2. Further down the page (below the image), there is an invisible link to "ofcom announces winners of the 4g auction" - which is on Firefox is the second image on the banner - which prevents Ofcom for consumers, Ofcom licensing and part of Ofcom for stakeholders being clicked 3. This repeats with the third invisible link "how much does a phone call really cost" on top of the majority of the links under the Ofcom for consumers and Ofcom licensing headings. The alt text when hovering over these links is correct, the target is not. 4. The fourth banner image section "Ofcom awards Liverpool local tv licence" is available as a hidden link on top of the cookies banner.
This page also seems to be decoding/displaying the images multiple times. If I cache the ready-to-display bitmaps when they are initially plotted on screen, the page displays quickly. If I don't it is extremely slow, leading me to believe it is plotting the images onto the page more than once.

issue.description:
NetSurf 3.0 - CI #746 (RiscOS 5.19 Raspberry PI)
1. I'm having a hard time selecting text with the mouse. Maybe it's me, maybe not. If you see this as a Feature Request please move it.
To select some text I have to click and then drag the mouse in any direction. -> This only works I the mouse cursor is inside a text and not above a hyperlink.
a) If the mouse is above a hyperlink and I press the mouse button the link is immediately opened (this is unusual in other browsers but seems acceptable.)
b) If the mouse cursor is not inside a text at all (eg. at the end / beginning) NetSurf simply won't start selecting anything. Instead it will start dragging / scrolling the page around.
That way you cannot copy an email address that stands for alone or select a complete text from begin->end or other way round. You can see it by trying to select the Word "NetSurf" in the upper left corner. I've also attached a very simple example.
2. Double clicking a word normally selects it up to an including the next space character. This does not work in NetSurf.

issue.summary: "Base stylesheet failed to load" on second page loaded
issue.description:
Hi,
I'm trying to use Netsurf on an arm926ejs platform. What happens is that the first page I load is ok, but when I click on any link I get an error ("Base stylesheet failed to load") in the lower left corner of the screen. The same page does not fail if loaded first (via netsurf command line). This happens with all the sites I tried up to now. Netsurf target is framebuffer, sdl, tslib (800x480 16bpp).
=== DETAILS ABOUT SOURCE CODE ===
Netsurf versions tested: 2.9 (debian sources), and netsurf from git:
git://git.netsurf-browser.org/netsurf.git
Both versions show the same problem. All the details I'm about to list refer to the git version.
netsurf git log:
646b33d make it possible using a custom freetype-config 33d40a0 Unstackify RISC OS content handler's title setting. baf50ce make image content handlers title setting use the heap instead of the st 0b7db9b treeview.c hasn't been pushed yet.
The commit on top is a small change I made for cross-compiling:
$ git show 646b33d commit 646b33d97702fd1d52464640d301d115d8192664 Author: Davide Ciminaghi <ciminaghi@gnudd.com> Date: Thu Oct 25 18:33:15 2012 +0200
make it possible using a custom freetype-config
diff --git a/framebuffer/Makefile.target b/framebuffer/Makefile.target index 2a41f41..9233901 100644 --- a/framebuffer/Makefile.target +++ b/framebuffer/Makefile.target @@ -7,8 +7,9 @@ $(eval $(call feature_enabled,MNG,-DWITH_MNG,-lmng,PNG/MNG/JNG ( $(eval $(call feature_enabled,PNG,-DWITH_PNG,-lpng,PNG (libpng) ))
ifeq ($(NETSURF_FB_FONTLIB),freetype) - CFLAGS += -DFB_USE_FREETYPE $(shell freetype-config --cflags) - LDFLAGS += $(shell freetype-config --libs) + FREETYPE_CONFIG ?= freetype-config + CFLAGS += -DFB_USE_FREETYPE $(shell $(FREETYPE_CONFIG) --cflags) + LDFLAGS += $(shell $(FREETYPE_CONFIG) --libs) endif
netsurf libraries also cloned from git yesterday. Buildsystem:
ciminaghi@dello:netsurf-git-libraries/buildsystem$ git log --oneline 8cf8b9a Add backslash 8d82336 Install binaries with correct permissions. af7e594 add coldfire atari 2359506 use more portable ccache detection ...
Libraries:
ciminaghi@dello:netsurf-git-libraries$ for d in lib* ; do pushd $d >/dev/null 2>&1 ; echo $d ; git log --oneline HEAD~~~..HEAD; popd >/dev/null 2>&1 ; done libcss 7a4d170 Hopefully silence a warning 3c973e0 Prioritise id and class hashes over element hash when inserting rules. 71d2898 Skip empty/broken rules early, before we match their selector chains. libdom 733d263 extend binding error enumeration to explicitly include hubbub errors 88a1e6a Fix for current libdom. 9c18242 Update comment. libhubbub 1dee56a Fix up for json-c 0.10 797d66f Sprinkle some const correctness around e3e7423 update for json-c 0.10 API libnsbmp efc2688 Remove suspend/invalidate stuff. 1ad808f Update to new NSBUILD infrastructure 3bec1ff Simple gitignore libnsfb 301429b avoid -Wno-overlength-strings 480b235 Split 32bpp support into xrgba, xbgr, and common. Should allow for BGR 1fbc4a8 Fix error text. libnsgif d4e35f2 Update to new NSBUILD infrastructure cdf1c3f Simple gitignore 041bf46 Bump version libparserutils 2c42fc0 -DWITHOUT_ICONV_FILTER a8c2e01 Fix input insertion. The gap in teh input was being created at the wrong 1c71d3e add simple insert test when an a is found in teh input stream libwapcaplet f9d1b53 Update to new NSBUILD infrastructure 0dc7a60 Basic gitignore 1e24766 Rework the majority of wapcaplet's interface to be macros. This removes
libnsfb and libparserutils have two more changes of mine for cross-compiling:
ciminaghi@dello:libnsfb$ git show commit 301429b82cb99ce971a85d372cdb3ea487e9e653 Author: Davide Ciminaghi <ciminaghi@gnudd.com> Date: Thu Oct 25 17:12:46 2012 +0200
avoid -Wno-overlength-strings
diff --git a/Makefile b/Makefile index 1fd4d47..47fa07b 100644 --- a/Makefile +++ b/Makefile @@ -15,8 +15,7 @@ TESTRUNNER = test/runtest.sh $(BUILDDIR) $(EXEEXT) # Toolchain flags WARNFLAGS := -Wall -Wextra -Wundef -Wpointer-arith -Wcast-align \ -Wwrite-strings -Wstrict-prototypes -Wmissing-prototypes \ - -Wmissing-declarations -Wnested-externs -Werror -pedantic \ - -Wno-overlength-strings # For nsglobe.c + -Wmissing-declarations -Wnested-externs -Werror -pedantic CFLAGS := -g -std=c99 -D_BSD_SOURCE -D_POSIX_C_SOURCE=200112L \ -I$(CURDIR)/include/ -I$(CURDIR)/src $(WARNFLAGS) $(CFLAGS)
This was done because my compiler does not support -Wno-overlength-strings
ciminaghi@dello:libparserutils$ git show 2c42fc0 commit 2c42fc03665dc11a95c56eae789ff0ca199262b6 Author: Davide Ciminaghi <ciminaghi@gnudd.com> Date: Thu Oct 25 17:38:51 2012 +0200

diff --git a/Makefile.config b/Makefile.config index 15c0a48..4a5363e 100644 --- a/Makefile.config +++ b/Makefile.config @@ -1,7 +1,7 @@ # Configuration Makefile fragment

# Cater for local configuration changes -include Makefile.config.override
This was done because I was on a hurry and didn't have the time to add Makefile.config.override.
==== DETAILS ABOUT THE BUILD PROCESS
The build process is performed by an homemade Makefile and a bunch of bash scripts (this stuff is some years old, I didn't know things like openembedded and the like). The netsurf-git package was built with the following packages:
curl-7.26.0 openssl-1.0.1c libjpeg6b-6b libxml2-2.8.0+dfsg1 libpng-1.2.15~beta5 freetype-2.4.10 libsdl1.2-1.2.11 tslib-1.0 netsurf-git-libraries

issue.summary: Status bar reports >100% of file received
issue.description: Using NetSurf test build (29 Jan 2006 12:30). Bug observed on both Iyonix (RISC OS 5.10) and Risc PC (RISC OS 4.39). Often I have noticed that the percentage received of a file (as reported in NetSurf's status bar) exceeds 100%, at which point the value becomes meaningless. This is presumably because the original estimation of the file size was incorrect; e.g. "Received 21.87 kB of 40.00 B (55982%)". For all I know this is a server-side problem, but it happens with tiresome regularity. Even if NetSurf is not at fault, it would be nicer if the total size and percentage received were replaced by "?" when the no. of bytes received exceeds the supposed file size; e.g. "Received 21.87 kB of ?". I attach a screenshot showing the phenomenon.

issue.summary: Fetching of file:/ URLs ignores encoding
issue.description:
Fetching of file:/ URLs fails to convert the path to the current system local encoding. This generates an inconsistency in the way in which local files are identified. In the case of a link in a web page, the URL will be UTF-8 encoded. In the case of a file loaded from disc (or from an URL/URI/IEURL file), the URL will be encoded in the system local encoding. When fetching the URL, the encoding is ignored (as it's assumed to be correct). If the file path contains top-bit-set characters (such as a hard-space), the UTF-8 encoded link from an HTML document will fail to fetch the file as it'll look for ...%c2%a0... instead of whatever the representation of hard-space actually is on the system at the time. To fix this requires a couple of steps:
1) Make the fetching system assume that the URL is UTF-8 encoded (which is already the case in 99% of cases) and, in the case of file:/ URLs, convert the path to the system local encoding before the fetch occurs.
2) When loading a local file (or a reference to a local file), convert the URL to UTF-8 encoding.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1403338 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.description:
This site:
http://pilot.citizendium.org/
causes NS to grab more and more memory until it fails (sometimes with an out-of-memory message, sometimes not). Site works in O2 and FF. The only log I have is about 50MB :-(
NS 6/2/07; RO 5.11, 512MB
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sat May 5 17:23:13 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
Downgrading from 1.0 RC - the current fix is good enough for the time being.
cjt02 added a note on Wed Mar 21 10:24:25 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1397835 Originator: YES
Thanks for the provisional fix, and for the interesting explanation.
jmb202 added a note on Mon Mar 19 00:31:40 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
This may be fixed in the latest version. It's a bit hacky though, and I'm not sure I like the fix.
Summary of the issue:
The page in question includes itself (probably indirectly through a CSS file) as a CSS document. NetSurf detects that the content type is not permissible in the relevant context and thus ignores the "stylesheet". It does this by simply having the owning content remove itself from the user list of the bad one; leaving the bad content alone for content_clean() to have its way with next time it's called. In the meantime, however, the bad content is still being fetched, parsed, etc. As it's the same document, we get some nice recursion going on, which eats memory until there is no more.
Summary of the current workaround:
As the content's in error, once the parent has removed itself from the user list, it explicitly checks to see if there are no further registered users of the content. If there are none, then it forcibly stops the fetch and marks the bad content as being in error. I'm not 100% sure this catches all cases, however, and it certainly doesn't solve the generic issue of indirected self-reference (there are already checks all over the place for direct self-reference, as this is easy to do and fairly common).
Perhaps a more robust solution would be to do the following:
In fetchcache(), traverse the parent content list up to the root. If the URL for the fetch being attempted is encountered, don't bother to fetch at all. This traversal needs to cover all registered users of the immediate parent content. Unfortunately, this doesn't cater for the case where the server serves up the same document from differing URLs (e.g. when different GET parameters are specified). Quite how we're meant to deal with that, I've no idea at present.

Logged In: YES user_id=1397835 Originator: YES

But after trying to look at another page on the site (just gets a login prompt), I used the back button and provoked the same crash, with DA memory constantly rising until 128MB, then a crash.
I did manage to get a log this time, but it appears to be too big to upload (324K, zipped from 14MB). I'll send it to you if you need it.
(Incidentally, NS clips the error message to "Uploaded file must be >20 and ", presumably because it's interpreting the subsequent "<256000 bytes." as a tag.)

issue.description:
A background colour is applied to table rows but not to the table itself. A cell spans two rows. In that cell the background colour is only applied to the area contained within the first row, not to the whole of the cell. See attached file.
Attrributes applied to a row must be applied to each cell defined in that row inless overridden in the cell tag (or in the case of row height by the cell contents forcing the row to be higher), regardless of whether those cells span subsequent rows.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1610400 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: "Failed creating formpost data" - hard spaces in file paths
issue.description:
NetSurf consistently reports the error "Failed creating formpost data" when I submit the contents of a web form that has an input field of type "file" that contains a RISC OS file path with one or more hard-space characters. This is easy to work around once you realise what the problem is, but can be frustrating before then because the other contents of the form is lost on every attempt.
I have witnessed this problem with both the 09 Jan 2007 19:45 and 14 Jan 2007 13:15 test builds of NetSurf. I am using the RISC OS 6 preview (21 Nov 2006) on a StrongARM Risc PC.
issue.additional_information:

This may well be tangentially related to #1403338. It's clearly a charset issue.

issue.summary: Problems with displaying very wide panoramic jpegs
issue.description:
See http://mistymornings.net/travel/nordsjo/panorama/index.html
If you click on the first image day02f.jpeg the image is downloaded and rendered. However the horizontal scroll bar is fully to the left whilst the centre of the image is view.
I can get to the left hand side of the image only by increasing the size of the Netsurf window to the maximum possible on my system (that is 2560x1024). At this point Netsurf displays the image from the left hand side edge.
When reducing the page size down the horizontal scroll bar stays in the fully left position whilst the left hand side of the image starts disappearing from view.
Both 02 and Firefox on the same machine display the image correctly from the left hand side and the browser window can be resized without losing access to parts of the image.
Netsurf v1.0, Iyonix 512MB RO5.13 Geminus 1.31 with JPEG acceleration and two screens.
Regards Stan workstuff@mail.com
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1725466 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.description:
1. Drag and drop an ArtWorks format file onto NetSurf. It displays in an otherwise 'raw' window. Now attempt to export the page as a DrawFile. (Ctrl-Shift-F3) You end up with an empty 24- or 48- byte Draw file, and the ArtWorks image drawn across the raw desktop. Hardly a serious bug, but obviously not desirable.
2. As 1., but using a Draw file instead. Exact same behaviour.
3. Drag an animated gif file onto Netsurf. It displays in a 'raw' window. Zoom in to 200%. Admire animation. Drag another animated gif into the same window. It /will/ be displayed animated, but it does /not/ respect the window's 200% zoom factor. Also pretty minor.
Haven't repeated any of these with actual web pages rather than just raw graphics files, but thought I'd flag them anyway.
issue.additional_information:
nobody added a note on Wed May 15 03:49:49 2013
Out of date / fixed sometime pre 14/05/2013

issue.description:
NetSurf 2.0 (Dev) (11 Sep 2008 21:45) r5304
When any 'new-look' Register news-page (eg http://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/09/17/reiss_leaves_rs/ ) is full-saved, the file version of the page does not display correctly.
This occurs because the source html of the page contains <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://www.theregister.co.uk/style_picker/design"> which NetSurf fails to convert into a local link, although the css file 'style_picker/design' _is_ saved as '36d177d8', or whatever.
Tony
issue.additional_information:
old_coaster added a note on Thu Sep 18 15:53:03 2008
To see the problem, using r5369:
1 full-save any news page from the Register, 2 take the computer off-line, 3 load the file copy of the Register page.
You will find that the formatting of the file copy page is bizarre.
Step 2, above, is necessary to prevent NetSurf loading the CSS file from the net (in the file copy html, the link to the CSS file still points to the net, instead of the file copy of the CSS file).
Tony

I cannot reproduce this problem (r5369).
Imported from sourceforge bug #2116103 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

commit 5d7ad9db465e8b76f07af36961f6ed0fe8bbc671 Author: Michael Drake <tlsa@netsurf-browser.org> Date: Mon Oct 8 20:32:57 2012 +0100
Port to new urldb.
commit e9b207c658b1771d7e208535017cbbf33d9e0cf8 Author: Michael Drake <tlsa@netsurf-browser.org> Date: Mon Oct 8 20:22:04 2012 +0100
Port urldb to nsurl. Won't build since rest of NS needs ported to new urldb
+ urldb API now takes URLs as nsurl, rather than string. + urldb internally stores full URLs with nsurl ref. + urldb internally stores schemes as lwc_string. + Load and save of cookies and URL file may be slower since we now need to create a nsurl. + Everything else should be faster, and there should be much less allocating/freeing and much less parsing of the same url over and over again. + Updated urldbtest for new urldb API. + urldbtest now cleans up at the end + Added lwc_string itterator to end of urldbtest + Adding some broken URLs (such as http:domain/) will now work, since nsurl fixes (http://domain/) them.
commit 1b9b870921c93a0e2835c19233c1d7e3b68f3888 Author: Michael Drake <tlsa@netsurf-browser.org> Date: Mon Oct 8 19:26:35 2012 +0100

zcorn added a note on Mon Mar 19 22:27:00 2012
This also happens with the GTK version, however it requires a few more clicks.
And it's probably related to an buffer overflow or other memory corruption.
I also get:
(169.506747) content/content.c content__reformat 357: 0x9d4c380 https://webmailer.de/smaction=reply nsgtk: render/textplain.c:1265: textplain_get_browser_window: Assertion `c->handler == &html_content_handler' failed. Aborted (core dumped)
which differs from the previous posting. I assume c->handler can't be matched again &html_content_handler because one of these pointers is overwritten.
zcorn added a note on Fri Mar 2 23:38:55 2012
in selection_get_browser_window we have:
if (s->is_html) return html_get_browser_window(s->c); else return textplain_get_browser_window(s->c);
in textplain_get_browser_window
we have: assert(c->handler == &textplain_content_handler);
Is this correct? I doubt the textarea is implemented as textplain_content
zcorn added a note on Fri Mar 2 23:24:19 2012
Part of the log:
( 49f8c4) pc: 6e620 lr: 36fb4 sp: 49f8c8 textplain_get_browser_window() ( 49f8e8) pc: 36fa0 lr: 2635c sp: 49f8ec selection_clear() ( 49f900) pc: 26328 lr: 37424 sp: 49f904 browser_window_set_selection() ( 49f924) pc: 3730c lr: 54e44 sp: 49f928 selection_click() ( 49faa4) pc: 54430 lr: 94d0 sp: 49faa8 html_mouse_action()

issue.description:
Attempting to view any page on the Ravelry.com website will take you to the log-in screen https://www.ravelry.com/account/login (which is fair enough so far as it goes - this is a member-restricted site), but the log-in then repeatedly fails. After supplying a valid name and password the requested original URL will appear in the URL bar briefly but the page is not rendered before you are once again returned to the log-in screen. (If you supply an incorrect password there is no attempt to transfer to the requested URL, so the data is clearly being received and acted upon at the far end.)
Once you do manage to get logged in (I haven't managed to work out what triggers it) you then have access to the whole site, with the absence of the JavaScript features, but cannot then log out. This is less of a problem but still puzzling.
The log (attached) suggests that the problem is occurring somewhere around "Failed creating namespace" (line 86 in log)
issue.additional_information:
harriet added a note on Tue Jan 22 04:09:04 2013
Addendum: it is possible to log into the site using the test JavaScript version with Javascript *disabled*, but only on the ARMini. The identical version of Netsurf (825 js-on) running on the Iyonix requires the cookies to be deleted as previously. (RISC OS 5.19/5.18)
Uploaded: logs of failed (on Iyonix) and succeeded (on ARMini) attempts to open http://www.ravelry.com and log in nusing same username and password.
harriet added a note on Fri Dec 21 22:53:57 2012
This is apparently a [lack of] JavaScript issue in addition to a cookies issue, since it is possible to log in to this site without prior cookie deletion using the test JavaScript version.
harriet added a note on Thu Nov 17 11:00:21 2011
Further to this: you have to open the login page *before* attempting to delete the Ravelry cookies - doing so 'in advance' doesn't work. Required sequence: display http://www.ravelry.com/account/login Show cookies Delete www.ravelry.com cookies Log in
nobody added a note on Thu Jun 23 00:45:17 2011
The answer to logging-in is to deletes cookies, apparently (I knew I'd done something or other in the past....)
And the solution to the XSRF Netsurf/Sourceforge problem which prevents the posting of comments is still to log out of Sourceforge :-(
Harriet

issue.description:
ver. r10552 (16 May 2010 16:15) running on a rev.C4 BeagleBoard
As described on the mailing list: http://vlists.pepperfish.net/pipermail/netsurf-users-netsurf-browser.org/2010-April/009393.html
As suggested by John-Mark Bell, this *does* appear to be a configuration problem.
To get https: to work I did the following: - Deleted Boot:Choices:WWW.Netsurf - Loaded NetSurf - Under Configuration, click 'Set' on any setting (in fact, I've not tried them *all* but am now satisfied that it's not just a case of, e.g. changing the cache size, as I found at first. - Quit and reload
I'm happy to have a look at the sources but as I'm still getting things up and running and don't exactly have adequate programming experience, it'll be a while before I do.
Thanks for the continuing enthusiasm with NetSurf - I hope there's some way to keep the RO front end up to date in the longer term.
Cheers
Trevor Johnson

issue.description:
Hello,
Been trying to compile Netsurf (stable 2.8 and yesterday's latest r13109 from svn) for linux framebuffer frontend on an embedded Linux (3.0.4 kernel & quite basic Busybox) booting from PXE, running in a VMWare. Problem with both versions is that it almost immediately segfaults after launch, like this:
[...] (0.18172) content/fetchers/curl.c fetch_curl_setup 359: fetch 0x8b9c738, url 'http://www.heise.de/' (0.18266) framebuffer/fbtk/fbtk.c fbtk_request_redraw 106: redrawing 0x8b9b630 0,0 640,26 (0.18278) framebuffer/fbtk/fbtk.c do_redraw 563: clipping 0x8b9aff0 0,0 800,600 (0.18286) framebuffer/fbtk/fbtk.c do_redraw 563: clipping 0x8b9b0b8 0,0 800,30 Segmentation fault
I've pasted some more useful output into a Pastebin: http://pastebin.com/b44dHYss - Contained in there is an "fbset -i" (just to show that the framebuffer is working - an ancient pre-compiled version 2.0 of Netsurf did in fact work nicely in that same environment), my Makefile.defaults (got rid of the references to Makefile.config), the entire "netsurf -v -f linux" Output and an abbreviated ltrace and strace of that same command.
It *appears* to be a problem in fbtk's do_redraw() but I have no idea how to fix this or if it has something to do with my libs or whatever. The dependencies have been compiled with basic "make install" from svn on the dev-machine and only the libs which "ldd netsurf" told me have been copied to the target.
Any ideas?
Thanks already, Andy
issue.additional_information:
zcorn added a note on Tue Mar 20 01:04:20 2012
Is the linux framebuffer implemented at all? Source doesn't look like that, much of the frambuffer structure is still zero.
zcorn added a note on Tue Mar 20 00:17:00 2012
sorry, Optimization does not influence it.
zcorn added a note on Tue Mar 20 00:13:49 2012
This only happens with gcc optimization on ( with optimization linelen of the X libnsfb surface is 0 )
zcorn added a note on Mon Mar 19 23:43:16 2012
I can confirm this also happens here with libnsfb revision 13537.
framebuffer bit depth doesn't matter.
zcorn added a note on Mon Mar 19 22:39:34 2012
Did you also link to latest version of libnsfb?
Does it also happen when running the frambuffer in a different bitdepth? ( using -b option )
djsdjsdjs added a note on Wed Nov 2 16:59:09 2011

dmesg | tail -n 1

djsdjsdjs added a note on Wed Nov 2 16:56:29 2011
Ok, I was able to reproduce this bug with the latest r13112 on a freshly installed Debian 6.0.3 x64 ("Expert install", skipped the "Install packages" part entirely, so no X, no bloat, only very basic server installation) running in VMWare 8.0.0.
Those commands have been executed after first login:
added "vga=788" to /etc/lilo.conf, ran lilo, rebooted
fbset -i
mode "800x600-75" # D: 48.001 MHz, H: 46.876 kHz, V: 75.121 Hz geometry 800 600 800 600 16 timings 20833 96 32 16 4 96 4 rgba 5/11,6/5,5/0,0/0 endmode
Frame buffer device information: Name : VESA VGA Address : 0xd0000000 Size : 1920000 Type : PACKED PIXELS Visual : TRUECOLOR XPanStep : 0 YPanStep : 0 YWrapStep : 0 LineLength : 1600 Accelerator : No
apt-get install make g++ libncurses5-dev ssh fbset subversion pkg-config libcurl4-openssl-dev libxml2-dev libpng-dev libjpeg-dev libmng-dev (of course those were actually several separate apt-get commands but that shouldn't really matter).
cd /home/
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/netsurf
cd netsurf
mkdir libs
cd libs
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libparserutils svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libwapcaplet svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/hubbub svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libcss svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libnsgif svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libnsbmp svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/librosprite svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libnsfb
Then I cd'ed into each of those folders in that order, the "make install"s all finished without errors.
cd ..
make install TARGET=framebuffer (all (Make)files left untouched)

issue.description:
I thought this one had been cleared a long time ago, but it's either back again or still there.
A table inside a table cell with centre alignment (e.g. a table header) is not centered but left aligned. Within the table, the contents of data cells are centered when they should be left aligned. If the nested table cell contains an unordered list then the bullets are left aligned but the text of list items is centered. This probably applied to oiredered lists too but I haven't tried them.

minijem added a note on Mon Nov 15 10:45:41 2010
It looks like this might be specific to table header cells <th> as using a data cell plus a center tag works fine. I haven't tried align attributes yet.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3109233 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: Netsurf 2.6 framebuffer has not keyboard shortcuts
issue.description:
Hello: I compiled and installed Netsurf 2.6 in my Debian system running at init 3 (no x server). I compiled Netsurf for framebuffer with the TARGET=frambuffer flag.
While Netsurf runs very well and I'm very impressed by it, I noticed that aside from scrolling, there is no other keyboard shortcut active. I can't even quit Netsurf (have to do a hard shutdown on the system).
Following are my system specs, again, I'm running no x server
System: Host antiX1 Kernel 2.6.32-1-mepis-smp i686 (32 bit) Distro antiX-core-686-b1 27 July 2010 CPU: Single core Pentium III (Coppermine) (-UP-) cache 256 KB flags (sse) bmips 1403.77 clocked at 701.654 MHz Graphics: Card ATI Rage Mobility P/M AGP 2x tty res: 63x53 Audio: Card ESS ES1978 Maestro 2E driver ES1968 (ESS Maestro) at port 1400 BusID: 00:08.0 Sound: Advanced Linux Sound Architecture Version 1.0.21 Network: Card-1 Broadcom BCM4318 [AirForce One 54g] 802.11g Wireless LAN Controller BusID: 02:00.0 Card-2 Realtek RTL-8139/8139C/8139C+ driver 8139too v: 0.9.28 at port 3400 BusID: 06:00.0 Disks: HDD Total Size: 25.6GB (8.8% used) 1: /dev/hda IBM-DARA-225000 25.4GB 2: USB /dev/sda JUMPDRIVE_ELITE 0.3GB Partition: ID:/ size: 9.9G used: 2.2G (23%) fs: auto ID:swap-1 size: 2.18GB used: 0.00GB (0%) fs: swap Info: Processes 55 Uptime 15:37 Memory 24.1/247.7MB Runlevel 3 Client Shell inxi 1.4.12
Thank you!

issue.summary: Form text inputs: text seln "swipe backwards"
issue.description:
I recently suggested an enhancement request 1537335 for the Select-style "swipe" with the mouse pointer to highlight text in writable icons as this wasn't working.
On further investigation, I've found that it's because I swipe backwards from the right to the left and tend to start in the blank area to the right of the text.
I'm not quite sure if this is a bug or not but here are the details to reproduce.
In a RO Select writable icon, I can highlight text from right to left by starting the swipe in the blank area to the right of the end of the text and swiping leftward.
In NS writable icons, I can't do this (and struggle to reliably swipe leftward from the last character). Swiping left or right-ward within text works reliably.
Thanks, James
issue.additional_information:
nobody added a note on Tue Mar 3 07:49:11 2009
Yes, the problem still exists in (Dev) (02 Mar 2009 20:45) r6676

Should add that this is with the 06-Aug-2006 18:00 build running on VirtualRPC RO 4.39

issue.description:
(Copied from mailing list. Written from perspective of RISC OS; Chris Young confirms the jumping to bottom of list bug is core.)
Deleting cookies - any cookie - seems to be riddled with issues.
When I first select one and delete it (via the toolbar or the menu), the whole treeview flickers madly for a few seconds. After that, the cookie disappears from view, but scrolling down to the bottom reveals it's only been moved to the last entry instead of being deleted. Deleting it from its new position seems to work.
Deleting several cookies, either via the same delete operation or individually, results in them all being moved to the bottom. However, subsequently deleting one which was initially moved there but has since been pushed up by further deletions works, rather than moving it a few entries back to the bottom, so it doesn't seem to be a purely positional thing.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3297709 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: body height ignored and scrolling not working properly
issue.description: The test case sets body height to 100px but it actually expands to fill the viewport. When the blue-bordered div is clipped scroll bar is displayed as expected but it fails to work as expected most of the the time. At first, dragging the scroll bar does nothing. By some combination of key presses and mouse clicks it appears that the scroll bar begins to function but it doesn't always do what you expect. Sometimes its OK, but other times it scrolls the opposite way to the expected direction. This appears to be because the hand pointer is displayed and despite it being over the scroll bar, its being interpretted as over the document content. Clicking in the space above/below the scroll bar doesn't always do what is expected either, but it does seem to change the behaviour so that sometimes scrolling works OK. This is quite weird and tricky to give precise instructions to reproduce consistent symptoms. mike@mhobbs.demon.co.uk
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3310077 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.description:
There's a problem with drawing your scrollbars inside the boundaries of a fixed-size box - by definition, they make the box smaller.
See here for an example:
http://dandyforums.freeforums.org/post37.html#p37
The vertical scrollbar overlaps the right-hand border of the image, but NetSurf doesn't detect that the display area is now so narrow a horizontal scrollbar is required. Consequently, the rightmost column is invisible.

issue.summary: URIs with embedded auth details containing '@'
issue.description:
NetSurf fails to interpret the following URI correctly: http://guest@chrisy:guest1@webdav.mydrive.ch/public/test.txt
Instead of visiting webdav.mydrive.ch with a username of guest@chrisy, it tries to visit host chrisy.
URL-encoding the first @ makes NetSurf interpret the address as expected. ie. the following works where the above fails: http://guest%40chrisy:guest1@webdav.mydrive.ch/public/test.txt

issue.summary: Netsurf 2.7 on Google 'Failed writing body' error
issue.description:
Over the last few weeks I have been getting the following error when visiting www.google.co.uk sometimes:
Warning from NetSurf Failed writing body (0 != 249) Continue
When I click continue the page remains blank. When I click the Netsurf icon on the icon bar a second time, it usually works but sometimes it repeatedly fails to load with the same error every time. I have only had this error with the Google page. All other sites I have tried work OK as usual.
My telephone exchange has recently been upgraded to 21CN and my broadband connection has been upgraded to ADSL2+ a few weeks ago as well. I don't know if there is a connection but the error and upgrade both started around the same time.
I am using an Iyonix PC with RISC OS 5.16 (512MB memory) with the latest stable NetSurf 2.7 I also have a Windows PC and www.google.co.uk has never produced an error on that.
issue.additional_information:
kyllikki1 added a note on Thu Jun 6 16:18:11 2013
Thank you for taking the time to report this bug and helping to make NetSurf better. However, I am closing it because the bug seems to have been fixed in the latest development version of NetSurf.
Please, try to reproduce this bug using the latest version. If the bug still exists, feel free to file a new report with an updated version number.
nobody added a note on Sun Nov 20 18:09:09 2011
I also had this problem with the Atari port at the beginning. It was caused by an network bug within the kernel / socket API. The socket was reported to be writable right after connect(), which isn't correct - first it has to establish the TCP connection. If you write to the socket altough the connect() isn't finished. you will get exactly this error.
bapfish added a note on Thu Aug 25 08:14:32 2011
I have tried upgrading to the latest beta release - r12644 23 Aug 2011 - and the problem remains. It also happens occasionally on other websites, not just Google. It goes wrong about 30 times a day for me at the moment and is a real pain.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3378546 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.description:

jmb202 added a note on Mon Dec 17 00:23:09 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
Accept-Encoding: gzip is being sent in the GET request sent by NetSurf. Gzip-compressed data is returned by the server, sans Content-Encoding: gzip header. Thus, the server's misconfigured (wrt RFC2616 $14.11). Other browsers appear to handle this page, however. Dropping priority appropriately.
druck added a note on Sun Dec 16 12:15:51 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1385089 Originator: YES
Confirmed with 2.0 r3669
Imported from sourceforge bug #1851807 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: NetSurf sends requests (e.g. localhost) to proxies blindly
issue.description:
At present with a proxy set, NetSurf passes requests straight to it. If I attempt to access http://localhost, for example, my local proxy will try to talk to itself. Since we have a friendly user interface for configuring the connection again, it would be useful to be able to exclude certain URLs/requests from being passed on to the proxy. At least it is easy enough to turn the proxying on and off again now without having to quit NetSurf and edit the Choices and restart.
I would suggest that passing localhost through is never likely to be useful behaviour.
issue.additional_information:
kyllikki1 added a note on Tue Jun 4 18:19:26 2013
the http_proxy_noproxy user option now allows hosts to be excluded from proxy use, the default value is localhost
The GTK frontend has UI to configure this
in mainline git commit 4e248695248d2c749b2d9e892549ba0e9390a3d0
CI build #1248
element3260 added a note on Tue Mar 3 06:54:50 2009
Thank you for taking the time to report this bug and helping to make NetSurf better. However, this bug report seems to be more of a feature request. As such, it has been transferred to the feature request section of the tracker. Feel free to continue to contribute any additional information or comments to that report.

issue.summary: A particularly strange manifestation of the aborted-redraw bug
issue.description:
http://www.londonreconnections.com/archive/
Near the top of that page, just below the navigation bar, there's a text input field enabling you to search the archive. Except you can't see it at first, because the main area of the page is blanked out until you drag another window across it.
Experimentation with dragging windows around on top of the browser window narrows the culprit very specifically down to the top left pixel of the border of that input field. NetSurf simply will not redraw that one pixel, and blanks out the rest of the redraw rectangle if that pixel is included. With care, you can make all of the search box visible except for the top-left pixel, but not including it.
No idea what could be causing this one!
Tested with NetSurf #1097 and #1107, Iyonix, RISC OS 5.18.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3612512 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

kyllikki1 added a note on Sun Apr 28 17:24:42 2013
This appears to be an issue with the bision api.prefix and the flex bison-bridge option.
we set this in the src/Makefile
# Bison 2.6 and later require api.prefix, but this breaks Bison 2.5 and earlier. bisonvsn := $(word 4,$(shell bison --version)) bisonmaj := $(word 1,$(subst ., ,$(bisonvsn))) bisonmin := $(word 2,$(subst ., ,$(bisonvsn))) ifeq ($(bisonmaj),1) BISON_DEFINES = --name-prefix=$(*F)_ else ifeq ($(bisonmaj),2) ifneq ($(findstring $(bisonmin),"0 1 2 3 4 5"),) BISON_DEFINES = --name-prefix=$(*F)_ else BISON_DEFINES = --define=api.prefix=$(*F)_ endif else BISON_DEFINES = --define=api.prefix=$(*F)_ endif endif
$(BUILDDIR)/%-parser.c $(BUILDDIR)/%-parser.h: src/%-parser.y $(VQ)$(ECHO) " BISON: $<" $(Q)bison -d -t $(BISON_DEFINES) --report=all --output=$(BUILDDIR)/$(*F)-parser.c --defines=$(BUILDDIR)/$(*F)-parser.h $<
Can the build be attempted with "make Q=" and the results returned.
I am especially interested in the output of "bison --version"
Imported from sourceforge bug #3612033 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.description:
The Ctrl-arrow keys have not worked properly in Netsurf for quite some time now. (Maybe this is related to problems others have reported recently about Ctrl-U behaviour and about input focus.)
The standard Acorn behaviour in almost all other apps is that Ctrl supercharges the arrow keys to take you all the way in that direction.
In other words, Ctrl-up scrolls you all the way to the top of a window, Ctrl-right all the way to the right, etc. (I presume this is in the Style Guide.)
Try it. Shrink any Netsurf page (with its bottom-right gadget) to a small size so that it needs scrolling.
In Netsurf #898 and #616, and in 2.9 (on both Ro 5.18 and 4.39) -- Ctrl-up works as expected Ctrl-down does nothing Ctrl-left takes you all the way RIGHT Ctrl-right takes you all the way LEFT
In Netsurf 2.8, 2.7 -- Ctrl-down does nothing; other three work.
In Netsurf 2.5 -- all Ctrl-arrow keys work as expected.
-- Jim Nagel www.archivemag.co.uk
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3605090 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.description: In version 2.9 (SVN r13518) NetSurf can edit readonly field input text. issue.description: I used !TTF2f to convert the Trebuchet MS font to a RISC OS equivalent. I named the new font folder Trebouchet in !Boot.Resources.!Fonts and created appropriate Medium, Bold, Italic and BoldItalic subdirectories. On next startup NetSurf 3.0 #872 gave the following error message: 'Unicode failed to initialise, please contact the developers'. Renaming the font directory correctly to Trebuchet then allowed NetSurf to start, but next time it failed again with the same error. The only permanent solution was removing the Trebuchet font directory from Resources.!Fonts. While installed, OvPro and TechWriter could use the new font, so it seems to be valid.
issue.additional_information:

Update: 3 successive restarts of RPCEmu with the Trebuchet font directory reinstalled in Resources.!Fonts have resulted in a normal launch of NetSurf on each occasion. Whatever the original problem was, it has gone away.

issue.description:
A minor one:
Pick a reasonably large text submission area and select several lines of text. Within the selected area, start deleting. In particular, use Ctrl-End to delete to the end of the current line. The selected area shrinks from the end as you delete text in the middle, one character for one. So if you had 100 characters selected, and deleted 25, you would end up with /50/ characters selected, not 75. Expected behaviour returns once the cursor is at or past the end of the selected block.
On this sourceforge text box, selecting 'goes funny' as well. Dragging and selecting once, I have now got several non-contiguous areas of highlighted text. This may be a line-wrap issue.
I have a couple of sample screen grabs. Email me if you need them. simon_smith%zen:co:uk, or something. Netsurf version 03 March 2007, 23:00

issue.description:
Cut-and-paste from a NetSurf window into the URL bar adds one extra spurious character to the end of whatever you paste. If what you pasted was a filename, the presence of the extra character is likely to cause a file not found response from the remote server.
To replicate this minor issue:
Open a page with an external link on it (e.g. of the form <a href="http://www.example.com/index.html">. View source. Drag-select the link text for the link. (i.e. Just the bit inside the double quotes.) Save the selection from the editor window onto the Netsurf iconbar icon. A new NetSurf window will open, with a file:/// URL pointing to a ScrapFile, containing the pasted URL.
In the new NetSurf window, drag-select exactly the text of the link and drop it into the URL entry box. While the page is loading, click the mouse to the right of the pasted URL. You will see that there is a spurious character there. A hard space? A null? Hard to tell. If the link was to a web directory-level link (link ending in /) the page should still load. If the link is of the form http://www.example.com/index.html or http://www.example.com/image.png the link will probably not work because the extra spurious character is treated as part of the filename. You have to delete the extra character and retry. Seems to occur any time you cut and paste from within a NetSurf window into the URL field.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1834258 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: Subtree is not relabeled when text boxes change
issue.description:
If you edit a text area, and then try to drag-select it, the selection becomes disrupted in some places. It is unable to select some portions and wants to skip to the next line.
This is due to selection_label_subtree not being called when the text is changed. Currently it is only called whe n s->root is changed (as in clicking in another part of the page).
This also affects select_all as selection->max_idx is only recalculated when selection_label_subtree is called. This allows max_idx to be greater than the length of the text box when text is deleted.
To reproduce: copy this text "Whether you want to check your webmail, read the news or post to discussion forums, NetSurf is your lightweight gateway to the world wide web. Actively developed, NetSurf is continually evolving and improving."
and go to: http://www.mcfedries.com/CreatingAWebPage/textarea.htm paste it in that text area at the bottom and delete the word "developed", then try to select that line.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #2009133 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: Caret position wrongly updated when text box height changes
issue.description:
Material required for reproduction: Any multi-line text input box. The ones on SourceForge will do just fine.
When typing into a text box and its height changes above its original maximum extent (i.e. a scrollbar is present or newly created), whether this be by having typed too much, or simply having pressed Return repeatedly, then in between the keypress which caused the height to change and the next one, the caret is wrongly vertically positioned. The same symptoms occur whether the height increases or decreases, but if it increases, the caret is below the correct position, and if it decreases, it is above. It is reset to its correct position on the next keypress. The exact amount of error seems to vary according to the total extent, or possibly even just randomly.
The error doesn't occur if there is no vertical scrollbar in the text box either before or after the height change (i.e. if the extent of the box is still the same, but some parts are off-limits to the caret). It does occur if a scrollbar is created or deleted in the process. The actual vertical position of the caret is immaterial - it doesn't necessarily have to be at the bottom.
Tested, reproduced and confirmed on NetSurf r12872 (RISC OS 5.16), repeatedly, in this very text box, not always voluntarily.
issue.additional_information:
zcorn added a note on Mon Mar 19 23:34:43 2012
The crash can be reproduced by bringing up the scroll bar that scrolls from left to right. ( long line ) - then do a few selections.
I've also seen multiple selections.
zcorn added a note on Mon Mar 19 23:31:50 2012
Tested with GTK version - altough the caret seems to be positioned correctly ( visual indicator ), the selection is done a few lines below that...
It also crashed at some point in time.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3414730 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: HTML with DOS line endings is rendered very slowly.
issue.description:
This happens on all recent versions of Netsurf I've tried, including the latest test build 13028.
To demonstrate the problem - download this file (it's a large document from GameFAQs, about 1M in size): http://www.gamefaqs.com/n64/197770-the-legend-of-zelda-majoras-mask/faqs/49987
Save the file to disc. Open it in Zap's text mode and remove all CR characters (search for "\xd" and replace with ""). Save under a different name.
Load the edited file into Netsurf - for me it takes about 55 seconds (Iyonix RO 5.17).
Compare with the time it takes Netsurf to display the original file - I got bored waiting after about 8 minutes.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sat Nov 5 18:46:44 2011
Comedy :) This requires libdom to fix -- libxml2 is superbly inefficient when appending a text node to an element.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3421200 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

issue.summary: NetSurf has no icon (filer or iconbar)
issue.description:
There's a check in !Boot that looks for SpriteExtend 1.50, and if found does *ICONSPRITES on the alpha channel sprites. However, the RISC OS Open version of SpriteExtend has now passed version 1.50, so when softloaded on something other than RISC OS 5 the alphachannel sprites are used and rejected - hence no icon.
I think the various RMEnsures need tightening up a bit, to look for whatever version of Select that change switched in, rather than doing "if not RISC OS 5 and SpriteExtend 1.50 then alphasprites".
Here, using RISC OS 4.02 and SpriteExtend 1.51.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jan 13 21:51:41 2013
Sadly, the only way to do this is to write a chunk of BASIC which loads and verifies ASprites. If this fails, we assume alpha sprites aren't available and then do the OS version check.
kinnison added a note on Sun Nov 4 17:49:01 2012
Patch gratefully received
Imported from sourceforge bug #3556638 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:49 2013

Logged In: YES user_id=453739
I've tracked this down to the image https:// www.paypal.com/images/x-click-but04.gif on the page. In fact, any connection to https://www.paypal.com/ crashes NetSurf. I can also reproduce this with my curl port. The crash is in ssl code. Investigating.

issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Fri May 21 23:20:08 2004
Logged In: YES user_id=826159
David Pilling has said about Ovation Pro: "This is not a 'new bug' this is a shortcoming in the way OP selects a variation on a font. It is something that has dragged on for nearly 15 years - it's been changed to work one way, then another, etc. no one is ever happy.
You can select the exact font family member you want in OP, just makes things a little more difficult."
bursa added a note on Thu Mar 25 18:12:05 2004
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
There is nothing special about the NetSurf fonts. As far as I can tell, this must be a bug in Ovation Pro. Please try reporting this to the Ovation developers, and post any response here.
Thanks! James

issue.summary: Window iconize no longer works for osnews.com
issue.description:
This one is rather odd :
1. Clean <Wimp$ScrapDir>.WWW.NetSurf dir 2. Start NetSurf 27 Mar 2006 01:15 3. Open surf window and type osnews.com 4. Let it load all its data + relayout 5. Click on window iconize button -> window closes but no icon on the pinboard.
Using other URLs like www.drobe.co.uk, etc works. What's so special about osnews.com ? ;-)
Using RiscPC Adjust, ViewFinder.
issue.additional_information:
rjek added a note on Fri Jun 23 23:48:01 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=893271
I've added a workaround to NetSurf for this, for the people who aren't likely to be using or seeing Pinboard 1.01 anytime soon.
It also appears to be tricky to reproduce on RISC OS 5, although there are stories and myths of similar things happening. My workaround doesn't check for RISC OS 5, but I doubt users will notice the odd occation where the text is truncated a little more zealously than usual.
jtytgat added a note on Fri Jun 23 20:15:15 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1420374
It is confirmed as an OS bug (so it is not a NetSurf bug) and apparently fixed in RISCOS Ltd's Pinboard v1.01. No need to let this remain open.
rjek added a note on Wed Jun 21 22:24:43 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=893271
This does appear to be an OS bug. I have reproduced it with !Edit. Here's how:
1. Create a new Edit window. Save it as "iiiiiiiiiiiiiii" 2. Create another. Save it as "mmmmmmmmmmmmmmm" 3. Iconise both windows.
The "m" one won't appear. I suspect this has something to do with the Pinboard truncating at a number of characters, rather than a number of pixels. This would also explain why it works just fine at different point sizes and different fonts, and why some sites work and others do not.
Given this isn't a bug in NetSurf, I have reduced its priority to the lowest, incase Adrian can thing of some cunning work around. We might want to experiment to see precisely how many pixels, etc, causes it to fail, and make sure we truncate it for the Pinboard instead.
jtytgat added a note on Wed Jun 21 21:43:13 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1420374
The desktop font choice is indeed the clue we were looking for. I'm currently using Homerton.Bold at 12 point (aspect 100%) and then the bug is reproducable. 11 point and lower makes iconizing work like expected, 12 point and greater the iconizng no longer works so the trigger is somewhere between 11 and 12 point. Are we talking about a RISC OS bug ?
pnyoung added a note on Wed Jun 21 09:42:19 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1386864
This was aired on the Iyo mailing list a while back. It seems to be solved by changing or reducing the size of the desktop font. I had it with other sites, and it doesn't happen here with Homerton 11pt as the desktop font.
Best wishes,
Peter.
jtytgat added a note on Sun Jun 18 19:41:10 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1420374
Still reproducable with NetSurf build 15 Jun 2006 16:00. Doesn't this have to do with short length of the URL ?
jtytgat added a note on Mon Apr 3 21:46:49 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1420374
This problem got introduced somewhere between NetSurf build 16 Mar 2006 23:45 (= goes fine) and 27 Mar 2006 00:30 (= next build I took a copy off and there the iconisation of osnews.com does not happen).
jtytgat added a note on Mon Apr 3 21:40:49 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1420374
Still reproducable with 31 Mar 2006 10:45 build. I even removed my NetSurf choices directory. Tried 256/32K/16M modes. Always goes wrong with osnews.com (both with shift close-click or clicking on the iconize button), but not with drobe.co.uk or any other website I tried.
I also tried to remove the pinboard backdrop (a jpeg file) but that didn't make a difference.
It is not that there is an invisible iconized icon, it is simply not there because iconising other windows will not leave a gap for the supposely invisible icon.
Very odd (and annoying).
rjek added a note on Mon Apr 3 12:04:47 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=893271
I am unable to reproduce this on my RiscPC - the icon appears as a thumbnail of the page without issue (I followed your steps exactly, including emptying NetSurf's scrap directory.
I am using CVS head, and I used Shift-Close, however. Can you try again with the latest version?
There is one issue in that there are currently only "iconised" borders around the thumbnails on RISC OS 5, meaning that it's feasable that an icon might appear completely invisible.

issue.summary: Google's 'View as HTML' for PDF broken since abs positioning
issue.description:
Example URL: http://66.249.93.104/search?q=cache:TEtBUWTQW9UJ:www.opsi.gov.uk/si/si2006/uksi_20061623_en.pdf+South+Coast+Ambulance+Trust&hl=en&gl=uk&ct=clnk&cd=3&ie=UTF-8 (or searching google for 'Random pdf' and using 'View as HTML') It appears that the advent of absolute positioning has broken the appearance of PDFs converted to HTML by Google. The text from the PDF file ends up all on one line overprinting itself. (06 Jul 2006 06:45 version) I have gone back over previous versions and definitely all since 26 Jun 2006 05:00 have exhibited this problem though 24 Jun 2006 18:00 displays them OK. The format of the HTML generated seems odd anyway. ... // ...
...loads of
...
but ultimately it seems to be that NetSurf is not doing anything with the "top:foo" so ends up with everything printed as though it were attached to the top of the window.
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Tue Aug 22 01:39:12 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
NetSurf now has a workaround for this problem with Google's CSS.
bursa added a note on Sat Jul 8 19:55:33 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
The top and left CSS properties are missing units, so are invalid CSS and are currently ignored.
James

(or "left", or even "right") tag to force new paragraphs to be rendered beneath those 'flowed' around an image. This means that after using the tag, paragraphs can end up a long way from the images to which they are intended to refer....

issue.description: Browser crashes. Bug report generated. Peter@eues.net
issue.additional_information:
rjek added a note on Fri Aug 1 10:57:48 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=893271 Originator: NO
There is no bug report attached here, just a zip of the NetSurf log file. This does not constitute a bug report. A bug report contains information about what you were doing, how, if the issue is repeatable, what system you are using, which NetSurf you are using, which other sites show similar issues, etc etc etc.
Please do not file bug reports containing just the log. As I've said before, they're a waste of everybody's time. I suggest you read http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/bugs.html - it's quite a long read, but essential none the less for anybody who wishes to report bugs in a useful, constructive manner.
Imported from sourceforge bug #2034158 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
Any html markup in the value of a textarea field is not being displayed. It is essential that markup is treated as plain text since the form may be used to edit that markup.
For example you might put a link to a picture in a bulletin board post, or add a streetmap link to a database entry for an event.
This could also apply to special characters lile the ampersand and pound sign, but other browsers tend to convert these.
Btw, when I try to submit this using NetSurf I get a parsing error.
minijem
issue.additional_information:
phlamethrower added a note on Fri Sep 8 21:28:42 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1131038
This will be fixed as soon as I get my SVN access.
However, the text you get out won't always be the same as the text that's in the page source.
This is because of some idiosyncracies in the HTML4 and XML specs which mean that textarea contents are parsed for HTML tags. So according to the spec, if a server wants a client to display tags as text, it should replace the appropriate characters with html entities.
Once the page has been parsed into the XML tree we have no way of directly accessing the source text, so can't display the unprocessed form. We could probably rework the parsing to support this, but it would probably require a fair amount of work. The only time I can think of when you'd have raw HTML tags in a textarea is when you're editing something that contains HTML tags, so the text->XML->text conversion process shouldn't cause any serious problems.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1429046 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
Form textareas do not show a horizontal scrollbar when entering lines longer than the set width. This means the end of long lines are not shown making editing very difficult.
This commonly occurs when submitting urls in web forums using the syntax:-
[url=http://some.quite.long.url/]explanation[/url]
As there are no spaces in order to break the line and see the text after the url.

issue.description:
When pasting text into a text area in a form the cursor is left at the top left of the text area. However if you enter text it goes in after the pasted text. The cursor should be repositioned at the end of the inserted text.
N.B. single line text fields are handled correctly.
Richard (minijem)

Logged In: YES user_id=1131038
caret position & scroll offset should be fixed in the latest build

Logged In: YES user_id=1131038
actually, there are still some nasty issues with the caret position after pasting
phlamethrower added a note on Sun Sep 10 16:20:56 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1131038
this should all be fixed now
minijem added a note on Thu Jul 6 15:01:42 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
It looks like this has been partially fixed but there are still some issues. The caret is now placed on a line below the pasted text, not at the end of it. If the pasted text more than fills the box the caret appears below the box, where it would have been had the box been larger. Deleting at that point can have unexpected results!
If I now type something, let's say an x, then a newline, then paste in some text the text goes in before the x not after the newline.

issue.description:
Hiya,
Nice simple one. When the browser window is closed, the toolbar window is not. This may not matter visually, as the window vanishes due to it being nested. However, the window still exists, having not been deleted. The result is that if you open a few windows and close them, the toolbars are still hanging around the system taking up resources (for the Wimp).
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Fri Jul 18 00:05:06 2003
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Should be fixed in latest checkin.
bursa added a note on Sun Feb 9 19:55:09 2003
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
As I understand the gui code, the solution is as follows:
1. Replace the call to gui_window_hide() in gui_poll() with browser_window_destroy() (and remove gui_window_hide(), which is no longer needed).
2. Add wimp_delete_window() calls for the window and toolbars to gui_window_destroy().

issue.summary: Google groups unable to scroll thread tree.
issue.description:
Using build 2004-06-11 14:01
Viewing a given thread in Google Groups, leads to a two frame page. The left frame is the thread tree and the right frame say 10 of the messages.
All displays ok, the problem is with a deeply nested tree. The left hand frame containing the tree cannot be scrolled horizontally thus you cannot use the tree to select and view a given posting if the posting is too far to the right.
I could not find a way of scrolling sideways in that frame or indeed a way to increase the width of the frame to allow the tree to be fully browsed.
Although a number of RISC OS browsers do not allow frames borders to be dragged at least the contents of the frame can be dragged around to allow viewing of the contents of the frame.
Regards Stan

However all seems fine now. Not only is there a horizontal scrollbar but it is also possible to pull the vertical separator between the two frames left and right. Great!
So both problems solved . Thanks for that ! Regards Stan

issue.summary: Sunfreeware Website shows Text in Italic, not Upright Text
issue.description:
Hi, I'm using the current latest build - 07 Sep 2006, 09:45
I visited http://sunfreeware.blueyonder.co.uk/ to try out the new frames functionality and noticed, in NS, all of the text in the right-most frames is displayed as Italic; it's shown "upright" in various other PC-based browsers I've tried.
In NS, I have default font type set to "serif" and my serif font is "Trinity".
Any ideas why?
Thanks, James
issue.additional_information:
jmsargent added a note on Thu Sep 7 14:29:48 2006 Logged In: YES user_id=1447794 Thanks for the very swift response. As it would seem NS is doing the correct thing, I suggest this bug could be closed! jmb202 added a note on Thu Sep 7 14:16:56 2006 Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Yes; H5 in NetSurf is styled as: h5 { display: block; font-size: medium; font-style: italic; margin: 1em 0; } by default. In the case of those pages, the H5 at the top is not closed until the end of the document, thus this style is propagating until another block-level element is encountered (

in the case of the top frame, nothing in the case of the bottom frame), hence the italic text. Imported from sourceforge bug #1553990 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Reports missing definition in template file
issue.description:
First execution is ok but following system shutdown when executed again Netsurf reports missing definition in template file and requests a reinstall. Experimentation has shown that some action such as timestamping the template file allows execution of Netsurf.

issue.description:
With the latest build (2005-07-09) and one from a few days ago, whenever the pointer is over the Netsurf Window there are a constant stream of commands issued at 0.1 second intervals ...
12:02:19.06 [Appl\NetSurf] RMEnsure Iconv 0.04 RMload System:Modules.Iconv 12:02:19.06 [Appl\NetSurf] RMEnsure Iconv 0.04 Error 16_10F iconv support requires the Iconv module 0.04 or newer
12:02:19.16 [Appl\NetSurf] RMEnsure Iconv 0.04 RMload System:Modules.Iconv 12:02:19.16 [Appl\NetSurf] RMEnsure Iconv 0.04 Error 16_10F iconv support requires the Iconv module 0.04 or newer
etc etc!
It would seem sensible to issue them once, rather than from within each WimpPollIdle loop!?
Martin
netsurf@avisoft.f9.co.uk
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Mon Jul 11 19:26:37 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
This is the result of how UnixLib's iconv support is implemented. As the module may be killed from underneath an application that uses it, UnixLib takes the sensible approach of attempting to load the module each time a conversion descriptor is opened.
As much of the text in NetSurf is passed through iconv before display, iconv_open was being called a great deal. However, this isn't particularly efficient, as a great deal of conversions are between the same character sets. NetSurf has now been modified to cache the previous iconv conversion descriptor. This should fix the issue you are seeing (with the side effect that conversion is up to 18 times faster).

issue.additional_information:
sclaes added a note on Sun Sep 10 22:29:46 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
When the scale view is changed while the Scale view window is open, the scale is not updated. Would it be possible to change this? It's not that important but it would be nice if the scale was updated dynamically IYSWIM. ;-)
BTW: there are still no shortcuts in the Scale view window (IIRC 75%, 100%, 140% and 200%). I assume this is only temporary. (Testbuild 10 Sep 2006 20:30)
not_ginger_matt added a note on Fri Sep 8 23:36:22 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
This should now be fixed.
sclaes added a note on Fri Sep 8 23:04:40 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
NS also crashes with Ctrl+resize
see logfile2
sclaes added a note on Fri Sep 8 22:57:59 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
NS crashes when I change the scale view of
<http://www.archimedes.be/Test/NS/frames/toc.htm>
see logfile
not_ginger_matt added a note on Fri Sep 8 17:50:44 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
I've now updated the scale view dialog to make the operations clearer, and also made so that any scale changes are also applied to the dimensions and content of all child frames, both inline or frameset based. Similarly, Ctrl+resize will now correctly work for frame based pages.
not_ginger_matt added a note on Wed Sep 6 14:42:08 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
The issue here is that of an unclear GUI. Scaling the page via the toolbar results in the frameset page being scaled (invisible to the user.) When refreshing the child frames are then propogated with the scale of the parent and thus it appears to work. Although the fix is relatively simple, I'm hesitant to introduce it until a new menu structure and supporting UI is introduced such that an established way of what actions affect which windows is done. A further issue is whether we should scale the actual frame sizes or just the content. I'd probably suggest that the scale of the parent frameset is used for the frames (rather than either the frame scale or nothing) as it errs towards the side of how the page author expects the content to be layed out.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1553282 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
18 Jul 2006 02:00 build
Downloaded a file. Inadvertently clicked on the link to download the same file again. Closed download window. Was asked ' Are you sure you wish to abort this download?' Clicked 'Yes'. Both the download window and the query window disappeared as expected.
Clicked on the correct link for download. Inadvertently tried to close download window. Was asked 'Are you sure you wish to abort this download?' Clicked 'No'/ The download window remained (which is OK) but so too did the query window. No amount of clicking 'No' would get rid of it.
The downloads were all 1Mb+ in size, so that I actually had time to fiddle about.
issue.additional_information:
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Sep 5 19:34:39 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
NetSurfs internal window handling wan't correctly releasing handles for closed browser windows, so if this window handle was later re-used it would be passed onto the browser window icon handling code (ie none) and the query/download windows wouldn't respond.

issue.description:
Use Netsurf (any version as far as I can tell ) and go to http://www.trustedreviews.com/ . You should get a server error from this server which is running .NET.
This doesn't happen with IE or FireFox on the PC or Browse on RISC OS.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Fri Apr 21 21:33:55 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=826159
This appears to have been fixed by the site's webmaster.
bursa added a note on Sun Jul 3 14:07:26 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
This appears to be a bug in the website, not in NetSurf. I have emailed the website as follows:
Subject: Problem with http://www.trustedreviews.com/ and NetSurf From: James Bursa <james@semichrome.net> To: editor@trustedreviews.com
(Please could you forward this to your webmaster? I couldn't find a contact address on your site and webmaster@trustedreviews.com bounced.)
Hi,
I'm one of the developers of NetSurf, an Open Source web browser.
I received a report from one of our users that your site, http://www.trustedreviews.com/, doesn't work in NetSurf:
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=1184037&group_id=51719&atid=464312
I've investigated, and it looks like this is a bug in your site which is being triggered by NetSurf for some reason. I've attached the page that the server returns. Please let me know if you require more information to fix this bug, or if you think that this is due to a bug in NetSurf.
Thanks! James

issue.description:
I don't know whether this is an actual bug, but it seems worth reporting.
I have two copies of Netsurf on my original-spec RPC700 (RO 3.60) at present: 'Test Build (01 Jul 2004 23:30)' and 'Test Build (03 Mar 2005 22:35)'
The older one loads "instantly", and once loaded runs well and seems stable.
The later one (which I believe is the latest) takes three and a half minutes to load! However, once loaded, it runs well, and seems stable.
Both versions have a file stderr in their folders. The July 2004 version's stderr is short:
desktop/netsurf.c netsurf_init 62: version 'Test Build (01 Jul 2004 23:30)' desktop/netsurf.c netsurf_init 69: NetSurf on <riscos>, node <poolejpn.silver.ocn.ne.jp>, release <3.60>, version <2.02>, machine <arm-acorn>
riscos/gui.c ro_gui_check_resolvers 375: Inet$Resolvers '203.139.161.40 203.139.160.74 '
The march 2005 version's stderr runs to over 250kB and commences thus:
desktop/netsurf.c netsurf_init 68: version 'Test Build (03 Mar 2005 22:35)' desktop/netsurf.c netsurf_init 75: NetSurf on <riscos>, node <poolejpn.silver.ocn.ne.jp>, release <3.60>, version <2.02>, machine <arm-acorn> rufl_init.c rufl_init 102: old font manager rufl_init.c rufl_init 111: 508 faces, 99 families rufl_init.c rufl_load_cache 894: "AmTypeWrit.Medium2.Italic" not in font list rufl_init.c rufl_load_cache 894: "ANSI" not in font list rufl_init.c rufl_load_cache 894: "ANSI.Oblique" not in font list rufl_init.c rufl_load_cache 894: "gothic013.r48" not in font list rufl_init.c rufl_load_cache 894: "gothic013.r49" not in font list rufl_init.c rufl_load_cache 894: "gothic013.r4a" not in font list rufl_init.c rufl_load_cache 894: "gothic013.r4b" not in font list
etc etc in similar vein until it gets to:
rufl_init.c rufl_init 127: scanning 505 "Warsaw.UltraBold" rufl_init.c rufl_init 127: scanning 506 "Warsaw.UltraBold.Italic" rufl_init.c rufl_init 127: scanning 507 "WIMPSymbol" rufl_init.c rufl_init 154: 334 new charsets rufl_init.c rufl_save_cache 721: fwrite: 0x2: No such file or directory riscos/gui.c ro_gui_check_resolvers 422: Inet$Resolvers '203.139.161.40 203.139.160.74 '
the last part of which looks similar to the end of the July 2004 version's file.
Following this, there's also a lot of what looks like logs of Web page accesses, but what's presumably taking up all the time during loading is the checking and and scanning of fonts (I've got the Nuffield Risc OS port of the Wadalab Japanese fonts on board, so there are rather a lot of them).
I've attempted to upload the stderr file for the 03 mar 2005 version.
At the moment, the slow loading means that the latest version of Netsurf is hard to use on my machine, so I'll stick with the earlier one for now.
Regards
Michael Poole
poolejpn@silver.ocn.ne.jp
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1157281 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description: Consider: Link (Where AppNameRes is some path variable.) If I click on this link, NetSurf presents the file as a download (with type "data") rather than rendering the file in the browser window. Attached is a mini-application (kindly put together by David Pitt) which demonstrates the bug. Click on the "help path" icon bar menu option.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Wed Jan 11 21:16:32 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Reclosing this bug as the general case of path variables in links works correctly. There's a bug in your new testcase in that it sets test$path to a non-path string (and therefore won't work with anything). As for the hard space issue, this is a generic issue with fetching local files and I'll open a bug for that. The workaround is to replace the hard-space with %a0 in the URL. The other issue (of running an application whose !Run file is typed to HTML) is so unlikely to occur in the real world that I'm not inclined to fix it. If you wish to bundle HTML files in an application such that the file is opened in a browser when run, I advise doing what NetSurf's full save functionality does and make the !Run file an obey file containing the single line "Filer_Run <Obey$Dir>.foo/html"
jmb202 added a note on Wed Jan 11 19:05:07 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
What (and where) is reopend.zip?
adamr7747 added a note on Wed Jan 11 18:47:58 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=902784
Oh, I thought this was fixed, but it seems there's still a problem. Run the app in reopend.zip to see that the first two links do not work. (The path is set up in the !Boot file.)
This also reveals another problem - try running the app when NetSurf is already loaded.
nobody added a note on Sat Dec 10 17:09:55 2005
Logged In: NO
If it helps ...
file:///HelpHTML:/Docs/help.html works in your application.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1371902 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

the last part of which looks similar to the July 2004 version's file.
There's also a lot of what looks like logs of Web page accesses, what's presumably taking up all the time is checking and scanning fonts (I've got the Nuffield Risc OS port of the Wadalab Japanese fonts on board, so there are rather a lot of them).
