issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Tue Apr 12 19:10:31 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Fixed by 2005-04-05 changes to RUfl. A broken font was causing the charset->size field to be uninitialized, resulting in writing the cache failing.
bursa added a note on Tue Mar 29 19:20:18 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
This log indicates that NetSurf failed to save the cache of font character data, which means that it has to rescan all your fonts each time it runs.
The cache should be saved to <Wimp$ScrapDir>.RUfl_cache. Does this machine have a Scrap directory and is it writeable?
Thanks! James
Imported from sourceforge bug #1157272 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
When I load netsurf 01/09/2005 20:30, click on the icon and then go to www.ebay.co.uk, then type "strongarm" in the top right search box netsurf crashes. This is on an iyonix RO5.09 with 256MB. I have uploaded the crash dump to http://www.duffell.riscos.me.uk/dist/netsurf.txt
My email adress is johnduffell@yahoo.co.uk
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Sun Mar 26 18:11:54 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Fixed in layout.c 1.155.
jmb202 added a note on Sat Jan 7 02:48:29 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
It looks as though a negative margin on an inline element is causing this. It would appear as though the first pass in layout_line() terminates earlier than the second pass, thus causing the abort. This appears to be due to the first pass ignoring margins/borders/padding on inline elements whereas the second pass takes account of them.
Test case attached.
jmb202 added a note on Sat Jan 7 02:42:47 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Further report from David White on 6/01/06:
Whilst browsing on eBay, I clicked on the link to a vendor's 'Other items' and Netsurf crashed telling me it had experienced a 'serious error' and requested I submit a bug report. Following the error message, !Netsurf quits from the iconbar, but can be loaded again and used for other websites. The computer does not 'hang'. (Sounds similar to report submitted by Phil Michael on 1/1/06).
OS: RISC OS Select 4.39 Machine: StrongARM Risc PC, 128Mb RAM, 2Mb VRAM, 20Gb & 4Gb HD, Castle 16 bit SCSI+ Yamaha 8-4-24 CR-RW drive.
email address: david.white@cuckoofoot.plus.com
Regards,
David
PS I may have previously registered on this site when submitting a bug report, if so I have forgotten my login details - sorry!
Imported from sourceforge bug #1281704 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

bursa added a note on Thu Jun 16 23:03:26 2005

The percentage on the hourglass indicates that NetSurf is scanning fonts (which is only required once). This can take several minutes if large Unicode fonts are installed (for example Cyberbit).

Thanks! James

issue.description: I use an Iyonix, RISCOS 5.09. On starting a number of the latest versions of Netsurf (such as the versions built in the last three days) I get a message to the effect that UnixLib has deterected recursion in relation to SIGSEGV. Netsurf then exits.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Fri Apr 21 21:58:27 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=826159
I can't reproduce this any more. If you still experience this problem with the latest build, please open a new bug.
bursa added a note on Tue Jul 26 20:53:57 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Steps to reproduce and a workaround, received by email from original submitter Mick Dunford <m.f.dunford@ntlworld.com>:
The steps are: (1) start up my machine, double click on !Netsurf. I get
Unixlib detected recursion of signal SIGSEGV. Exiting Press SPACE or click mouse to continue.
(2) Find an archive containing the latest (maybe same) version of netsurf (builds netsurf) downloaded for the web site. Double click on the archive. Drag Netsurf to the RAM disc. Double click on either version and it appears on the icon bar and runs normally
I have repeated these steps many, many times. I have used a number of recent builds. In fact I often get the latest each day.
When I start up I run quite a few things: Aemulor, HID, Organizer, Edit

issue.description:
Double clicking on !Netsurf gives the following message: The Unicode font library could not be initialized. Please report this to the developers.

I seem to have the other required modules.
It may of cource be me doing something stupid!
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Tue Aug 16 01:13:32 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Font base encoding file issues. This isn't a problem with NetSurf, but is a result of TTF2f's behaviour. This has now been addressed in the form of a new version of TTF2f, which is more sensible with its font generation (now produces symbol fonts, rather than language fonts - the distinction is simply in the location of the Encoding file)

issue.summary: Netsurf crashes on loading on my Iyonix
issue.description:
For some months now, Netsurf builds have failed to load on my Iyonix (OS 5.10, 512Mb RAM). The same d/l works fine on my A9home. The last build which I have that works OK on the Iyo is of 25 March, but I may well have not downloaded any builds during last summer - I noticed the problem when I tried a November build. The error file is attached - the crash seems to appear just at/after the font scanning routine (very nicely shown in recent builds!). Sorry I haven't reported it earlier - as I don't load anything particularly unusual on start-up, I thought somebody else would have reported it earlier! Following the error message, !Netsurf quits from the iconbar, but can be loaded again and used for other websites. The computer does not 'hang'. (Sounds similar to report submitted by Phil Michael on 1/1/06).
OS: RISC OS Select 4.39 Machine: StrongARM Risc PC, 128Mb RAM, 2Mb VRAM, 20Gb & 4Gb HD, Castle 16 bit SCSI+ Yamaha 8-4-24 CR-RW drive.
email address: david.white@cuckoofoot.plus.com
Regards,
David
PS I may have previously registered on this site when submitting a bug report, if so I have forgotten my login details - sorry!
Log file attached
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sat Jan 7 02:49:18 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Merging with 1281704.
jmb202 added a note on Sat Jan 7 02:09:14 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
It looks as though a negative margin on an inline element is causing this. It would appear as though the first pass in layout_line() terminates earlier than the second pass, thus causing the abort. This appears to be due to the first pass ignoring margins/borders/padding on inline elements whereas the second pass takes account of them.
Test case attached.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1398359 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
When loading a page from a local storage medium (i.e. as a file) Netsurf fetches it from cache if it can rather than from the disc. This is very inconvenient for testing pages because you have to do a refresh after loading the page. Even then images are not always reloaded.
As there's no advantage in cacheing file objects it shouldn't be done.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Mon Feb 6 18:07:34 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Therein lies my confusion; once the ETag faking is implemented, there'll be no need to stamp files.
minijem added a note on Mon Feb 6 17:37:01 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
NetSurf doesn't affect SiteMatch. Stamping files does. I don't mind how you handle local CSS files - that's not the issue. I think you've covered the real problem. A 'clear cache' function is useful for a variety of reasons, but that would be a separate feature request.
jmb202 added a note on Mon Feb 6 17:28:27 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
I don't understand why you think NetSurf's caching behaviour hinders your usage of SiteMatch; once I've implemented the ETag header faking for local files, it'll do everything you wanted (and avoid the issues related with not caching local objects at all). It also removes the need for any "flush cache" buttons.
As for the CSS files, they may be "only 14k" but without caching, that's 14k for every HTML document you have open at any one time. That also takes no account of the processing time needed to parse the CSS files and apply the rules contained within them to the HTML documents.
minijem added a note on Mon Feb 6 16:19:47 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
OK, I use SiteMatch which uploads changed files to the web sites - one of a few such programs. I can exclude files from the upload but it's a fiddle. Thanks for the explanation. I looked in !NetSurf.Resources and didn't notice the two CSS files. I agree you don't want to load them every time if they're in RAM, though it's only 14k. If there was a "flush cache" option on the icon bar menu (or even on Choices/cache) that would alleviate the problem and the date/time check would be fine.
jmb202 added a note on Mon Feb 6 15:02:12 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
How would the unchanged file get uploaded to the web server?
Perhaps I had better explain exactly what NetSurf's caching behaviour does.
When attempting to re-fetch an URL, NetSurf first determines whether there's any cached copy and, if so, whether it's still fresh (i.e. if the age of the cached copy is younger than some limit determined by the HTTP headers the server sent when originally fetching the object). If there is one, that is used. If there is no cached copy, then the URL is refetched.
If, however, there is a cached copy but it appears stale, the cached content is revalidated. This will always happen for local objects as the age limit is always 0. In general, revalidation attempts to take account of two things:
1) If the object has been modified since it was last fetched (by consulting the modification time of the object) 2) If the object's content has changed but not the modification date.
If it detects that the object has been changed since it was cached, then the object is refetched. Otherwise, the cached copy is used. In this way, we can ensure that the viewed content is up-to-date.
In the case of local files, the second test is not currently used (and my suggestion of faking the HTTP ETag header for local files will fix this).
The local CSS files can be found in !NetSurf.Resources.
minijem added a note on Mon Feb 6 14:04:56 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
That's a possibility but then the unchanged file would get uploaded to the web server - hardly efficient if you're using a dial-up line. Where are the local CSS files?
jmb202 added a note on Mon Feb 6 12:51:57 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Not caching local files would mean that every time you fetched a new page, all of NetSurf's local CSS files would be reloaded. This is hardly efficient. Additionally, if you're copying files around, it's hardly onerous to stamp the file so the datestamp is updated. I suppose we could fake HTTP ETag headers for local files; this would avoid the need for restamping.
minijem added a note on Mon Feb 6 12:09:54 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
I'm not sure about the fix. If I've tried a modification and don't like it I can restore the old file and it will then be older that the cached version. I still want to see the page or image I've asked for and not a newer one that I've discarded. Therefore I repeat that objects on the local hard disc (or file server) must be loaded from disc and not from cache regardless of modification date.
jmb202 added a note on Mon Feb 6 00:23:54 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
All of this should now be fixed; NetSurf now takes account of the last modification time of an object - if it's newer than NetSurf's cached version, the content gets re-fetched.
minijem added a note on Mon Jan 30 20:18:01 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
Further to this, if you follow a link which is broken because the file doesn't exist or was misnamed, and you then create the file and double-click on it, NetSurf still thinks the page doesn't exist. If you actually present a file to NS by dragging it onto the icon or into the window or explicitly typing in the path, then NS should open that file.

issue.summary: NetSurf fails to find fonts in EasyFontPro
issue.description:
NetSurf (recent builds, including 08 Feb 2006 0045) fails to find fonts stored by EasyFontPro and so does not offer them in its menu. Deleting rufl_cache and trying again results in NetSurf silently dying (example log from such an event attached).
EasyFontPro adds its fonts to Font$Path by the macro <EasyFSPro$Fonts> which points to <EasyFSPro$Dir>.Fabis0004.^. There is no such Fabis0004 directory present and the resulting <EasyFSPro$Dir>. contains a 0 subdirectory followed by various numbered subdirectories. Presumably normally EasyFontPro does some 'magic' when the FontManager normally investigates the path.
Additionally, EasyFontPro turns all the files within the original font directories into numbered files within numbered subdirectories (presumably to more efficiently store them) along with some internal record of what is what.
I wonder if either or both of these factors are tripping up the 'check for Outlines data' changes to RUfl since a) the path doesn't really exist b) the structure inside is not that of normal fonts. EasyFontPro may fool the Font Manager but cannot fool the Filer, perhaps?
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1427715 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Can't log into Google mail with recent test builds
issue.description:
I would like to be able to use the latest builds of NetSurf to access my Google mail account. This is a popular web-based e-mail service which has an optional 'plain HTML' interface which is ideally suited to NetSurf if one can overcome the obstacle of logging in.
I am currently unable to log in to my account using test build 13 Jul 2006 23:00. The sequence of events is as follows:
I enter the URL http://mail.google.com in one of NetSurf's URL input fields. This redirects momentarily to http://mail.google.com/mail/ and then to a log-in page with the following URL:
https://www.google.com/accounts/ServiceLogin?service=mail&passive=true&rm=false&continue=http%3A%2F%2Fmail.google.com%2Fmail%2F%3Fui%3Dhtml%26zy%3Dl&ltmpl=googlemail&ltmplcache=2
Entering my user name and password takes me momentarily to:
https://www.google.com/accounts/CheckCookie?continue=http%3A%2F%2Fmail.google.com%2Fmail%2F%3Fui%3Dhtml%26zy%3Dl&service=mail&chtml=LoginDoneHtml
Which redirects to the following (broken-looking) URL:
https://www.google.com/accounts/'http://mail.google.com/mail/?ui=html&zy=l'
This page displays the error message 'The page you requested is invalid'. It does not seem to make a difference whether or not I enabled the 'Remember me on this computer' option on the log-in page.
However I can, with some difficulty, access Google mail using a test build dating from 24 Feb 2006 20:45 (which I keep specifically for this purpose).
Initially, logging in leads me to a broken URL with the same error message ("The page you requested is invalid") as the latest test build:
https://www.google.com/accounts/'http://mail.google.com/mail/?ui=html&zy=l&auth=QDNNNTjNNNO1b7CM8KBVM1n-WosjpSCloMhd_UKvPFPWfNLh1sPJFisleINaJ23NZvYu1gh6uADugnGx0uncCuZiatEPCpoVVOjCKxwPTXNf_OR6pdQCJXxpwqkkV__O-AeiFy2iJY4Ag4VUf7dNQUvuK-hNY6f5'
(I have scrambled the final part of this URL - after "&auth=" - to avoid compromising my account's security.)
Despite the error message, returning to http://mail.google.com/mail/ allows me to access my account (with the February test build). Instead of the usual invitation to log-in, a page is displayed giving the options of a JavaScript interface ('standard view'), a non-JS interface ('basic HTML view') and a version for mobile phones. Selecting 'basic HTML view' displays my e-mail inbox correctly.
The URL for the interface selection page resembles the following (again, I have scrambled the 'auth' code):
http://mail.google.com/mail/?auth=DQANNTfNNNNwzbBGpxjzAAajcdR7W76cqTv5rOCX9-FfMi0M0g-5HCT4l6wV4rz-leCnndzDzGIC8F_N9nejkUt2bvuqYXAbDuFrQMNEJIUGsJngNv9d89A6FZ6EXDtOzXWSm-3TVgRcuD510Yobe6jTuLixcr0n&mk=emy0j78zctf6
With the old version of NetSurf, even an apparently unsucessful log-in generates several additional Google cookies (whether or not I tick 'Remember me on this computer'). It is presumably one (or more) of these which enables access to my account.
I believe the problem relates to cookie handling, but the recent improvements in this area do not seem to have resolved it. It was obviously the intention of the site's designers that it should work with non-JavaScript browsers, so I am hopeful that NetSurf can do it.
Many thanks for your time.
issue.additional_information:
mittens added a note on Tue Jul 18 09:13:24 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1227467
Fantastic, thanks very much. I wonder if it would be worth telling Google that their meta refresh commands are broken?

issue.description:
Netsurf will not allow you to paste text from the clipboard into a form text field or text area unless it has been cut or copied from a text file. If the text is copied from an html file, either from a browser window or from the file opened in !Edit, it will be treated as a new page, wiping out the form. This happens whether the fragment makes any sense as a web page or not.
The workaround is to open an !Edit window, type in some random text to make it a text file, paste in the copied text, delete the random text and then save the file into the form and then close the !Edit window discarding the contents - very messy! You could probably cut and paste from the text file too.
issue.additional_information:
minijem added a note on Thu Jul 6 15:07:33 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
It looks like this has been fixed!
Thanks.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1458456 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: URL is run, rather than inserted

not_ginger_matt added a note on Mon Jul 3 02:38:50 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
Any content can now be dragged into text areas.
minijem added a note on Mon Apr 17 10:18:21 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
I think this is the same bug that I reported earlier. If you cut and paste from an html file or URI/URL, or drag and drop the file then Netsurf treats it as a new page and runs it. If the source was a text file then it goes into the form field as intended. The workaround is to set the file type to text, or to paste the URL into a text file in !Edit and then copy it out again, but note that a new !Edit window won't work unless you type some text first to establish the file type.
Netsurf has to distinguish between dropping html into a form field, and dropping it elsewhere in a browser window.

issue.summary: Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette
issue.description:
Since I started experimenting with different desktop themes (e.g. http://jymbob.drobe.co.uk) I have become more aware of which icons have their own palette, because they do not blend in with their surroundings like those that use the desktop palette.
The toolbar icons in the default Netsurf theme 'Aletheia' seem to fall into this category; I'm currently using a green-tinged desktop palette but the toolbar icons remain resolutely light grey. I think it would make more sense for them to use the desktop palette.
issue.additional_information:
mittens added a note on Sat Jul 8 13:24:50 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1227467
IMO the 16 colour version of Aletheia does look better (than the original) with an alternative desktop palette and window tile sprite - see attached screenshot.
Note the light green fringe on the faded icon. This is becase the window tile sprite isn't a uniform colour and doesn't quite match colour 1 in the Wimp palette. Arguably this is the fault of the desktop theme and not NetSurf, but it could be avoided by using semi-transparent pixels to anti-alias the icon edges.
tlsa added a note on Tue Jul 4 20:33:47 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=826159
I have attached a zip file containing a 16 colour version of Aletheia. Please copy it into Choices:WWW.NetSurf.Themes and select the Aletheia16 theme from NetSurf's theme config window. The Throbber has not been converted, only the buttons as it would be a lot more work. I don't intend to update the theme again until I overhaul it for version 1.0.
nobody added a note on Fri Jun 30 00:23:44 2006
Logged In: NO
As far as I know, only 16 colour sprites with no palette of their own are rendered using the desktop palette. Experimentation appears to confirm this.
The border anti-aliasing doesn't work (in fact it is unsightly) with any window background tile of a significantly different colour than light grey. The background of NetSurf's tool bar does not seem to be under control of the theme; it is the same as in all other windows.
It is for this reason that I don't generally like grey anti-aliasing around the borders of icons - if nothing else then they will look odd against a coloured Pinboard backdrop. The gradated sprite masks provided by RISC OS Select may be some help with this in future.
tlsa added a note on Fri Jun 23 20:07:02 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=826159
The sprites have a subtle fade from a light grey to a darker gray on the face of the icons. More shades of grey also improve the border anti-aliasing.
Please tell me what format the sprites need to be for the desktop palette thing to work. (The icons are currently 256 colour sprites with no palette.)
mittens added a note on Mon Jun 12 08:49:35 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1227467
Well it's hard to tell given the way that the themes are packaged up, but I can reduce a screen snapshot of the 'Aletheia' toolbar to 8 grey levels (in InterGif) without any visible deterioration. Is there any reason why these (simple, monochrome) sprites should use 8 bits per pixel?
bursa added a note on Mon Jun 12 03:50:49 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
I think the icons are 256 colours, so as far as I know this isn't possible.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1491299 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
When searching on Ebay, certain Tick boxes can be selected to refine or extend the search. However, once you've clicked the 'Search'-button, the resulting page shows the radio buttons unticked. This means that their default state isn't set correctly, or that (more likely) the state of the original tick boxes hasn't been passed (correctly) when submitting the search.
Here is how to reproduce it. Goto http://www.ebay.com and type a search word in the top right field. Press Enter to start the search. A new (advanced) search window will now open. Select the tick box right under the search field, called 'Search title and description'. Now click the 'Search button. The resulting page will have the tick box unchecked again. The same is true for all other options on the page.
Paul Reuvers support@xat.nl
issue.additional_information:
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Jul 4 21:55:17 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
This appears to be fixed in the current build.

issue.description:
I have configured UTF8 as the current alphabet because it solves some problems. It enables me to use more than one charset: I can choose another keyboard driver to select chars from another charset. (I can even use this when I rename files or directories.) But there are still some problems...
If a title of a webpage is iso8859-9 encoded (latin5) and the title contains e.g. a dotlessi (\xFD) then an yacute is displayed instead of this dotlessi. I can understand this because the yacute has the same code (\xFD). It is just a char form another char set (iso8859-1 aka latin1)
But if I enter a search string in Altavista (or Google) that contains a dotlessi then the resulting url is displayed incorrectly in the global history. The dotlessi is not replaced by an yacute (as expected) but as a ccedilla.
Why?
issue.additional_information:
sclaes added a note on Tue Jul 11 13:25:24 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
Is NS always sending 'Accept-charset: iso-8859-1' to the server?
BTW: why not add this to the choices file? (e.g. after the 'accept-language: ' entry)
sclaes added a note on Tue Jul 11 11:02:59 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
NS doesn't use the current alphabet at all. :-(
I changed the alphabet to latin-5 and the configured country to turkey and I removed the obey file that changed the alphabet to UTF8. But when I go to altavista.com, I still get the webpage in latin-1. Why?
sclaes added a note on Tue Jul 11 10:49:45 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
Excellent.
There are still some problems with altavista though. For some reason altavista insists on using latin-1 and it replaces the dotless i (in the search string) with \x8f \xe7... I changed the preferred_language entry in the choices file but that didn't make any difference.
ICBW but I think NS doesn't use the current alphabet (on my computer it is changed to UTF8 by an obey file in !Boot.choices.boot.predesk) when requesting a webpage (from altavista). Is there any way to change this?
BTW: the title of a webpage is still displayed in latin-1 (instead of e.g. latin-5: <http://www.osmanli.org.tr/>)
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Jul 11 01:41:17 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
Trees are now rendered using rufl rather than wimp_ploticon, thus should display UTF8 correctly.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1434430 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Link overlaps text entry line on Dictionary.com
issue.description:
At http://dictionary.reference.com , the 'Dictionary.com' logo in the top left corner of the page seems to invisibly overlap the adjacent text entry box. This manifests as the mouse pointer shape changing to a finger rather than a caret whilst over the left end of the text box. Clicking in this side of the box text follows the link instead of positioning the caret.
The overlap is increased if the width of the window is reduced or the display scale is increased (until eventually the 'Dictionary.com' graphic also visually overlaps the text box).
A weird side effect is that pasting text from the clipboard into the text box will fail if the caret is within the area overlapped (i.e. the first few characters of text). Instead of entering the text into the field, it is displayed as a new page.
This is with the NetSurf test build of 01 Oct 2006 18:15, on RISC OS Select.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Fri Oct 5 09:12:32 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
This is now fixed.
Thanks for reporting.

issue.description: Running IPCop with DansGuardian as a firewall/proxy/filter, NS needs to be explicitly told its address. There's no way then of bypassing the proxy (although this is a different issue). If I need to access sites on my LAN, I need to either have no proxy set (which blocks access to outside sites) or have the ISP's proxy set (Which negates the filter). Other browsers (IE, Oreganos, Opera, Firefox, Fresco) route through the transparent proxy when "no proxy" is set . As at build 05 Jan 2006, can't set proxy at all due to no UI, but i guess this is a temporary thing. Mike Gilbert

issue.description:
I may have mis-understood the new fetcher but, as a webmaster, I am a little concerned about the default value of max_fetchers_per_host; For keepalive connections the RFC (8.1.4 Practical Considerations) states
Clients that use persistent connections SHOULD limit the number of simultaneous connections that they maintain to a given server. A single user client SHOULD NOT maintain more than 2 connections with any server or proxy.
which suggests that max_fetchers_per_host should be set to 2 rather than 5.
John
john.p.baker@bristol.ac.uk
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Thu Aug 17 15:13:07 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Fixed in r2854.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1469511 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Ebuyer site crashes NetSurf during formatting
issue.description:
The current build of NetSurf (21 Aug 2006 03:15) and other recent ones I have tried crashes out during the formatting stage while attempting to display pages from Ebuyer.
The home page http://www.ebuyer.com/customer/home/ does and a direct product page did too.
Have attached a gzipped log.
issue.additional_information:
czantra added a note on Sat Dec 2 23:57:44 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1447221 Originator: YES
I concur. The current NetSurf seems to have no problems with the current Ebuyer site.
not_ginger_matt added a note on Sat Dec 2 16:44:36 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199 Originator: NO
Can you please try these pages with the latest build as I'm unable to reproduce this.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1544253 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

bursa added a note on Wed May 2 02:08:56 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=453739 Originator: YES
Autobuilder now has the latest libxml2 with this fixed.
jmb202 added a note on Sun Mar 18 00:53:38 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
This is fixed upstream, so is just waiting on an updated libxml on the autobuilder.
bursa added a note on Mon Jul 24 20:24:10 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
The bug hasn't been fixed. The page may have changed so that the precise conditions required to trigger it are no longer present.
I'll leave the bug open.
James
pnyoung added a note on Mon Jul 24 12:51:23 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1386864
This seems to have been solved, for the originally offending site at any rate.
Many thanks,
Peter.
bursa added a note on Sun Jul 16 21:11:25 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Reported upstream as http://bugzilla.gnome.org/347708
Imported from sourceforge bug #1523427 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Netsurf hangs when attempting to apply online for EHIC
issue.description:
Netsurf hangs (requiring an Alt-Break) when attempting to decode the final stylesheet for the page
http://www.dh.gov.uk/PolicyAndGuidance/HealthAdviceForT ravellers/fs/en
WebsterXL, faced with the same problem, simply displays a blank page, but I am able to access the site by turning off CSS support; obviously this isn't an option in Netsurf. (Shouldn't it be possible to ignore all remote stylesheets and fall back on Netsurf's own?)
The log simply states "Failed writing body": full log attached below.
issue.additional_information:
harriet added a note on Sun Feb 11 20:32:09 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=208570 Originator: YES
I confirm that this now works for me with the 11 February 2007 build - thanks.
tlsa added a note on Sat Feb 10 23:42:46 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
This seems to work now. Please reply if it still hangs for you with the latest build.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1492034 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
This URL:
http://5thnovember.blogspot.com/
displays fine, but cannot be added to the hotlist either by Adjust on the toolbar icon or via the 'Add to hotlist' menu entry. Prefix it with www and it can be added.
Incidentally, this URL is one that regularly seems to spontaneously disappear from the hotlist (along with bOING bOING)
3 Dec build, RO 5.11
issue.additional_information:
cjt02 added a note on Thu Dec 7 21:22:02 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1397835 Originator: YES
Works OK now; thanks.
jmb202 added a note on Mon Dec 4 11:51:17 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
This works here with the 4th Dec 2006 02:15 build. Please try with that (or a later version, if available) and report back.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1608279 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: crash in hlcache when attempting download
issue.description:
r13251 of NetSurf is crashing consistently by following the following steps : Go to http://www.google.co.uk Type in "gettext" and search. Click on the top link (page is http://www.gnu.org/s/gettext/ - probably ok to start here) Scroll down to the link "the latest release is..." Click on this link.
Top offsets in the stack trace:
9.Files:Projects/netsurf_svn/netsurf> a2l netsurf 572b8 content/hlcache.c:664 9.Files:Projects/netsurf_svn/netsurf> a2l netsurf 56dc8 content/hlcache.c:526 9.Files:Projects/netsurf_svn/netsurf> a2l netsurf 59db8 content/llcache.c:1463
issue.additional_information:
chris_y added a note on Thu Dec 8 19:45:11 2011
I have a NetSurf log file if needed, I forgot to login to submit this bug and now it won't let me add any more files.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3454606 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
I accidently keyed in a URL as http:moodle.org when I should have keyed http://moodle.org. NS crashed.
This happened also with http:google.calendar.com
message in log says:- content/fetchcache.c fetchcache_go 223: url http:moodle.org, status TYPE_UNKNOWN "content/urldb.c", line 1416: urldb_add_host: Assertion failed: host riscos/gui.c ro_gui_signal 755: Dumping: 'http://rickman.orpheusweb.co.uk/lynx/index.htm'
issue.additional_information:

Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
http://a_a/ is fixed, but requires the autobuilder's copy of UnixLib to be updated, which will happen in due course.

I don't know what it was trying to resolve as a domain name, but it's an acceptable response. Sorry about the dump. I can't upload a file if it's not my bug report.

issue.description:

issue.description:
There are some problems with certain webpages that are utf8 encoded: e.g. <http://www.instituteus.com/news/turkish/>
Multibyte utf8 sequences such as e.g. \xC4 \xB0 and \xE2 \x80 \x99 are not displayed correctly.
I checked the utf8 codes with Zap (1.47) and they are correct.
issue.additional_information:
sclaes added a note on Sat Jun 3 21:42:53 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
It seems NS displays question marks because there are invalid UTF-8 codes in that webpage.
sclaes added a note on Sat Jun 3 21:08:49 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
I found a webpage that has no top-bit character in the body of the title element and yet it is not displayed correctly... <http://www.lyricwiki.org/Shakira:Peligro>
Any idea why?
sclaes added a note on Fri Feb 17 01:52:02 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
At least it worked once (i.e. after forcing a reload with adjust clicking on the reload button all paragraphs were displayed correctly) but it doesn't seem to work anymore (after reloading the webpage by clicking with select on the reload button, the first paragraphs were displayed incorrectly again).
Very bizarre :-/
sclaes added a note on Fri Feb 17 01:43:11 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
Reloading the webpage seems to solve the problem.
sclaes added a note on Fri Feb 17 01:40:40 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
And why are only the first two paragraphs displayed incorrectly? e.g. <http://www.civcivler.com/okul.htm>
sclaes added a note on Fri Feb 17 01:35:24 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
Why do almost all applications assume 8859-1 instead of using the current alphabet? It just doesn't make any sense.
jmb202 added a note on Fri Dec 23 21:22:18 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Yes. This is a known issue with the parser. Essentially, if it detects a top-bit-set byte before the character set for the document is determined, it assumes 8859-1 and refuses to change this even if there's a <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=foo"> tag later in the document.
See http://moose.mine.nu/testcases/utf8test.html for a testcase for this (the source also contains comments explaining the issue in more depth and a pointer to the code section that causes this).
I'm not entirely sure of the best solution to this (other than perhaps parsing the <head> of the document first, extracting any charset information and then reparsing the whole document with the charset specified).
Imported from sourceforge bug #1389126 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Google search string reappears after deletion.
issue.description:

However if I remove the text with Ctrl-U and then I go to Google 'News', I still get news articles related to the deleted text string, which has reappeared in the search box. Here's how I repeat it:
http://www.google.co.nz or http://www.google.com.au
Type 'penguin' in the search box and press enter. Now delete 'penguin' with ctrl-u or by repeatedly pressing delete.
With the search box now empty, click on 'News'. Result = 'penguin' reappears in the search box and all the news articles relate to it.
Brian quattroi@clear.net.nz Build 9 Jan 19:45 RISC OS 5.11
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Wed Jan 10 23:14:43 2007

issue.summary: Title in window title bar displayed as latin-1 ?
issue.description:
The title of a webpage is displayed as latin-1 instead of the correct encoding.
e.g. <http://www.osmanli.org.tr/>
The title is latin-5 encoded, but it is displayed as if it were latin-1 (there are in fact 2 encodings listed: windows-1254 and iso-8859-9)
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sat Feb 10 23:07:33 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
Meta charset declarations occurring after the title element is now fixed. The display strangeness appears to be down to the Wimp's caching of the current alphabet for font display - a full-screen redraw (i.e. f12, return) updates the cache.
sclaes added a note on Tue Jul 11 18:41:00 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
The problem seems only to appear if the title precedes the meta http-equiv tag...
sclaes added a note on Tue Jul 11 18:03:07 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
It is even stranger than I thought: if I load the webpage and then change the alphabet from utf8 to latin5, then the title appears differently from what I described below. But if I adjust the size of the window, then the window title bar changes.
cf http://www.archimedes.be/Images/NS/before.jpeg and http://www.archimedes.be/Images/NS/after.jpeg
sclaes added a note on Tue Jul 11 17:27:21 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1055477
I forgot to mention: current alphabet is UTF8
In latin-5 the dotless i has code \xfd, but when I select this encoding (*alphabet latin5) then the dotless i (in the window title bar) is transformed to \x8e \xfd
Bizarre... the dotless i has unicode codepoint u+0131 and is encoded as \xc4 \xb1 in utf-8, so I have no idea where the \x8e comes from.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1520588 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description: http://www.gutenberg.org/files/25504/25504-h/images/map_big.png leads to a 2635KB PNG file. When it is dropped into a NetSurf window, Netsurf 2.0 (Dev) (26 May 2008 11:00) r4210 crashes. Log file attached. SARPC RO6.06
issue.additional_information:
old_coaster added a note on Tue Jun 3 15:17:54 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=1384902 Originator: YES
Yes, there's now an out of memory warning but, having grabbed the memory, NetSurf r4238 doesn't release it. Some notes:
boot RO6.06, run NetSurf 104MB free drop the large PNG onto NetSurf, it displays without error 38MB free thus the PNG > Sprite takes about 66MB
close the PNG display 103MB free load etext 75MB free so there should be enough space to display the PNG?
adjust-click on small map in etext to display large PNG. a new window opens but _immediately_ NetSurf warns 'running out of memory ...' 13MB free
this suggests that NetSurf now estimates the size of the Sprite, before starting to convert the PNG, and has reserved 62MB for it
why wasn't a larger reservation made so that the PNG could be displayed?
close the empty PNG window 13MB free
close the etext window 18MB free
why doesn't NetSurf release the memory when all its windows are closed?
quit NetSurf 109MB free
Tony
bursa added a note on Sun Jun 1 01:29:45 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=453739 Originator: NO
NetSurf needs enough memory to store the uncompressed image as a Sprite, which is approx. 70MB.
It shouldn't have crashed, and I've fixed this in r4237. You should now get an out of memory warning.
James
old_coaster added a note on Sat May 31 20:58:53 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=1384902 Originator: YES
The machine has 128+2MB RAM. Loading NetSurf, after a clean boot, reduces this to 104MB free.
The PNG is an enlarged map, linked to from a smaller version, in a Gutenberg etext. After displaying the etext, about 75MB RAM is free, and it is then that clicking the link, to display the larger map, fails.
However, I now find that if the PNG is dropped into NetSurf, _before_ displaying the etext (ie when 104MB RAM is free) then the PNG _does_ display without error. I am surprised that so much RAM is needed.
So your implied guess - too little memory - is correct, and this is not primarily a NetSurf problem. Many thanks for your rapid response.
Tony
bursa added a note on Sat May 31 19:40:00 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=453739 Originator: NO
How much RAM does this machine have?
Imported from sourceforge bug #1978373 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Broken pipe whilst using Google mail
issue.description:
The 05 Nov 2006 20:00 test build of NetSurf just crashed, leaving a log file in which the last message is "Termination signal received: Broken pipe". The symptoms are very similar to bug #1519138, which has been closed. At the time I was browsing my Google mail inbox, and I believe that I had just clicked on a link to view an e-mail. I was browsing the BBC News web site at the same time.
NetSurf often crashes when I am using Google mail, but usually it just leaves a truncated log with no error message, register dump, or stack backtrace. It is unusual for it to record a coherent error message. I will attach the log file (zipped).
It is not so much the error that is irritating (perhaps it is legitimate), but the fact that it is fatal and NetSurf does not report it properly.
issue.additional_information:

Logged In: YES user_id=1227467 Originator: YES

This may be due to an improvement in Google's service. I don't know how to articificially 'break a pipe', but under the circumstances, suppressing SIGPIPE does seem sensible.

issue.summary: Memory leak when redirection is taken ?
issue.description:
Visiting the frontpage of http://www.standaard.be/ means loading about 150 objects and most of them load very quickly. However the last object takes a long time and during that period NetSurf memory usage grows steadily to about 22 MByte while communication with the server goes on.
I suspect this memory usage is unnecessary and might show a memory leak in the redirection code : in the attached log file you see that the last object to be loaded is njs.gif which constantly gets refered to another URL by a 303 Object Moved server responce, each time adding to the URL the "&dcsredirect=1" string. This happens about 292 times and then its stops (not sure why). But in the meanwhile I guess about 15 MByte of RAM is wasted.
So several questions: - Is NetSurf behaving correctly in the sense that the server constantly replies with 303 Object Moved ? I guess this is a server/website configuration stupidity, right ? - Shouldn't there be a sensible bound to the number of URL redirections ? Or is there one but not yet met ? Or is the 292 one ? - Probably the most important question : am I right suspecting there is a memory leak in the redirection code ?
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1540982 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
**Original Post to Mail list [amended] as follows since your response**
Since the upgrade of NetSurf [around the end of May (delete previous ref to Style Sheets)] I have been unable to complete any financial transactions via https web pages.
[ Normal HTTPS usage for sign-up to mail lists, register with SourceForge etc.is perfect! ]
This first showed with PayPal, which I was not too bothered about as I only rarely use it, and after the kerfuffle with their new T&C acknowlegement, I am even less so.
However, this week I needed to upgrade my details with ISP 'Free-online.Net' ( branch of PlusNet) and find it impossible to log into the secure section. My last [sucessful] access was in January.
The open pages of this site load quickly and fully with no problems -
- I am on Dial-Up -
But as soon as I go to the secure pages everything slows to a crawl. Lots of errors occur such as 'errror loading object', 'SSL timedout' and 'failed after 30xxx millisec'
During all this Style sheets are loading and then the message 'Converting xxx bytes' appears for what appears to be up to 40 odd seconds at a time.
Finally 'loading xx objects' takes for ever then 'processing page' starts.
A few seconds after this NetSurf disappears from the Icon bar with a continuous Hour Glass.
PayPal behaviour is similar.
Inspection of the Log shows 'Termination signal received: Broken pipe' as the final entry
Throughout the log there are many listings of the ISP's secure certificate.
[ copy of log 'nslog/zip' attached - Ns version 0804]
Tried again today with version 0819 and got a new error, never seen before, a window saying 'netsurf failed to verify SSL certificate' and listing three certificate names.
best regards - Bryn Evans
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Mon Feb 26 01:19:58 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
Closing this as SSL connections are now back to the same kind of speed as they were before parallel fetching and handle caching was implemented.
jmb202 added a note on Thu Jan 18 02:04:19 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
The broken pipe crash should be fixed now. SSL connections in general are slow, although I'm not sure there's much we can do about that. However, I've also reverted the change which prevented caching of SSL connection handles, so it may now be a bit faster.
The certificate verification dialog appearing is not an error; it's telling you that NetSurf couldn't verify the validity of the certificate chain provided by the server, so it's providing you with the details to make a decision as to whether you trust the other party or not.
Please test with the latest build (18/01/2007 01:30 UTC) and report back about whether you experience any further broken pipe crashes or SSL timeouts. For the timebeing, I'm going to reduce the priority of this bug as it's no longer a crash.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1544731 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: "Invalid multibyte sequence" given for GIF as text/plain
issue.description:
The URL http://list.mail.ru/10928/1/0_1_0_1.html gives a message box reporting "IconvFailed: Invalid multibyte sequence".
A quick first-look revealed:
[01:48] <jmb> they've sent a GIF as text/plain with a charset of CP1251 [01:48] <jmb> hence the warning [01:49] * jmb wonders if it'd be better to simply log the error rather than reporting it to the user; they shouldn't really care, anyway [01:51] <joty> I agree, the user doesn't care [01:51] <jmb> trouble is; if they're actually loading a text document, they would care [01:51] <jmb> and at the point the error happens, we can't tell the difference :/ [01:56] <jmb> actually; it shouldn't matter; if they're loading a text document, the browser window will be the owner and it'll handle the error for us [01:57] <jmb> hm. I think our content handler error handling needs looking at; I'm not sure any of them should call warn_user directly
Jo.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1580127 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:

The archive contains the form, the input text, the resulting page and a screen shot (sprite) of the relevant part of the output. I have saved the log in case it's needed, and I may also be able to identify the relevant scripts.
The result page is displayed in a similar manner by Fresco and Oregano 1.10. If special characters are entered on Fresco or Oregano they are output correctly on all three browsers, because they go through unaltered.

issue.description:

The site updates every 15 minutes (when the PC is on) and the upload time is shown at the bottom of each weather graphic. o If you drag the window resize icon to and fro horizontally, you will see some text behind the sky graphic in the top frame. This text matches the following statement at the beginning of the index.html page - <!DOCTYPEÂ HTMLÂ PUBLICÂ "-//W3C//DTDÂ HTMLÂ 4.01Â Frameset//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/frameset.dtd">

issue.description:
With apologies for the ludicrous length of this URL:
http://www.dh.gov.uk/PublicationsAndStatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/PublicationsPAmpGBrowsableDocument/fs/en?CONTENT_ID=4097241&MULTIPAGE_ID=4912278&chk=kcvxqz
(I did try to use makeashorterurl, but found another bug ;-)
This gives a warning in the message bar:
Warning: stylesheet is not CSS
and hourglasses extensively. It does eventually display the page after a couple of minutes (Iyonix), but apparently without any styling applied.
The Firefox debugger reports no problems with the page or the CSS (which consists of multiple @includes, many of which contain CRLF linefeeds).
10 Dec build, RO 5.11
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Tue Oct 9 19:48:17 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Closing this as the URL nolonger seems to work.
The issue was that there was no content-type header with the CSS. Now it is treated as text, rather than HTML, so there is no long period of hourglassing. Content-type sniffing has not been implemented in NetSurf (as the spec. says it shouldn't be). There are several other items on the tracker about implementing content-type sniffing so this bug may as well be closed.
Thanks for reporting.
tlsa added a note on Thu Dec 28 12:55:03 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Changing the default type to text/plain has fixed the long period of hourglassing.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1620549 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Frames with vert scrollbars also need horizontal scrolling?

Fantastic that FRAMES now works in most cases. well done!

issue.summary: Hit area for link on image
issue.description: If an image with a link on it is constrained by height and width arguments to a smaller size than it actually is then the hit area for the link extends to the right and below the bounds of the image, probably to the original size of the image. It is probable that the converse applies if the image is stretched beyond its original size but I haven't tested this.

I can now confirm that if a small image is stretched the hit area for the link is correct. If a large image is compressed then the hit area is wrong.

issue.summary: FONT not applied to ordinals in Ordered List
issue.description:
With
  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2
The ordinals (the "1" and "2") show as black and the list items show as red. I believe the FONT attribute should apply to the ordinal as well as the list item. I first noticed the problem with where I found the size difference between the ordinal and the list item particularly noticeable (and annoying). Putting the FONT attribute outside the OL tag works as required but is not valid HTML.. Putting the FONT attribute around the LI also works but the ordinal numbering goes wrong. As this is also not valid HTML I do not think the wrong ordering matters. Richard Wheeler
issue.additional_information:

Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Firefox, Konqueror and Opera all do as NetSurf does.

issue.description:
While using !LinkSure, occasionally the report it produced caused Netsurf to abort at various stages of loading/rendering. Generally the document being loaded was large - although I did find it happen witha smallish one - once.
I say that the abort occurred at various stages because on the state pane at the window bottom various messages appeared - the one appearing most often being something like "3/345 bad object .." but others gave "fatal error" only - before the error window requesting this report appeared.
Interestingly also, merely a single 'click' to dismiss the window did not result in any action - a second click was necessary - resulting in the log file attached.
While this error does crop up with LinkSure documents I have not had it occur with any other URL, so thought to attach the source if that might help in diagnosis.
Whatever the message which appeared at the bottom of the window every log file had exactly the same callback list at the end.
Over to you!
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz

issue.description:
When attempting to render/display a local file of about 300k, Netsurf (15 Aug build) crashed - after some long time.
It reported that the document was complete (though nothing was displayed) after 8.5 seconds or so and then, almost immediately, the red/yellow hourglass appeared. After a further minute Netsurf closed the logfile after giving a trace and register dump.
Early on in the rendering process a warning indicated that box->last was wrong. The entire document seemed to have been rendered before a whole lot of additional stuff was written to the log - apparently some configuration information and finally many lines relating to fonts and font names.
Unfortunately the log file is 17Mb raw (about a third of a Mb as a zip file) - which sourceforge complained about - incompletely - as an error.
I have a zip file containing the original local file and the log if you wish me to forward it direct to someone.
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
PS Sorry that this is the third error report this am - but I have the odd feeling that this one might be related to the first one.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Apr 8 23:29:46 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
Reporter no longer has the log but claims that they have not seen this issue in any build this year. Closing.
bursa added a note on Wed Aug 16 14:44:37 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Please email the file and log to me, james@semichrome.net
NetSurf outputs various internal structures to the log when it detects a crash (document tree, user choices, font data, etc.) to help with debugging. This is normal, and can take some time.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1541024 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Incorrect font names in exported !Draw files
issue.description:
When NetSurf exports a page as a draw file, the font names are incorrect (I just verified with Castle). For instance, Homerton.Bold\EUTF8
The fontname shouldn't have \EUTF8 at the end, and this is preventing the Drawfile from being subsequently printed via !Printers.
This is using NetSurf2 29th Aug 00:30 build.
Paul (Vigay)
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Tue Oct 2 06:06:12 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=453739 Originator: NO
This is intentional. NetSurf on RISC OS 5 creates Drawfiles that contain Unicode text encoded using UTF8, so it sets the encoding on the font identifier.
Unfortunately Printers on RO5 does not support UTF8 when using a PostScript printer.
James
Imported from sourceforge bug #1794784 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Netsurf exits when using https via proxy server
issue.description:
When using Netsurf to view web pages that may have content accessable via https:// (e.g. www.drobe.co.uk has a Paypal donate button) and a simple proxy server is configured, Netsurf will exit and leave the hourglass running.
Any use of https:// with a proxy will cause Netsurf to exit without error. The log file registers a SSL connection made to the proxy and nothing else - no subsequent errors or warnings are reported.
Configuring no proxy solves the problem, even if the proxy performs transparent proxying. The proxy server is squid-2.5 STABLE 1-2 running on Red Hat Linux 9.0.
Netsurf 07-May-2006 build running on 233 MHz rev S StrongARM Risc PC with 64 MB RAM, 2MB VRAM, WindowManager 3.98 and RISC OS 3.70.

issue.description:
When uploading an xhtml file to the W3C validator, Netsurf incorrectly types the file as text/html instead of application/xhtml+xml - reported by the validator!
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Fri Feb 20 15:00:39 2009
This entirely depends upon your MimeMap file. NetSurf uses the MimeMap module to map between RISC OS filetypes and MIME types. It sounds like the file you were uploading was typed as &FAF (i.e. HTML). I'm not aware that there is a filetype allocation for XHTML.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1769710 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Aborted save provokes crash on next click-drag
issue.description:
Load a page with graphics on it.
Click-drag in the page, and the mouse pointer should change to a hand icon, allowing you to drag-scroll the page up and down, if it's big enough.
Menu-click a graphic on the page, select Object->Save->Save as
Drag and drop the file icon somewhere useless, like an empty area on the task bar or the pinboard, thereby producing an aborted save.
Now try click-dragging again anywhere in the page, and you should get the hand icon again for an instant, and an immediate crash of Netsurf. In practice of course, the tiniest movement when clicking could get interpreted as a drag-scroll. Thereafter, the next inadvertent click-drag, /even several pages later/ will provoke a crash. Log files available if needed, but this is now 100% repeatable for me.
(Tested with gif, png and jpg, may well apply to any aborted save.)
issue.additional_information:

Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO

issue.summary: utils/filename.c makes use of BSD extensions
issue.description:
utils/filename.c makes use of the d_type field in struct dirent, which is a BSD extension, and prevents NetSurf building under Solaris, and most likely other esoteric UNIX variants.
Ideally, this code should be reworked to stat() where it needs to know the type, and use the IS_DIR() macro instead.
issue.additional_information:
rjek added a note on Sun Jun 10 12:31:11 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=893271 Originator: YES
Fix in r3317/3318. Uses stat().
Imported from sourceforge bug #1706804 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Save box uses ROM HTML sprite in preference to current one.
issue.description:
On RISC OS 4.02, on both Netsurf 1.0 and Netsurf 1.1: When doing a save from the menu or F3, the HTML sprite is always the ROM one, rather than the current one loaded into the wimp pool.
This is particularly odd considering Netsurf adds its own pretty HTML file icon to the wimp pool on loading.
Looking at the registers received by DragASprite, you're creating a special sprite area and putting the sprite in there. Wouldn't it be easier to just pass 1?
issue.additional_information:
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Oct 9 18:49:59 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=999199 Originator: NO
The reason for the sprite area is to handle the dynamically generated document preview icons. The issue here was the fetching of icons defaulted to the ROM pool rather than the RAM pool which has now been fixed in the development build. R.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1781184 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Shift+Adjust on links behaves as plain Adjust
issue.description:
From: Christopher Martin <belles@internode.on.net>
I am using version 2.0 (Dev) (20 Aug 2007 02:45) r3529. But as I recall, this has been a long-standing bug. According to the User Guide, a Shift+Adjust click on a link should allow saving the target address as a URL. However, the behaviour is the same as that produced by plain Adjust, as if the Shift key status is being ignored.
Tonight, I downloaded the latest sources via SVN. I think I may have identified the cause of the problem. There is a block of code in function browser_window_mouse_action_html(...), in file <netsurf.desktop.c.browser>, in which three if-else tests are performed. The order of the tests is significant. The present order is as follows:
if (mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_1 && mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_MOD_1) { ... } else if (mouse & (BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_1 | BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_2)) { ... } else if (mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_2 && mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_MOD_1) { ... }
Might I suggest you consider swapping the 2nd and 3rd tests so that the structure becomes:
if (mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_1 && mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_MOD_1) { ... } else if (mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_2 && mouse & BROWSER_MOUSE_MOD_1) { ... } else if (mouse & (BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_1 | BROWSER_MOUSE_CLICK_2)) { ... }
I have attached a modified version of <netsurf.desktop.c.browser> for your consideration. (I should mention that I do not yet have all the tools needed to build Netsurf for myself and test my changes.)
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Sun Aug 26 18:00:34 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Thanks for the fix. I've tested it and applied it.
nobody added a note on Fri Aug 24 09:00:33 2007
Logged In: NO
From: Christopher Martin <belles@internode.on.net>
I have now recompiled Netsurf and the changes outlined do indeed solve the problem.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1779560 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Thu Sep 6 14:56:49 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
JavaScript is currently unsupported. If you don't want to lose the current page (perhaps due to filled in form information), follow links with an adjust click, to ensure they open in a new window.
rik_g added a note on Mon Jun 25 15:04:51 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1577829 Originator: NO
Those "(?)" links use javascript to pop open a new window. Of course NetSurf doesn't do JS, but it appears that it's parsing part of the javascript as a valid URL.
If you want to ensure you open something in a new window, get into the habit of right (adjust) clicking on links :)

issue.summary: PNG library error - BMP typed as PNG
issue.description:
When Netsurf tries to fetch the file at:
http://phoenix.inf.upol.cz/~opichals/aranym/papyrusXdemoA.png
it displays "PNG library error" Netsurf Test Build (28 Feb 2006 01:15)

issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Sun Sep 4 11:33:01 2011
Fixed in 12707.
element3260 added a note on Tue Mar 3 06:44:34 2009
This bug still exists in the latest development version.
element3260 added a note on Tue Mar 3 06:44:34 2009
What is the expected behaviour in this case?
bursa added a note on Sat Mar 4 17:46:02 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
The image is actually a BMP, not a PNG, even though it is served with "Content-Type: image/png".
NetSurf's behaviour is correct according to the HTTP spec (see 7.2.1). However, we may implement detection of the type from the content for images in future.

issue.description:
Many phBB forums have an additional style tag within the body of the page to define the styles used topic and message tables. NetSurf currently ignores these leading to a very poor quality display. Manually putting the tag in the hader reveals NetSurf can display all the table styles correctly.
Examples are:-
http:///rx8ownersclub.co.uk/forum/index.php http://www.pocketgpsworld.com/modules.php?name=Forums&file=viewforum&f=61&sid=e5f315601cf6e78943e57ac18251237d While styles tags in the body my not be strictly correct they are handled by all other browsers including W3Cs Amaya. The ommision in NetSurf is a great pity as its fast rendering is ideal for these sites, which are pitifully slow and tedious with other RISC OS browsers.

issue.summary: Exotic fonts not appearing in pull-down menus
issue.description:
The fiollowing URL generates Lorem Ipsum text in, among other languages, Cyrillic, Hebrew, Elvish(!), Thai, Morse Code(!!) and Arabic.
http://www.lorem-ipsum.info/generator3
But the languages that use non-Roman characters appear entirely blank in the language/charset pull-down menu. (BTW I was thoroughly impressed to see Netsurf displaying them all so smoothly). Clicking blind selects the non-Roman fonts fine, so this is probably a RISC OS issue with exotic characters in menus rather than something NetSurf can do anything about, but I thought I'd report it anyway. Setting the system font to Cyberbit made no difference.
simon_smith*cough*zen:co:uk
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Thu Oct 27 02:25:25 2011
Realistically, we're not going to do this. Fix the Wimp, instead :)
jmb202 added a note on Wed Sep 26 20:43:30 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
This requires the Wimp to gain support for some kind of charset/font encoding specification for strings in menus (and other places, like writeables and window title bars). There's no other solution to this, short of NetSurf gaining its own implementation of the things the Wimp provides. Priority lowered appropriately.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1802990 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
In the throes of setting up part of a web site which contains many SVG images, I tried the new (15 July) version of NetSurf on the 'root' document.
http://srv.asgard.org.nz/docs/index.xhtml
Like the SVG in NetSurf, much of the site is WIP! However, I was most surprised to see that those bits of the image which did render were from an inverted whole. In addition to this some of the elements (tiny blue rectangles) do appear to have been shifted from their correct position.
If you want a real test for your SVG try -
http://srv.asgard.org.nz/alpn/index.html
for which none of the SVG currently renders at all - not even the tiny circle in NZ-PN.svg!
In reporting this bug I fully realise that SVG is very much WIP - but thought to offer some intermediate feedback.

PS All SVG images produced by Artworks

--8<-- [23:49] <jmb> Nettle: Looking up host www.davidpilling.net... [23:49] <jmb> Nettle: Connecting to 85.234.133.167... [23:49] <jmb> Nettle: Connected to 85.234.133.167 [23:49] <jmb> HEAD / HTTP/1.1 [23:49] <jmb> Host: www.davidpilling.net [23:49] <jmb> HTTP/1.1 302 Found [23:49] <jmb> Date: Tue, 10 Apr 2007 21:48:29 GMT [23:49] <jmb> Server: Apache/1.3.37 (Unix) mod_auth_passthrough/1.8 mod_log_bytes/1.2 mod_bwlimited/1.4 PHP/4.4.4 FrontPage/5.0.2.2635.SR1.2 mod_ssl/2.8.28 OpenSSL/0.9.7a [23:49] <jmb> Location: http://www.davidpilling.net// [23:49] <jmb> Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1 [23:49] <jmb> (note the Location: header in the response) [23:50] <jmb> that said, NS should handle that sanely --8<--

issue.description:
If elements in a definition list do not have a terminator </dd> then each successive definition is indented to the right. A <dt> or <dd> should implicitly close an open <dt> or <dd> element and not implicitly open a new <dl>.

issue.description:
shift-clicking on a link to a local application directory, or plain directory, doesn't download the directory, as expected, but downoads an html file, which lists the contents of the directory. For further details please see the demo-file at http://oldcoaster.drobe.co.uk/local_file_download.zip
Tony
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Thu Jan 12 13:15:04 2012
NetSurf is behaving exactly as intended here.
There is no concept of downloading a directory of files, only individual files.
When you shift click on a link it forces the download, rather than display of the link target.
So for a PNG, it forces a download for the PNG rather than displaying the PNG in NetSurf. Likewise, for a directory it forces the download of the page it uses to show the directory, instead of rendering it in NetSurf.
old_coaster added a note on Wed Jan 11 11:09:32 2012
demo file also attached here
Imported from sourceforge bug #3470312 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Files from Sunfish: cause "not found" error
issue.description:
Dragging a file from a Sunfish mount to NetSurf always results in the error "Sorry, NetSurf was unable to display this page. Could not open file /Sunfish". The URL bar shows "file:///Sunfish#::Mount.$/<path>" (where <path> is the path of the file in the mount). Removing the "#" character and pressing Return loads the file correctly. Tested with build of 07 Mar 08 on an Iyonix, 128MB, RISC OS 5.11.
The "#" character is not part of the filename sent by the Filer, but it is included when a Sunfish file name is canonicalised and at a guess, NetSurf ask for the file name to be canonicalised. After doing so, NetSurf should process the filename and replace "#" by "%23" since "#" is not a valid character in a base URL (it introduces a fragment identifier).
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Wed Apr 2 01:47:52 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
The percent encoding is fixed in SVN. However, the path translation requires an updated UnixLib, so won't appear fixed until this occurs on the autobuilder.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1910169 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

Some more details on problem are here: http://mail-index.netbsd.org/current-users/2008/03/13/msg001342.html

issue.description: I had only just reloaded NetSurf after the last crash (another segmentation fault) when it bombed again.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1978007 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Background image obscured by text not within
issue.description:
If the attributes of the tag of an HTML document specify both a background image and (to enable graceful degradation) a background colour then any text within the document body that is not enclosed by a pair of tags (e.g.

for a paragraph) aquires a plain-coloured background rectangle. A real-world example of this can be seen at http://www.starfighter.acornarcade.com/mysite/newtitle.html I have also attached a small test page that demonstrates the problem. Whereas the first two lines of text (enclosed by

and tags respectively) are rendered correctly against the background image, the last line (separated from the others only by a
) is instead rendered against a plain background.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Sat Jul 19 20:42:59 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Now fixed. Thanks for reporting!
mittens added a note on Thu Jan 26 14:28:56 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1227467
I have now worked around the problem at the URL quoted above, so it is no longer useful as an example. However Andreas Dehmel's web site has the same symptoms: http://www.zarquon.homepage.t-online.de/Manifesto.html
Imported from sourceforge bug #1414232 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Table centring has gone wrong again
issue.description:
The centring or otherwise of nested tables has gone wrong. This is an excerpt from my page http://www.mmpa.org.uk/
text
[a number of similar cells omitted]
The problem occurs in the nested table at the bottom. The cells containing the navigation buttons should be left aligned within the enclosing table cell, but they are centred. The outer table is correctly centred on the page.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Sat Mar 29 21:03:23 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Should be fixed in the latest build.

issue.description:
This is with RISC OS 5.13 and 2 April build. I expect it's my fault, but it does seem to be a bug.
I clicked on Global History before the home page was loaded; The serious error warning appeared, and NetSurf quit. I will try to attache the log file (squashed) but this usually doesn't work for me.
(Gnashes teeth) The logfile won't go. I still have it if anyone wants it
With best wishes,
Peter.

issue.description:
On my sites I use form submits with PHP code behind and generate a reply with a header like this:
Location: mailto:my@email.address
With previous NetSurf versions this worked flawlessly, far more better than with every other browser I have found (the other browsers all show the site content of that page, which contains alternative instructions of how to contact one, _and_ open a mailer, whereas NetSurf just opened the mailer like an ordinary mailto: link would have done).
However, recent NetSurf versions don't do this anymore, but just react with:
Sorry, NetSurf was unable to display this page
The address mailto:my@email.address could not be understood.
You can test this behaviour e.g. on the bottom right of http://www.sbellon.de/

issue.description:
The makefile depends on the source directory name being "netsurf". I noticed this while preparing to build a .deb for nsgtk from an exported tree (rev. 2601). I've renamed my checked-out tree "netsurf.svn" :-)
The attached patch hacks around this somewhat, and a little less than ideally *but* less intrusively; it should really remove all "netsurf/" from all #includes.
It hard-links some files into place for access by nsgtk, and I've altered the clean target appropriately.
I've removed *most* hard-coding of /usr/bin/gcc.
I've left in -I.. in $(CFLAGS_RISCOS), but I think that this really needs to be removed too.
NOTE: It /may/ break building of the other versions (I've not checked this).
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Mon Jun 12 03:55:44 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
Thanks for the patch! I'll have a look in detail when I have more time.

issue.description:
Virtual RPC-AdjustSA RISC OS 4.39 NetSurf r5194
On this and several recent issues table cells containing only sometimes render with any of > & n b s p ; < as the cell content, either singly or in combination. nobody added a note on Tue Aug 26 22:35:01 2008
Logged In: NO
This may be related to a transient problem I have seen at the beginning of a table where above the table at the left on a line of its own appears a single character - often the digit '8'.
I thought I had traced this to being a charset problem (RISCOS vis-a-vis utf8 - some 'invisible' character code - but the artefact is always outside the table area and I have not, as yet, been able to pin-point what is causing it - attempt a fix and it goes away never to come back - until the next document. No other browser shows the artefact (Firefox, Opera, Konqueror, Amaya, etc). Might this be a buffer flushing to the rendered document which is expected to be empty but isn't?
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz

issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Thu Jun 12 14:13:20 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=453739 Originator: NO
Hi Richard
Thank you for the bug report.
However, as I mentioned in 1980759, more of these reports do not help us. The log files do not contain enough information and we can not reproduce them. Until we can reproduce this or have a theory or possible fix, please stop submitting new bugs for these crashes. You already have 15 open bugs with "crash" in the summary and 11 "segmentation fault", plus some others for similar aborts. Please be assured that we know about the problems you're seeing and submitting more bugs won't get it fixed faster.
James

Yes, I found those missing tools... re2c and lemon were missing. But the Makefile did not stop!
BTW: Would be fine to have a minimal README, that hints someones attanetion to the mentioned docs Docs/BUILDING-GTK.
Normally in other projects, Docs are the details, and there are README and INSTALL.
Would be good to have at least a README also in the netsurf-packages... it makes things easier for the not-involved people.

nobody added a note on Tue Jun 17 16:11:59 2008
Logged In: NO
I found the problem: the Makefile does not stop, if packages are missing.
After installing re2c and lemon, compilation was successful.
would be fine if the Makefile (or a certain script) would detect missing tools, before compileing...
...and when there are missing tools (which possibly were not reported by a certain checker-script), that the Makefile stops the compiling process.
(I also had other missing packages, but at those stages the Makefile stopped, so I could locate those two libraries early; for re2c and lemon this was not the case.)

Hello All
When I try to Full Save the the following site - http://www.anyclean.co.uk/articles/rug-cleaning.html
I get the error - The file could not be saved due to an error: htmlSaveFileFormat failed - Is this due a bug in NetSurf or a problem with the site?

-- Geoff
issue.additional_information:
jtytgat added a note on Mon Jul 28 23:58:25 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=1420374 Originator: NO
The assert in pencil_save.c is most probably fixed by change r4782. Please check in next dev build of NS.
jmb202 added a note on Tue Jan 29 15:02:58 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
In future, please file separate bug reports for each individual issue.
The full save problem is due to the page claiming to be utf-8 encoded, then using non-utf-8 text. This causes the parser used for full save to except loudly. It's a known issue which will be fixed in due course.
The draw export problem manifests itself as an assertion on line 331 of pencil_save.c. A reboot should never be necessary. At most, the "A serious error has occurred..." error box should appear twice.

issue.summary: Master bug for crashes experienced by minijem
issue.description: I think this one happened when I clicked on a Google result.
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Wed Jul 1 13:38:05 2009
Hi Richard,
After discussion with the other developers we are convinced that the vast majority of these crashes must be due to a serious problem with the hardware that you are using.
We haven't been able reproduce any of them, and the pattern and frequency of crashes is unique to your reports. The test builds that we sent you found no software bugs. I'm sorry, but there's nothing we can do to solve this, and more reports or log files are not going to change that.
Therefore we're going to close this and the other similar bugs. We request that you don't report more crashes until you replace your hardware.
James

bursa added a note on Sat Sep 13 22:58:50 2008
In order to deal with the crashes you're seeing, we would like to manage the communication in one place. I have chosen this bug as the place. Please don't submit any new bugs. Instead add comments to this bug.
Please download the special debug build at http://zamez.org/netsurf-debug.zip
When NetSurf crashes, it will produce 3 files additional to the log file in your root or current directory: dmalloc_log, NetSurf_Slot, and NetSurf_DA. Please email those and the log to me directly for the next 1 crash only, except if it has hubbub in the backtrace at the end of the log.
James
