issue.description:
From: john@schild.demon.co.uk
I regularly download new NetSurf releases to run on Iyonix with 5.11 OS in 16 million 1600x1200 mode on Iyama Pro454.
Since mid-November the web page image graphics in the toolbar history graphics window do not display. The window grows as links are followed and floating the mouse pointer over the history window displays the associated URL information as would be expected had the graphics been present.
I am not aware of any change made to the computer which might have triggered this fault. I did not report it before because I thought it would have been picked up and corrected some time ago had it been a general experience.
issue.additional_information:
smiffles_2000 added a note on Mon Jan 1 22:02:24 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1681025 Originator: NO
I have this problem too. History graphics used to work then just stopped, the floating url message works but not the graphics. I recently found that to get the History thumbnails to work you need to use an external programme such as Sargasso or Messenger to open the Netsurf window. The thumbnails will continue to be generated provided you only navigate using links on the pages you visit. If you manually enter a URL into the address bar the thumbnails stop appearing from the page you entered the URL for. The previous page thumbnails that appeared continue to appear so long as the window is not closed.
I am using Test Build (01 Jan 2007 20:45) on a RISC PC with OS 4.37
Adam.
riscosman added a note on Fri Dec 29 23:02:34 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1603677 Originator: NO
Now you see it now you don't! Since reporting that this problem had gone away. (see comment 9 Dec 06) the problem has returned. But - it is now a reproducible problem.
If I use NetSurf to browse a set of html pages on my harddisc then the local history window shows images. On the other hand if I browse remotely then the local history window is blank.
bursa added a note on Fri Dec 22 20:50:26 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739 Originator: NO
This problem may depend on the sites that have been visited. If you reproduce it again, please attach !Scrap.ScrapDirs.ScrapDir.WWW.NetSurf.Log after quitting NetSurf.
James
riscosman added a note on Sat Dec 9 22:41:15 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1603677 Originator: NO
Curious - I reported this on 21 September 2006 id 1563147. The odd thing is that it has just started working again on both my A9 and Iyonix (5.12) I am running Test Build (11 November 2006 20:00)
But the even more curious thing is that it was not working on the Iyonix last week with the same level of NetSurf, although it was working on the A9. What I can't recall is whether it is since updating to 5.12 that it has started to work.

issue.description:
Exhibited on the BBC News website where onmouseover command text is sometimes displayed between image navigation buttoms at the bottom of the page.
Example; http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/pop_ups/07/uk_stricken_ship/html/1.stm moving through the images by pressing next or previous or clicking on the numbered buttons will cause the fault to occur randomly. It is not a fault on indivisual pages, as apart from the image name and text, they are otherwise identical (and contain exactly the same W3C validation errors).
issue.additional_information:
bursa added a note on Thu Jun 7 06:28:42 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=453739 Originator: NO
This is due to a bug in libxml2. It occurs when the chunks of data received are split at a certain point in the file, so only happens some of the time.
I've reported the bug upstream:
http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=444994
Imported from sourceforge bug #1640394 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
Hi,
I can't reply to the previous report. Please don't close the report, without giving a chance for an answer. I haven't changed anything locally. All I did is
$ svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libcss $ cd libcss $ make

issue.summary: libparserutils not using iconv on RISC OS
issue.description:
Since iconv causes NetSurf to crash when libparserutils is configured to use it, we currently use lpu's internal encoding support.
This means we can't load pages which are in certain encodings on RISC OS at the moment. This particularly affects eastern encodings.

issue.summary: Improper call to search program on FreeBMD
issue.description:
I've used the FreeBMD site http://freebmd.rootsweb.com/cgi/search.pl extensively in the past with Netsurf. between r4853 and r5031 something changed so an error now results. i'[ve just confirmed this is still happening with R5131.
To see what I mean enter a simple search on the page I gave teh link to. An example would be Types: Births; Surname: Pinder, Date range Mar 1901 - Dec 1910.
This generates this error:
Content-type: text/html
The FreeBMD site has encountered an error. Please try again later.The error that has been reported is: ERR02: Improper call to search program - no hash at /usr/local/lib/perl5/5.8.8/CGI/Carp.pm line 409 CGI::Carp::croak('ERR02: Improper call to search program - no hash') called at /home/apache/hosts/freebmd/cgi/search.pl line 233 www4.freebmd.org.uk
This message means that your browser is not sending all the necessary data to FreeBMD.
This is NOT a problem with the FreeBMD server, it is a problem with the way you are attempting to access the data
1. You must not use 3rd party add-on programs to search FreeBMD 2. You must not use search forms on other web sites to search FreeBMDThis is a new security system. This error can be caused by cached copies of the page. Please clear your browser cache"
Good luck with sorting this, and thanks for all your efforts to date!
Andrew Pinder Andrew.Pinder@tiscali.co.uk

issue.description:
The 'Update' feature on the IMDb no longer seems to work with Netsurf. Clicking on the Update button on any of the relevant pages leads to a page with a single unlabelled checkbox and 'Cancel' and 'Choose again' buttons, instead of the expected drop-down menu icon with appropriate selections for that section of the film database... The actual HTML served up to Netsurf seems to be different, not merely the browser's rendering of it!
To demonstrate: go to the URL https://secure.imdb.com/register-imdb/login and log in as the sample user 'Cunarder', password 'websterxl'
Visit the page http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0058007/trivia (Trivia for the 1964 horror movie 'Devil Doll') Click on the yellow 'Update' icon at the bottom of the page.
Under the heading 'Fun Stuff' at the bottom of the new page you should see a drop-down menu list that currently reads 'No change'; select 'Add one item' from this menu and click on the 'Continue' icon.
You ought now to see a long list of instructions, with a writable icon at the bottom into which the new data can be typed.
Using Netsurf, what you see is a blank page beneath the standard IMDb header, with a single unlabelled checkbox and a pair of 'Cancel' and 'Continue' buttons - no way of actually entering any data!
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #2213067 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
Netsurf (21 Oct r5612) seems to be having some trouble with the IMDb's MyMovies feature. Copying films from one 'category' (list of film entries) to another no longer works, and nor do attempts to create new categories. Both worked the last time I tried them (on earlier versions of NetSurf) and still work with WebsterXL with JavaScript disabled - so it can't be a case of newly-introduced JavaScript dependency...
This behaviour can be demonstrated on a sample account: go to http://imdb.com and log in as user 'Cunarder', password 'websterxl', then select "Cunarder's account" from the various options at the top of the page. Click on 'Update MyMovies' (in centre column) and you should see a list of 8 titles under the heading "Cunarder's Movies".
Select an appropriate title by clicking on the option icon to its left, select the empty category 'Depp' from the menu icon at the bottom of the list, and attempt to copy the title into that category by clicking the 'Copy' button.
What *should* happen is that the page reopens to display the new contents of the destination category; what actually happens on Netsurf is that the page reopens on the same list, and the title is not copied to the destination category at all (as can be established by clicking on the 'Depp' entry listed on the left of the page).
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #2212986 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Fails to load pages on Fedora 9
issue.description:
NetSurf 1.2 won't load any page on Fedora 9, it just says "Opening page..." with the throbber animation running.
I think this is due to a change in libcurl 7.18.1 (http://curl.haxx.se/changes.html):
- setting the CURLOPT_SSL_CTX_FUNCTION with libcurl built without OpenSSL now makes curl_easy_setopt() properly return failure
Fedora 8 used libcurl 7.16 which would explain why this works. Fedora 8 and 9's libcurl packages appears to be built against NSS for SSL support.
With lines 614 and 615 of content/fetchers/fetch_curl.c commented out pages are loaded.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Fri Feb 20 13:59:17 2009
We've worked around this in the buildsystem. The long term fix requires libcurl 7.19.x to be shipped by distributions.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1957289 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

All you get on screen is
\n"); w.document.write("
which appears to be part of a bit of Javascript. The Javascript is correctly enclosed in HTML comments but NetSurf doesn't seem to be ignoring it. Could it be because the script includes unescaped < and >?
The software used by Dundee is also used for about thirty other university library catalogues in the UK so it's a nuisance for anyone wanting to use these resources.
Hope you can fix this!
Tested with NetSurf version 1.1 and also with the development build of 17 Sept 2007 15:00 (r3545) on an Iyonix running RISC OS 5.13.
NetSurf doesn't crash, but it doesn't display anything useful for this page.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1799151 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Unmatched end comment not handled correctly
issue.description: NS 28th Feb. - When I removed the start of a comment but left the start of tag and the end comment i.e. <!--July:--> changed to <July:--> text further down in a different table cell disappeared. There were no other intervening comment delimiters or any preceding open comment. Removing the -- caused the text to reappear, as did removing both delimiters completely. Unless a comment is currently open the --> should be ignored except that the > may terminate an open tag. If the tag is not recognised then the whole thing should be regarded as displayable.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1440910 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

This has become tiresome. Please cease repeatedly raising bugs for the same issue and respond to the comment I wrote in bug 3475474 a fortnight ago. For your benefit, I'll repeat it:
You either have a corrupt filesystem, or a font management tool which is removing Corpus.Medium from the installed fonts while NetSurf is running. Please ensure that a) your filesystem is not corrupt and b) any font management tool is configured to not remove fonts while applications are running.
Further reports of this issue will be closed without prejudice, as there is *nothing* wrong with NetSurf here.

issue.summary: Redraw problems in browser when scrolling
issue.description:
When scrolling up and down a page, NetSurf r12872 (RISC OS 5.16) frequently blanks out sections of the document which come into view, but then fails to redraw them. The problem is intermittent and difficult to reproduce, but is very reminiscent of a similar redraw box-related scrolling bug which was fixed several months ago.
I don't guarantee results, but one page which seems to be suffering particularly badly is http://www.corporateskull.com/. Casually dragging the vertical scrollbar downwards will usually result in the loss of a horizontal chunk out of the top picture in the current most recent blog post, "The end of Corporate Skull".
I've discovered a few other issues by accident while testing. Clicking on a second NetSurf browser window which is behind the Corporate Skull one, keeping the Skull title bar visible, and then clicking the latter to bring the Skull window back to the front, will result in the entire formerly covered area of the Skull window being blank. I tested this with the SourceForge 'Add Artifact' window I'm typing into, and I was unable to reverse the effect - i.e. to blank out the SourceForge window by opening, and then hiding, the Corporate Skull window in front of it. I could, however, blank the Skull window by opening a StrongED window in front of it, although this took several attempts, suggesting either a very intermittent bug or one dependent on some uncontrolled third factor, e.g. dragging of NetSurf windows in the meantime.
Dragging any other window over a blanked area will cause the redraw to be completed in the regions the dragged window leaves behind. This also works with menus, including opening a menu over the NetSurf window itself.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Thu Nov 3 14:23:43 2011
Can't reporduce, and no contact details.
Might be that you're out of memory, in which case sections of the document can fail to redraw.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3414714 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

This build was installed by deleting the old one and copying the new build out of the archive into the same location. The previous build I was using was trouble-free and was used to download the new one, which then failed as soon as I started it up. No internet or other settings were changed, I simply installed a new build. Firefox and Oregano2 continue to work without difficulty. The computer is an Iyonix, RISC OS 5.09, broadband connected via the Ethernet interface. I'll be glad to provide any further information if pointed in the right direction. I have tried to cover off simple possibilities, but the problem seems to have occurred in circumstances where the only change was to install a new version of NetSurf - it is difficult to see what other possibilities to eliminate. Email is tudway@11stonebuildings.com

phlamethrower added a note on Sun Sep 10 17:46:13 2006

Try the latest build, it's got a lot of fixes for textareas.
AFAIK the only remaining issues are: - text selection is still broken in various ways - ctrl-x possibly broken. It works fine for me on OS 5 and 3.7, providing the cursor is in the text area at the time. what OS are you using? - ctrl-z possibly broken. seems to work fine for me though.
You're right about the ctrl-u behaviour - it only clears the line, not delete it. That's how it was designed, so if you'd rather have it delete the line you could open a feature request for it. Once text selection is working properly I don't think there'll be much use for it.

issue.description:
I'm using NS 6-Aug-2006, 18:00 build on VirtualRPC Adjust running RO 4.39
Viewing the page http://simple.wikipedia.org.wiki/Main_Page, I set the magnification to 150%. The view area (the RO window) is smaller than the page size in both the horizontal and vertical directions.
I wanted to scroll down the page, so grabbed a piece of page background at the bottom of the visible page, to the right of the left-hand grey margin.
I move the mouse upward, the pointer changed to a hand shape and the page scrolled down. When the hand/pointer got *almost* to the NS toolbar, the whole visible web page started to oscillate up and down slightly (though sometimes it'll go left-right) - usually as the tip of the pointer reaches the toolbar.
It's not easy to reproduce but I have been able to do so. It only seems to happen at 150% magnification, I've not seen it happen at other scales.
I have been able to reproduce this effect on other websites - such as http://news.bbc.co.uk/ or http://iconbar.com/

issue.summary: Crash on second attempted save of image
issue.description:
When saving out an image from a web page (via MENU-click followed by Object->Save) Netsurf often seems to crash silently if you then attempt to save out another image from the same page using the same mechanism. No error message is given and no log data appears to be written :-(
In this particular case I happened to have done a Full Save of the page involved immediately before the browser crash, so I reloaded the saved version from hard disc, restarted the browser and repeated the exercise twice - again, the browser crashed each time I attempted to carry out a second image save. (Netsurf r12805, RISC OS 5.16, strip filenames ON)

It doesn't have to be from the same web page either. However it is intermittent, sometimes it works fine for a whole session. issue.summary: 'Back' on search results goes too far back
issue.description:
I run Netsurf GTK from scratch (GNOME launcher), which displays the NetSurf home page (netsurf-browser.org/welcome/) I type in a term into the Google search box to the right of the URL bar, let's say 'cheese', and press Return That gives me Google's page of search results in a new tab I click on the first one, which takes me to cheese.com I click the back arrow on the NetSurf toolbar This takes me back to the NetSurf home page, not back to the page of Google search results
Whenever I do a search from the search box and click on a search result, clicking 'back' takes me back to the page that was in the tab I had open when initiated the search, even though that page is still open in the original tab. There's no way to get back to the list of search results.
NetSurf 2.7 (7th April 2011) on Debian Squeeze, .deb downloaded earlier this week: -rw-r--r-- 1 atm26 atm26 962790 Apr 27 22:46 netsurf-gtk_2.7-2_amd64.deb Linux eocene 2.6.32-5-amd64 #1 SMP Wed May 18 23:13:22 UTC 2011 x86_64 GNU/Linux

I have a number of URLs stored as single-line text files. Dragging one of these files into the address bar loads the page. Buffer problems, by the looks of it.
Logfile att - oh, bugger, restarting Netsurf to log the problem has overwritten it, hasn't it? Can't you have NetSurf alternate between Logfile A and Logfile B on successive runs so that the logfile from the previous run is preserved? I been caught out by that several times.
Anyway the problem is 100% repeatable.

issue.summary: Find text window vanishes after type a character
issue.description: With RISC OS version 2.8 (2.7 did not show this problem). Go to Page entry of main menu, choose Find text, and then type a single character (which exists on the page being viewed) into the string box, the cursor jumps to the next occurrence of that character but the window vanishes. The main menu remains on view but with the Page entry greyed out. Therefore I cannot continue typing more than one letter, to search for a string. If the single typed character does NOT exist on the page, the window does not vanish, and it says Not Found at the bottom as expected. A work-around is to use the pop up history menu (of search strings). Once something has been selected from this list, the entry in the text box can be altered to add further characters until I've typed what I actually want to search for without the window disappearing. Ewen Pring
issue.additional_information:
steve-f added a note on Sun Nov 20 14:42:10 2011

This has been observed by another user (see netsurf user maillist). Pages used to test action are various riscoosopen.org pages and bbc.co.uk pages. Method: Start a fetch in NetSurf and then manually trigger a mail or news fetch. Once the status window opens for mail/news fetch, NetSurf may error. issue.description: Hi, not sure if this is a Netsurf-specific or Beagleboard-specific problem. On my Iyonix using Netsurf 2.8, https://ibank.barclays.co.uk/olb/w/BasicAccessStart.do is accessible but on my Beagleboard (again Netsurf 2.8 with same settings as Iyonix) the page times out. issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Tue Feb 7 23:10:22 2012
This is not a bug in NetSurf. Please add the following to the User configuration file for the Internet stack:
*sysctl -ew net.inet.tcp.rfc1644=0

issue.description:
Netsurf r9629 crashed just now when i clicked on a link. last lines of log file say "Font manager error: NSsymbol font not found".
is this really crashworthy, rather than just errorbox-worthy?
-- Jim Nagel jim@archivemag.co.uk
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Thu Oct 29 06:45:29 2009
Well, the layout engine has got itself into an undefined state, which is why it asserts. It could be made more robust but, right now, there are a number of more important things to improve.
I think it's perfectly reasonable to expect the NSSymbol font to be present, as it's shipped with NetSurf. It should reside in !NetSurf.Fonts. Please ensure that this is the case.
Imported from sourceforge bug #2888243 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: linefeeds after textarea opening tag included in text area
issue.description:
From: rik.griffin@denbridgemarine.com
When using a POST form with a TEXTAREA in it, if there is a linefeed in the HTMLÂ source following the TEXTAREA tag, a linefeed is inlcluded as the first character in the text area. I am not sure if this is strictly a bug, but no other browser I have tried does this.
Also, when submitting the form, every line in the text area has a space character appended to it (ie space inserted before linefeed characters).
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sat Jul 25 23:58:54 2009
This was fixed with Hubbub. Not sure why it wasn't closed then.
phlamethrower added a note on Sun Sep 10 15:00:31 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1131038
I've fixed the wrapping issue that Keith described, but will leave the CR/LF issue for now.
The cut/paste issues are being tackled in another bug report.
nobody added a note on Sun Feb 19 03:24:49 2006
Logged In: NO
If, when entering text in a text area the first character is a space then line-wrap fails to occur - certainly for over 300 chracters typed. Back-spacing to remove the leading space(s) makes the line wrap normally.
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
minijem added a note on Tue Feb 14 00:22:21 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
And another one - when pasting text into a textares (RO 4.39) the text goes in one line above the cursor.
jmb202 added a note on Mon Jul 4 01:13:16 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
I'm unconvinced about the first one. I can see why other browsers do strip the leading CR/LF/CRLF sequence - in fact the example in the HTML spec appears to indicate that this is exactly what should happen. It does, however, seem to me to be a bit incongruous arbitrarily stripping some linebreaks whilst retaining others. Until I've read up more on the issue, I'm going to let the current behaviour stand. Whilst we're dealing with linebreaks, NetSurf fails to differentiate between CR, LF and CRLF sequences in text areas - they all get submitted as CRLF sequences. I believe this behaviour to be wrong.
jmb202 added a note on Mon May 16 01:57:27 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
The second of these should now be fixed.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1196456 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
I have sometimes noticed that Netsurf displays incorrect images when pages are loaded. Today I found one on the BBC news site. I have a screen grab and a full-save of the page affected. A picture of some damaged buildings was somehow mixed up with the blue Netsurf logo from the file:///<Netsurf$Dir>/Docs/intro_en page (which is the page my version displays when first opened.)
When I went through the save directory to see if the image was there, it wasn't; the correct image had been saved. Furthermore the web page *partly* updated to use the correct image from the cache. (I dragged a window over part of the affected image, provoking a partial redraw.) However, I have a screen grab of the mixed-up image. Note that the corrupt image as shown in the screen grab is robust and continues to survive having windows dragged over it.
I think I provoked this problem by loading a large number of pages in quick succession, but the problem isn't reliably repeatable.
See http://www.simon-smith.org/netsurf.zip shortly - I am compiling Netsurf log, web page, screen grabs, list of sites visited etc. for you to look at.

issue.summary: yahoo mail rendered as blank page
issue.description:
NetSurf (30 Sep 2007) r3613 displays my Yahoo Mail inbox page so that it is readable, but NetSurf (04 Oct 2007) r3622, and subsequent versions, display it as a completely blank (white) page. The page html is in the zip attachment.
Tony
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jul 26 01:08:23 2009
NetSurf has long searched for meta refreshes deeply nested in the tree. Thus, this is out of date. If you're still getting a blank page, then please open a new bug report.
old_coaster added a note on Thu Nov 22 15:13:59 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1384902 Originator: YES
So why is it that NetSurf (30 Sep 2007) r3613, and previous versions do _not_ display a blank page?
Was there an 'error' in r3613 which allowed it to follow the re-direct? If so, could the 'error' please be reinstated?
Tony
tlsa added a note on Mon Nov 5 12:14:26 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
OK, yahoo is giving you a version of its web mail which uses JavaScript. Something's causing that page not to be shown at all. The real issue is that the HEAD element contains a META refresh which should take you to the non-JS version of the web mail. NetSurf doesn't follow this redirection because the META refresh is in a NOSCRIPT element. NetSurf ignores NOSCRIPT contents in HEAD.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1815016 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
Yesterday I accidentally (using !XChars) clicked 83 and af to encode U+00ef in a document which has encoding (and charset) set to utf-8. Netsurf renders this as U+00ef erroneously. I should, of course, have clicked on a3 and af - this, as expected, renders correctly as U+00ef.
Unfortunately, the first, erroneous encoding invalidated the document. I would expect Netsurf to render a miniature 'four hex digit' character rather then the 'intended' encoding for the erroneous document.
Incidentally, the bug 1796337 may also be related to this one.
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jul 26 01:11:14 2009
Invalid characters will be replaced with U+FFFD.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1840666 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Problem with passing data to e-mail software
issue.description: Sorry, but I have no idea what any of the above boxes are for. You need to make things clearer! Contact via rh_lists@beeb.net. DO NOT use the e-mail address in the bug report below: if you do it will get treated as spam since it will not be a holiday booking! ------------ Bug Report Begins ----------------------------- I have found that when using something like: Book this Holiday In a webpage, Netsurf only passes a small part of the text required into the e-mail software, in my case Pluto. Using Fresco the full text is passed to the Pluto document. On a PC it works fine with Firefox / Thunderbird, Opera / Thunderbird, Internet Explorer / Outlook Express (not tried that myself, but that is what most customers use!) and at least some Apple systems. ------------ Bug Report Ends ----------------------------- Russell Hafter
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1867165 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
See http://www.cojak.org/
You will see that the dark red ideographs are correctly aligned in the table cells, the blue touch the bottom and the black are too low. If you then look at the style sheet (normal.css) you will see that the red cells (class charindex_simpable) have a td rule which contains font-size 24px, the blue ones have a td rule which contains NO font size while the black ones have a 4px font size.
Below this set of three rules is another set indicating the style to be applied to a elements which follow the td ones - each of these is given an identical font size of 24px - the size which Netsurf should, therefore, use!
Somehow every version of Netsurf since last July gets the ideograph positioning wrong. Firefox and Opera (just to name two others) seem to get all ideographs aligned the same way, irrespective of td element class - which is what the style sheet leads me to expect.
Over to you!
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1875543 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
When a file: protocol address is specified along with a hostname part, NetSurf incorrectly takes the hostname as the first component of the path. eg. file://localhost/path/file becomes file:///localhost/path/file (ie. path is now /localhost/path/file instead of /path/file)
Notes from jmb's list email on the subject: --8<-- It's not quite that simple. There needs to be a reliable way of knowing that file://localhost/<path> really is requesting <path> on the local host, rather than "localhost" being the top-level component of the path. Most likely, the correct solution is some kind of DNS lookup (as you'd expect file://<hostname>/<path> to also work, where <hostname> is whatever the current host's name is). --8<--
NB: amiga/misc.c r9656 contains a workaround for this issue in the Amiga port, which will probably need to be reverted back to r5695 when there is a proper solution in place.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Fri Feb 25 13:07:43 2011
Seems to work now.
Imported from sourceforge bug #2892261 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
On some sites, the plotting of images in the vertical direction is too short (not all image displayed).
I can reproduce this on the OS4 and GTK versions of NetSurf and have seen it on two sites - screenshots attached.
On http://www.nintendolife.com the "featured review" image shows this problem. On http://www.amiga-look.org the main heading banner shows a hatched area below where NetSurf thinks the bottom of the image and text links should be.
I think these are both the same issue but they might not be.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Tue Apr 27 13:28:26 2010
The amiga-look one was a bug in the vertical positioning of absolute positioned inlines using the static position. (It got rendered too far down the page, causing other content further down the page to obscure the bottom of the image.)
This is fixed in r10495.
The nintendolife one is actually that the site renders another (semi-transparent) box on top of the image using the z-index and opacity properties. Neither of these properties are currently implemented in the layout engine. The opacity property is CSS3, which we've not started on. The z-index property is just not done yet and I'm not sure if it will be done with the existing layout engine, as it requires quite a lot of changes. So those are both features that are still on the TODO list.
I'll close this since the bug was fixed, and we're aware of the other issues.
Imported from sourceforge bug #2956002 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Binary downloads incorrectly interpreted as HTML
issue.description:
NetSurf 2.6 (21-Sep-10; running on Iyonix/RISC OS 5.16/128MB RAM) ignores the content-type information sent by the server and incorrectly interprets resources as HTML if the following two conditions hold:
a) the resource is in a password protected directory b) the resource has not been downloaded in the current session yet
This problem is a regression from earlier versions. NetSurf 2.1 interprets the content-type correctly under the above conditions.
Test case:
http://www.mw-software.com/test/ User: test Password: testtest
Click on the download link. The zip file is incorrectly interpreted as HTML and displayed in the browser window despite the server sending "content-type: application/zip". Other browsers interpret the content-type correctly, including earlier versions of NetSurf.
Now, try again but Shift-click on the download link. This time, the file is correctly downloaded as a zip file. Now, try again with a normal click on the download link. Now even that works correctly. So, at a guess, this problem does not occur if the file is already in the cache.
If the resource in question is a large zip file, trying to interpret it as HTML can have nasty effects, causing NetSurf to apparently lock up the machine.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Wed Oct 27 23:12:21 2010
Fixed in r10912
Imported from sourceforge bug #3096811 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: Framebuffer frontend crashes after page load
issue.description: Because cokie_initialise is not used within the Framebuffer frontend, cookie_tree_root is NULL. But there is some callback scheduled after page load which does not check for this condition. When the callback get's executed, NetSurf crashes. One possible fix is to avoid the scheduling of the cookie update callbacks if cookie_tree_root is NULL.
issue.additional_information:
zc0rn added a note on Wed Oct 6 22:33:23 2010
The Bug is within desktop/cookie.c Revision 10866
Imported from sourceforge bug #3082503 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
On Netsurf 2.9 an image with ALIGN="LEFT" (for example) will wrap any following text around it, including H1/H2/H3 tags.
On Netsurf 3.0 the same HTML markup results in the heading appearing below the image and no wrapping taking place. Behaviour with text other than headings appears to be the same.
See e.g. http://www.wdc-cnd.org.uk/Photos/ (headings appear to right of photos in 2.9, below photos in 3.0)

issue.description: Had been testing NetSurf 2.6 for RISC OS on my Beagleboard-xM (http://www.tankstage.co.uk/Beagle/ROM.zip). I used the onboard NIC for the first time, using a pre-release version of EtherUSB. Configured my network settings manually. Everything fine at first. After a complete power off and restart though I was unable to start NetSurf. Deleting EtherUSB, Netsurf itself didn't chieve anything. Deleting all my network settings finally allowed me to start my newly installed Netsurf. Choosing "via DHCP" seems to have solved the problem as everything seems to be fine again. However the logfiles don't seem to mention network settings as the culprit.

issue.description:
r9178
Not et sure how I initially triggered it, but I ended up with a couple of pages 'stalled' while downloading their last style sheet. (3 of 4 in one case, 7 of 8 in the other). Despite network activity continuing, the last stylesheet never downloaded. Duting this period, no other page would load or display. Eventually I stopped the two initial rogue pages loading, and even closed all open NetSurf windows, and yet downloading continued. What of, I'm not sure, but I'd guess the last stylesheets. NetSurf's memory usage crept up from under 60Mb to a full 128Mb DA, growing at a rate of about 1Mb/minute. Then about 7 additional DAs, each ~1Mb in size appeared. /Then/ the mystery data transfer finally stopped and NetSurf returned to functioning normally, albeit using about 140Mb of memory.
I /think/ the initial URL was launched from Messenger. w the full job description please click the link below: http://www.jobstoday.co.uk/jbe/vacancy/8y6TaE/9733473/35584595/932850079/0/iWjUnW/0/6
issue.additional_information:

issue.summary: conflict between authentication and downloading file
issue.description:
someone has put a 5M file for me on his webspace and emailed me the link and a username and password. click on the link in the email. Netsurf launches. blank browser window opens, "Site authentication" box pops up, I enter username and password. 71 seconds for download, then "Processing document" and hourglass for about three minutes, no disk-light activity, browser window remains blank, and finally Netsurf crashes.
try same thing with Fresco. click on the link in the email. blank browser window opens, download begins immediately, takes 16 seconds, a save window pops up showing a zip file, browser window remains blank. (The first time i tried this, Fresco asked for username and password, but did not do so on subsequent downloads of the same file.)
i copied the link from the email into a simple web page, so that i could Shift-click on it. this time Netsurf behaved well. the authentication box came up and the download went ahead smoothly (although the progress box during the download showed peculiar behaviour: the estimated time alternated between two rather high values that proved meaningless).
summary: it seems Netsurf (2.5, RiscOS 4.39) gets confused when an emailed link for downloading a file (rather than displaying a page) involves authentication.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jan 9 12:28:26 2011
Duplicate of 3096811
Imported from sourceforge bug #2996859 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
When browsing files in a directory which requires 401 authentication, NetSurf appears to require the username/password for each file you request rather than remembering it for the directory. The following is the IRC log from this evening:
22:42 < jmb> ok, fetch the latest NS 22:43 < jmb> then go to http://test.netsurf-browser.org/forms/forum.html 22:43 < jmb> enter data into the form 22:43 < jmb> submit it22:43 < jmb> and pastebin the output 22:43 < jmb> fwiw 22:44 < jmb> in the meantime, I've found a bug in our 401 handling 22:45 <@acp> done 22:45 <@acp> I get a blank page 22:45 < jmb> sigh 22:45 < jmb> that's boggleworthy 22:46 <@acp> oddly, it asked me for the authentication details again when I clicked "Post" 22:46 <@acp> Or is that the 401 bug you found? :) 22:47 < jmb> ooh, fun 22:47 < jmb> no, it wasn't 22:47 <@acp> heh 22:47 < jmb> can you try to submit again 22:47 <@acp> OK 22:47 < jmb> it /should/ work this time (as we've cached the auth details) 22:47 <@acp> this time I get a string of text back 22:47 < jmb> assuming you've not killed NS in the process 22:47 < jmb> :) 22:47 < jmb> can you pastebin that, plase? 22:47 < jmb> +e 22:47 <@acp> I pressed back, re-pressed Post. 22:47 <@acp> righto.. 2 secs.. 22:47 < jmb> good 22:47 < jmb> there's also move.pl.html 22:48 < jmb> same process 22:48 < jmb> shouldn't want login details 22:49 <@acp> OK, first one gave me: http://pastebin.com/mdd7b0c2 22:50 < jmb> https://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=2625614&group_id=51719&atid=464312 22:50 < jmb> is the 401 bug 22:50 < jmb> good. that's correct 22:50 <@acp> when entering the URL for move.pl.html, it asked for auth again, fwiw 22:50 < jmb> fun! 22:50 < jmb> oh. I know why 22:50 < jmb> it's stupid :) 22:51 < jmb> it's storing the auth details for that page alone 22:51 < jmb> not for the directory 22:51 <@acp> ahh 22:51 < jmb> and not for the host, sans path, either 22:51 < jmb> can you stick something on the bug tracker and assign it to me, please? 22:51 <@acp> http://pastebin.com/m548f918d 22:51 < jmb> a log of this conversation will do
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #2625634 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: NetSurf incorrectly renders (deprecated) relative font sizes
issue.description: Setting <font size=+/-x> where x is between 2 and 4 doesn't work correctly, instead assuming x is 1. This is incorrect according to the W3C html specifications at http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/present/graphics.html as the font size can be from 1 to 7 (+/- 4)
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1885124 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
Can no longer drop text files (or selections of text) containing links into the Netsurf URL bar. I used this feature a lot, so I really miss it!
simon_smith*zen.co.uk
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jan 27 04:41:50 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
The way in which URLs are extracted from text files dropped on the toolbar is pretty simple:
1) Strip any leading whitespace 2) Read up until the end of the data or a CR/LF (whichever comes first) 3) Try to launch the resulting string as an URL
It currently performs no sanity checking that the text it's read actually is an URL.
Thus, if the file you drop on the toolbar doesn't contain an URL as the first line, then it won't have any effect. This behaviour hasn't been changed for a very long time.
nobody added a note on Wed Jan 23 21:30:42 2008
Logged In: NO
Not wholly NetSurf's fault; seems to have been an interaction with the ROOL SrcEdit application, at a guess. More details to follow if I spot a pattern.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1877777 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
Recent builds of Netsurf display a habit of single-tasking for extended periods while 'secondary' downloads are taking place, i.e. progress indicated to the right of the main percentage display at the bottom of the page. While this is happening nothing on the entire desktop updates except for the figures on Netsurf's progress indicator, which change very rapdily in tenths of a second.
This seems to happen with great regularity, and makes the browser rather hard to use on a dial-up connection.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Mon Jan 10 13:23:49 2011
This was fixed, thanks for those fixes, Rik!
rik_g added a note on Wed Feb 3 10:10:09 2010
OK I might be being thick but I can't see any way of attaching the log file to this artifact, using either Netsurf or Firefox (on RISCOS).
I will save the log and can email it to a developer if required.
rik_g added a note on Wed Feb 3 09:54:44 2010
I wonder if we could revisit this fault - it's still happening. I've recently tried to use RISC OS Open's WebServe as a local cache but Netsurf single tasks as described in the other comments on this page, preventing the cache from doing anything. I've attached a log showing an attempt to fetch a page that uses CSS (http://www.theregister.co.uk)
Netsurf appeared to load the main page but then single tasked while trying to get a style sheet. It eventually timed out after about 3 minutes, and the page displayed without styles.
Using the 9th Jan build - r9799.
rik_g added a note on Mon Jun 25 14:59:49 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1577829 Originator: NO
Just another follow up to say:
a: Sorry about all the typos in that last message, I meant "I do NOT know" where the fault lies, for example.
b: The symptoms of the problem are not altered by deleting NetSurf's "cookies" file.
rik_g added a note on Mon Jun 25 14:49:50 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1577829 Originator: NO
I've been experimenting and have discovered that including a link to a style sheet in an HTML page provokes this bug consistently, but only when the page is served from WebJames running on the same machine.
This leads me to suspect it's some sort of blocking issue ... perhaps NetSurf is blocking waiting for some input, which a server running on the same machine can't provide until it gets polled in, of course.
Whether this is the fault of NetSurf, WebJames or RISC OS I do now know :) But the 8 April 2007 build of NetSurf doesn'r show this behaviour.
This HTML page triggers the bug, but if the link to the stylesheet is removed the problem goes away.
<html><head> <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/include/head-styles"/> <title></title></head> <body bgcolor="#ddddff"> </body></html>
rik_g added a note on Mon Jun 25 13:47:29 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1577829 Originator: NO
This sounds like it might be connected to a bug I was about to file a report on.
I'm using WebJames to serve a simple website from this Iyonix. If I try to browse the site locally (ie from the same machine) using a recent build of NetSurf, NetSurf single tasks as Harriet describes for a long time (180 seconds I think) and then eventually displays the page.
An old build of NetSurf I have (8 Apr 2007) does not display this behaviour.
nobody added a note on Sat Jun 23 18:44:27 2007
Logged In: NO
For me - and I am still having trouble pinning it down - it seems to occur when setting up an https connection when there are many other fetches in background windows (remember this is dialup). Eg something like - Go to http://www.mozillazine.org/ - right click on Todays Bugs - bring first window to front and right click on Todays Checkins - bring first window to front and left click on weblogs - when the Bugs or Checkins window has been fetched, right click on a few random bug numbers
This is a typical use rather than a repeatable example but it is fairly consistent.
On April 18th build I get large periods of hourglass when I can't move windows etc; On release build I get same but without the hourglass!
harriet added a note on Thu Jun 14 00:38:01 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=208570 Originator: YES
I've now seen the status bar displayed on its own without the contents area, as earlier described: it happened on several occasions over the last few days when I closed a window which had previously been hiding NetSurf's status bar, and did so at more or less the moment it started single-tasking. Instead of the top window disappearing, the status bar (but not the rest of the browser window or its furniture) appears floating on top of it, updating, until the single-tasking process has completed.
harriet added a note on Tue Jun 12 00:16:48 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=208570 Originator: YES
It seems to happen on all sites that trigger a 'secondary' download indication, which is not all of them by any means. I haven't worked out what the common factor is.
I was going to say that deleting the old Cookies file had produced a speed-up, but then I tried logging into Sourceforge, and found the problem there just as bad as ever before. :-( As a test, I quit Netsurf, deleted those few cookies that had accumulated in the course of my tests last night, and reloaded the bug tracker page with no Cookies file at all - the desktop still single-tasks when the secondary download starts. It's easy to tell the difference, because during the normal 'primary' download you can resize the Netsurf window; after it starts doing the extra stuff, the window stops responding.
tlsa added a note on Sun Jun 10 12:46:14 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Does this only happen on particular, regularly visited, sites?
Please try: 1. Quit NetSurf 2. Rename or move your cookies file away (Choices:WWW.NetSurf.Cookies) 3. Run NetSurf and check for single tasking symptom
Is it faster without your cookies file?
Remember to quit NetSurf before restoring your old cookies file.
nobody added a note on Sun Jun 3 15:59:30 2007

I've noticed this as well. I am not sure if there is more single-tasking but I have had to revert to a test build, as the release build doesn't show the hourglass which makes it harder to judge if clicks and drags are queued for action.
I also, occasionally, see only the status bar updating without the content area even being displayed.

issue.summary: Vspace appears to be ignored for images
issue.description: The 'vspace' attribute for tags appears to be ignored by Netsurf; it's quite hard to demonstrate visually since it also ignores the border attribute and the image size settings! Fresco and Oregano add extra vertical space both above and below the image in the attached example, WebsterXL adds it below, and Netsurf seems to do nothing at all. It makes no difference whether the image is found or (as in this case) it is missing, save that the absence of surrounding space is rather more obvious when the image is actually displayed; is this a case of deprecated code now expected to be implemented via CSS sheets?
issue.additional_information:

Fresco, Oregano, Firefox and MSExplorer all correctly leave a gap between the photos, but not Netsurf (1.0 and still 1.1).
-- Jim Nagel

issue.description:
If you click on a link for, say, a PDF file the file name in the save dialogue may not be the same as the filename in the link. For example open page:
http://www.raib.gov.uk/publications/bulletins/bulletins_2010/bulletin_06_2010.cfm
Now hover over the link under "Download report:" and see the link URL at the bottom of the window. Alternatively use menu option Object > Link > Save > Text. In both cases you get:
http://www.raib.gov.uk/cms_resources/06-2010%20Sylfaen%20Summit.pdf
Now click on the link. The filename you get in the save dialogue is (I'd previously saved it to the same directory):
ADFS::HardDisc4.$.rap.MMPA.RAIB.cms_resources/cfm
So why does NetSurf want to save the file as "cms_resources/cfm instead of 06-2010 Sylfaen Summit.pdf ?
issue.additional_information:
minijem added a note on Thu Feb 24 16:07:25 2011
This is still a problem. For more evidence go to
http://www.raib.gov.uk/publications/investigation_reports/reports_2011/report032011.cfm
Then hover over the link
Download report: 110224_R032011_Carrbridge.pdf (1,560.36kb)
You'll see that the link is correctly displayed at the bottom of the window as:
http://www.raib.gov.uk/cms_resources/110224_R032011_Carrbridge.pdf
You can also save the link in any format and it is still correct.
Now click Select on the link and a save dialogue opens showing filename
cms_resources/cfm
Why is this happening?
Imported from sourceforge bug #2998117 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

Sorry, NetSurf was unable to display this page Could not resolve host: news.bbc.co.uk (Domain name not found)
connect to the net, and click NetSurf's reload button

Tony

nobody added a note on Fri Jun 29 10:13:54 2007
Logged In: NO
I've added 'Connection: close' to the reply header (on the Server), but to no avail. The problems seems to be related to CSS. Paul Reuvers
nobody added a note on Thu Jun 14 18:36:20 2007
Logged In: NO
Oops! -> "Connection: close"
nobody added a note on Thu Jun 14 18:33:07 2007
Logged In: NO
This may not be relevant to the original query but may be to Paul's comment:
I also had a self-written HTTP server that stopped working at about this time; I needed to add a (required by RFC) 'Connection: Close' to my response header to make it work again which implies that the change in libraries meant that persistent connection handling was changed.
HTTP/1.1 applications that do not support persistent connections MUST include the "close" connection option in every message.
nobody added a note on Sat May 12 07:05:27 2007

issue.summary: Corrupt/wrong thumbnails when browsing gallery pages
issue.description:

If I browse one gallery all seem fine. Browsing subsequent galleries it starts to go wrong.
Two things happen. 1) the thumbnail image(s) do(es) not correspond with the image itself. The image(s) come(s) from previous galleries. I would be fairly sure this is because of a faulty font in my !fonts file. That's because it only started happening after installing this font, and that's where it seems to freeze. The font is one downloaded from a PDF file using RiScript, and moved into my !Fonts directory by me quite recently. It is an incomplete font, but I need it for certain documents produced in Ovation and Artworks. The font loads, displays and prints perfectly from those applications so I am reluctant to remove it. issue.description:
Simple form with <select><option value="...">Option text</option>.... where some option text might be fairly long (say 40 characters) typically causes the displayed element to be too narrow to contain the selected option. The result is truncation of the selected option text.
This was seen with default font face and size (homerton) with NS 1.1 (15 Oct 2007 23:00 r3633). mike.hobbs@antplc.com or mike@mhobbs.demon.co.uk
And while I'm entering this bug report I've noticed another input element size problem. The Summary input is showing the summary text of this bug where the caret will not move to the beginning of the text. It shows "lect menu size too small to contain all option tex" and the caret won't go any further left than between the truncated "e" and the "l". It does move to the end of the text. Further experimenting reveals that this condition is dependent on placing the caret within the text usint the mouse and then moving it left with cursor key. If the caret is moved to the end of the text and then left it will go all the way to the beginning. Looks like there is a wrong calculation of the size of the rendered text under certain circumstances.
And, if the desktop is using system font the NS version details don't fit in the Version field of the Info window.
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Mon Feb 11 18:32:41 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=826159 Originator: NO
Select element width should be fixed in the latest build.
Renaming bug report for 2nd issue.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1884242 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.description:
When http://www.netsurf-browser.org/downloads/themes/ is opened in a NetSurf window, which is not wide enough to display the full width of the PNGs, a horizontal scroll bar appears, within the height of each PNG. Attempting to drag the scroll bar launches a download of the theme, instead of scrolling the PNG.
Re-sizing the window, by even a small amount, causes the scroll bars to be re-drawn below each PNG, and scrolling then works correctly.
Another re-draw problem is seen if you
1 re-size the window so that only the left half of a PNG is visible, 2 drag its scroll bar to the extreme right and 3 re-size the window to full width.
The scroll bar disappears, but the PNG remains half-width.
Tony

issue.summary: Stack frame out of bounds on loading
issue.description:
r3857 on loading reported something wrong when loading default style sheets and then crash with a segfault stack frame address fffffff6!!!!!!!!!
I tried a couple of times with the same result.
I then tried my normal 9 July version which tried to load and crashed - reporting no error. - looking at the log this was just another segfault. Since I have been using this 9 Jul 2007 version regularly for months, I deleted all copies of Netsurf from the machine in use and, over my local net tried the copy on one of my other machines - this crashed too!
Running that copy on its own machine, however, ran perfectly - as I expected.
I copied this to the machine causing the problem - still segfaulting.
I rebooted and the 9 Jul version works seetly again.
I suspect that something rogue had happened due to previous activity using some other application/utility over the last few weeks since the last boot, however, as when I tried to shut down prior to reboot there were fatal errors in Minidisc, StrongED, etc.
While, therefore, it appears that the error may not actually be in Netsurf, I sort of suspect that there is something which it isn't or can't catch and recover from. Hence this bug report.
I wish I could offer more thoughts as this is the sort of bug that leaves me tearing my hair out!!
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1893281 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:50 2013

issue.summary: svg text element xml parsing error?
issue.description:
Using build 4100 an svg document which has text elements renders a LF before the text. The source document reads in part -
<text ....... > Fred</text>
This is the style in which ArtWorks generates text - starting the actual text on a new line.
If I edit the document to make the text content run on after the start tag then the LF disappears - suggesting that leading whitespace is not being removed during parsing as it should be.

issue.summary: Overlapping images displayed in wrong order
issue.description:
http://www.tspc.co.uk/results.asp?area=1%23&type=1002.1002%231000.1255&minprice=150000&maxprice=390000&bedrooms=4%23255&daterangestart=1&streetname=&searchtype=traditional&submitbutton=Search!
Viewing this page in other browsers, some of the images of houses are overlaid with PNG banners reading "Under offer". In NetSurf 2.1 and the latest test build (28th May 2009) the "Under offer" PNGs are not visible, I assume they must be being rendered underneath the images of the houses concerned. Some of them appear briefly while the page is loading, but disappear as soon as the image they're supposed to be on top of has been loaded.
As the stylesheet is not included in the page source I can't see at a glance what bit of code NetSurf is having trouble with.
Thanks for looking into this!
This same page also shows up three problems with Draw file export: (1) the TSPC logo (which is a GIF) loses its transparency and is mostly black. (2) the white-on-blue links across the top end up somewhere off-screen to the left of the rest of the page. (3) and the white-on-blue links just end up as plain ordinary blue text, i.e. they lose their style sheet formatting.

issue.summary: Can't write capital or special characters
issue.description: on framebuffer sdl with internal fonts.
issue.additional_information:
nobody added a note on Sat Jun 20 14:31:37 2009
that is problem because SDL is not switch in unicode mode. read here
http://lists.libsdl.org/pipermail/sdl-libsdl.org/2004-October/046782.html
i do in netsurf in fb_os_init
that line
SDL_EnableUNICODE(true);
and later in fb_os_input change to this
... event.key.keysym.unicode;
the shift alt work then as expectet.but national chars dont work, but that seem Bug in amiga 68k sdl.games that allow player names use always EnableUnicide, and here too language special chars are not print

issue.description: In some circumstances NetSurf generates the wrong file name when saving a file downloaded from a web page. This usually happens when the file is delivered by a content management system. Conversely when you save the link as a URI for example, the uri file is saved with the correct filename of the target file. An example of this can be found on page http://www.raib.gov.uk/publications/investigation_reports/reports_2009/report332009.cfm Click on the link under "Download report". The file is saved as cms_resources/cfm. However if you save the link as a URI the file is named 091214_R332009_North_Rode.pdf which is the correct name of the target file. The URI file contains URL http://www.raib.gov.uk/cms_resources/091214_R332009_North_Rode.pdf
issue.additional_information:
minijem added a note on Mon Dec 14 14:33:23 2009
Note that double-clicking on the URI file produces exactly the same effect. The anchor tag for the link is <a target="_blank" class="siteAibReportLink" href="/cms_resources/091214_R332009_North_Rode.pdf">
Imported from sourceforge bug #2914185 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

old_coaster added a note on Mon Feb 12 15:06:58 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1384902 Originator: YES
Test Build (04 Feb 2007 13:00)
Since last reporting, I have upgraded the RPC memory to 128MB and, after running NetSurf the free memory is about 113MB.
Loading a full-saved page, containing many images, causes NetSurf to claim a total of 69960K in nine DMA slots. At this point the hard drive indicator light flashes continuously, at intervals of about a second. When the page is closed, NetSurf does not release all the memory, but still occupies 65920K in one DMA slot.
Re-loading the same page causes NetSurf to claim a total of 71084K in eight DMA slots. Loading more pages eventually leads to
NetSurf: NetSurf is running out of memory. Please free some memory and try again.
Disregarding this request, loading more files and/or directories causes the Task Manager to show Next 0K, Free 0K. At that point
NetSurf: NetSurf is running out of memory. Please free some memory and try again.
Filer: There is not enough memory to load all of the available sprites. This may affect the appearance of files and applications.
Despite these errors, it is now possible to quit NetSurf (or other application) and I have not been able to reproduce the circumstances, described in my initial report, where alt-break was needed to regain control (because the task manager could not function).
NetSurf memory handling seems to have improved, but there remain some problems, particularly in the release of memory, when no longer needed.
Tony

issue.summary: Repeated corruption of hotlist on shutdown
issue.description:
Netsurf keeps truncating my hotlist when saving it back on qutting the program. Fortunately I keep a backup copy: on the most recent occasion I ran the program for less than a minute after restoring from backup, quit it, and found that it had truncated the hotlist file again! (see attached log)
I attach an archive containing the backup version and a truncated version - the most obvious difference (apart from the missing data) is that the 'new' version does not encode the ampersand symbol in URLS as &, and that the </head> tag is missing at the top of the file. The backup version is what was loaded by Netsurf from disc: the other is what it saved back on exit 50 seconds or so later.
RISC OS 5.19, ARMini, Netsurf 3.0 dev #651

issue.summary: Unicode problem which ONLY manifests in release builds
issue.description:
The problem page is this one:
http://www.kiwisbybeat.com/greatarchive.html
I first noticed an issue when I viewed it with NetSurf 2.6 ages ago. At the time I thought, 'Bugger', and went and downloaded the latest development version to see if it had been fixed yet. It had, so I didn't complain.
Or so I thought.
I've just viewed it under NetSurf 2.7, and it's back!
So I went and downloaded the latest development version (r12201), and tried again. Voila, as they probably say in foreign parts, the problem vanished.
The symptoms are this:
AFAICT, it's encoded in either UCS-2 or UTF-16, with every character taking two bytes. In practice, this means every other byte is a zero. Development builds fully support this, but release builds, for whatever reason, don't! The result is a page full of uninterpreted HTML source interspersed with blobby hex characters.
I've no idea what was different in the compiling process, but if ever there was a reason not to bother with so-called 'stable' versions, this would seem to be it.
RISC OS 5.16 on Iyonix.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Thu Apr 21 21:59:37 2011
Will be fixed in the next stable release.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3290962 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: Crash on dragging text file to browser window
issue.description:
OK, a real textplain-related bug this time!
If a browser window is open and displaying a web page, and you drag a text file into it (under RISC OS), NetSurf r12553 crashes (log attached).
If a browser window is open and displaying an image (e.g. JPEG, PNG) and you drag a text file to it, it displays correctly.
If a browser window is open and displaying a web page, and you drag an image to it, this also works, as does image-to-image.
If a browser window is open and displaying a text file, and you drag another text file to it, NetSurf crashes!
Note: Dragging any file to the icon bar icon works as expected - the target has to be an open browser window.

issue.description:
NetSurf r12553 has developed severe issues with the HTML form upload field, erroring with a "failed creating formpost data" - but this only happens if you try to submit certain filetypes to certain forum engines.
I've confirmed it is impossible to submit zip files or text files to SMF-based forums, and it also appears impossible to submit (at least) text files to phpBB-based forums. However, it is possible to submit PNGs to phpBB-based forums. Which forum you use appears immaterial - it's the engine that matters.
I did manage to submit a text file to the Icon Bar forum, but this admittedly has a very different attachment mechanism, in which you have to first submit the post, then go back for another page in which the only form fields are the upload and the submit - so it may be to do with having a text box in the same form, or multiple action buttons.
I've attached a text file here to see if SourceForge does it as well. (Curse the lack of a preview button!) CORRECTION: it does. A bug report cannot be submitted with a text attachment. Since this precludes attaching log files, you may want to look into this post-haste!
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sat Jul 2 15:23:16 2011
This artifact has been marked as a duplicate of artifact 1635844 with reason: No explanation provided.
nobody added a note on Sat Jul 2 14:08:08 2011
Update: I've worked out what's causing it!
It's nothing to do with the filetype, and everything to do with the filename. If there is a top-bit set character anywhere in the filename or pathname (in my case, it was a hard space) then you get the "failed creating formpost data". The PNG worked because it was in a different directory! This still doesn't explain how I successfully submitted a file located beneath a directory with a hard space in it to TIB though!
Imported from sourceforge bug #3349331 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
[Iyonix RISC OS 5.16]
On both r12288 and r12380, the stability of the browser is significantly compromised. The test version I had used before that was r12243, which AFAICR did not exhibit this bug.
The browser keeps stiffing the computer totally - hourglass running, but nobody home. I can't find a specific cause, but it often occurs when closing browser windows. Since installing r12288 and subsequently r12380, almost every NetSurf session has eventually been terminated in this manner, by means of Alt+Break.
On this particular occasion, I closed the last browser window, revealing the hotlist beneath. I clicked on the collapse button for the level which was currently open, and the the top level (its parent). Neither level collapsed, which is when I discovered the computer had locked up. I mention this in case it's relevant (by analogy to Windows stiffing if you click too fast).
No log file crash report, because the program didn't trap the crash. I have attached the final section of the log file it did leave behind, starting from the point when I opened the fateful window.
This is, needless to say, an extremely serious bug.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3300525 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
If I click on a link such as:
<a href="javascript:AntiSpamEncoder('856879799272917576697687359082827170828772856879799217828574178878')" title="Click to e-mail me">
I get an error like:
The requested URL /856879799272917576697687359082827170828772856879799217828574178878 was not found on this server.
So obviously NetSurf has tried to extract something from the href attribute and sent it off as a request to the web server. In fact it is an email link. As NetSurf doesn't support javascript it should ignore the whole tag.

issue.description:
[Iyonix RISC OS 5.16]
This was supposed to be a repeatable bug. It still happens most of the time, but not all the time.
The first log is of me going to <http://www.amigaremix.com> and clicking on the first MP3 link (second column) on the current front page ("Guitar Slinger"), which is supposed to download the MP3. In this case, it was at <http://www.amigaremix.com/listen/2502/Zzr%20-%20Guitar%20Slinger%20remake%202011.mp3>. NetSurf segfaulted. I successfully produced the same error on all attempts with r12624, r12633, r12664 and r12668.
So, after that I thought I'd get all smart and try to reduce it to a minimal test case. The only unusual things I could see about the URL was that it was a binary file, and there were hex codes in its name, so I tried uploading a test binary file with hex codes in its name. Much to my annoyance, NetSurf downloaded this perfectly.
Trying to figure out exactly what had gone wrong, I went back to the original file via the AmigaRemix front page (so not a directly typed-in URL)... which then proceeded to download perfectly.
In desperation, I quit NetSurf the normal way and clicked on a saved copy of the MP3 link above, causing NetSurf to load automatically in the process. The file again downloaded perfectly.
Then, without quitting NetSurf, I went back to the AmigaRemix front page, where I had first observed the bug and which had worked on the last attempt. I clicked the link and... whoops, it crashed.
The second log is of this last attempt, starting from the automatic load.
I hope I've managed to provide enough information to make this bug fixable, and that I'm not the only person who can trigger it. It seems easiest to crash from a 'cold start' - i.e. not having viewed any other pages first - but bear in mind that the very first crash was at the end of an extended browsing session. Also, as far as I can tell, it's impossible to crash without having clicked the link on the AmigaRemix site - all 'Open URL' attempts and link clicks in other applications so far have worked.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3398114 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
When NetSurf attempts to open a telnet: address, it appears to freeze. Actually it is waiting for input on the command line, hitting return in the shell used to launch NetSurf after trying the following example causes it to continue.
To reproduce: Try any valid telnet: address in the address bar, or click on a telnet: link, eg telnet://www.netsurf-browser.org:80
The CURL fetcher is registering the telnet: address scheme but probably shouldn't be, as NetSurf as NetSurf has no way of allowing the user to interact with the telnet session, and on proper telnet connections even typing things into the shell doesn't appear to put NetSurf back into a state where it can be used.

issue.description:
Netsurf 2.9 will output some characters as unicode which may be reasonable for displaying HTML, but inappropriate when used with a filename, which means the browser cannot find the file.
For example, a bullet symbol is legal in Risc OS filenames, and should be displayed in a hyperlink to that file as %8F, but Netsurf 2.9 changes this to %EF%BF%BD which is a unicode error code. This results in a 404 file not found message, especially when used for local browsing across a hard disc. Many other such characters will be adversely affected.
Tennant Stuart, tennant@orpheusmail.co.uk - see also the thread "Local browsing" on comp.sys.acorn.misc
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Fri Sep 28 08:32:48 2012
This artifact has been marked as a duplicate of artifact 1403338 with reason: No explanation provided.
nobody added a note on Wed Sep 19 18:19:52 2012
Sorry, I forgot to sign the above comment, which is again
Tennant Stuart, tennant@orpheusmail.co.uk
nobody added a note on Wed Sep 19 18:16:50 2012
I can now confirm that *all* characters in the ASCII range 128 to 255 are adversely affected, even when Netsurf uses a valid unicode value. This is because the file name is still corrupted.
For example, a filename containing the word resumé (the more modern term for a CV, and correctly spelt with an e-acute to avoid confusion with the verb "resume") is rendered by Netsurf 2.9 as resum%C3%A9 instead of resum%E9 as specified by HTML standards.
Of course, there will be many thousands of affected words in various European languages.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3568247 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Fri Jan 4 23:19:24 2013
The server couldn't cope with TLSv1.1. As of build #766, we now detect this situation and downgrade to TLSv1.0 or worse. If the Co-op banking site is still broken, please follow the instructions in the previous comment and open a new issue.
jmb202 added a note on Thu Jan 3 01:42:58 2013
Co-op is fine here. If you can still reproduce it, please download Wiresalmon from http://www.cp15.org/networking, and capture the packets sent on the wire when trying to access the Co-op site in NetSurf (I'm presuming that the problem occurs when you click the login link at the top of the co-op home page. If not, please provide precise steps to reproduce.)
jmb202 added a note on Thu Jan 3 01:40:17 2013
The server is sending a TCP reset in response to our TLSv1.1 Client Hello. This may be the result of the number of cipher suites we're offering (or the server simply can't cope with TLSv1.1, which would be disappointing)

issue.summary: The local decimal separator in calculations
issue.description:
NetSurf version: 2.0 (Dev) (11 May 2008) r4144 OS/Hardware: Risc OS 4.02/4.39 VRPC
I would like to report a bug in NetSurf. It's about function ^read_symbol which call Territory_ReadSymbols. You use this function to get the decimal separator to display numbers in the local territory. In the dutch/german territory this is a comma (,) and not a dot. Somehow this comma is used in some (floating point) calculations (and I assume the numbers after the comma are set to zero or something) which produces the next symptoms: - Fonts are displayed at the wrong size than they should. So sometimes they won't fit their bounding box (see supplied file of google and theochem website) or the other way around that bounding boxes are too small to display the font. - Pages with frames are displayed wrong. The first frame of the page is completely stretched out in the main window (see supplied file of bigbenclub website) perhaps same problem as reported bug 1929508
Entering numbers with the local decimal separator in configurations windows work ok. The number are stored right in the configuration file and read back in ok. One small bug though. When you remove the separator (the comma) from the input field, you can't type it back again. This is a fault in the template files.
Dick mrseed(a)gmail.com
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Wed May 14 00:34:14 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
Actually, the previous analysis was backwards -- NetSurf was erroneously setting the locale for the entire application to that of the native system. Unfortunately, the vast majority of the codebase expects the default C locale. This has been fixed, which should solve the frame sizing and line-height issues.
Dynamically changing icon validation strings in a safe way is currently non-trivial, so will have to wait. In the meantime, the keypress restrictions in the Dutch templates file have been removed.
jmb202 added a note on Mon May 12 17:13:06 2008
Logged In: YES user_id=906191 Originator: NO
read_symbol is a function internal to UnixLib. NetSurf does not use it (nor any of the locale stuff that calls it).
The problem is that sscanf knows nothing of the current locale, so assumes a decimal separator of '.'.
As for the templates file, ideally the validation string for numeric icons would change based upon the current territory.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1962431 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: Soft spaces changed to hard spaces in text on some backgroun
issue.description:
1) Netsurf 2.6 and Dev version 10Nov 2010 23:00 r10943 2) RiscPC 4.02 and Beagleboard -xM 3) Reproduceable 4) When selecting and dragging out the text of an HTML page which has the grey backgound eg the program in the Alignment Exceptions section near the bottom of http://www.riscosopen.org/wiki/documentation/pages/ARMv7+compatibility+primer the soft spaces hex 20 are converted to hard spaces hex A0 (the basic program then gives syntax errors) This does not happen to other text on a white background. This does not happen with other browsers. I have contacted Steve Revill of ROOL who tells me that the program has soft spaces and it is only Netsurf that changes them to hard spaces 5) http://www.riscosopen.org/wiki/documentation/pages/ARMv7+compatibility+primer 6) Select any text with a grey backgound on that page and drag eg to !Edit, go to Find, tick magic characters, search for \xA0 (the Hex value for hard space) which will show that the soft spaces have been changed to hard. Repeat with a section of text on a white background - spaces stay as soft spaces.
From alan.dawes@argonet.co.uk
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jan 9 14:24:30 2011
Duplicate of 1419350
Imported from sourceforge bug #3111612 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
Using NetSurf test build 20 Apr 2007 19:15
When you visit the URL http://www.x-cosmos.it/cropcircles/ all you get is a completely blank page.
Having looked at the source code to the page, there are some embedded document.write('html') and 'body' tags inside a <script>...</script> porttion (from line 18 in the source code onwards).
It looks like NetSurf is seeing these tags and somehow interpreting them to (falsely) believe there is no content between the <body>...</body> tags.
Surely NS should ignore everything from <script> until </script>? If you manually delete this section of Javascript, then the page starts to render (still not correctly, but that's probably due to other javascript) but at least you can see the main body etc.
regards, Paul Vigay nospam (at) vigay.com
issue.additional_information:
nobody added a note on Wed Apr 25 19:04:13 2007
Logged In: NO
Officially the script ends at the first ETAGO so the script is wrong, and the three occurences should be escaped. It probably works in other browsers as the page will use quirks mode (no DOCTYPE).
http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/appendix/notes.html#h-B.3.2.1
john
rjek added a note on Tue Apr 24 18:53:37 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=893271 Originator: NO
My understanding is that UAs should ignore tags that they don't understand, but render their contents as if there tags where not there. This is why people often use HTML comments to hide the contents of their <script> tags.
This will need somebody who is more well-read in the spec than I to decide, however.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1706778 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
Graphics don't render under NS on this 'simple' page:
http://www.wenzel.com/documents/waveform.html
Yet Fresco renders it OK.
I've hacked around with the source HTML, but to no avail.
RPC SA 3.70 + tons of memory, and after a reboot.
With best wishes James R Miller Cambridge
issue.additional_information:
not_ginger_matt added a note on Sat Mar 3 20:02:00 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=999199 Originator: NO
The GIFs on this page suffer from a fairly common problem -- some encoders incorrectly specify the GIF 'screen size' which should be the dimension of the canvas for all frames of the GIF. The specified size in this case is 1024x768 which NetSurf's GIF decoder now ignores (along with other common incorrect dimensions - 800x600, 1280x1024 etc) and instead calculates it from the dimensions of the subsequent image frames.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1650225 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
Barclays Bank (http:///www.ibank.barclays.co.uk/) has heavily nested stuff on its login document (click login on the above URL) and with a style sheet which leaves input element text boxes rendered smaller than the user-set minimum font size (eg 1.5pt against a minimum of seven). This also applies to text areas - and seems to produce invisible radio buttons on some of their documents too!
I believe that Netsurf should limit font minima to the user-specifed minimum for all element rendering.
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
