issue.summary: Window redraw failure with CSS doct
issue.description:
I noticed today that a new version of Amaya was available - checked for the details of updates (http://www.w3.org/Amaya/User/New.html) which rendered with the left-side div above the rest of the document.
I wondered why, so checked the source and asked Netsurf (11 Apr 1716) to retrieve the style sheet (http://www.w3.org/Amaya/amaya.css). It said it was done withoout rendering anything (probably OK) but when I moved another window over the top of the originally displayed document then all that was redrawn appeared to be the repeated edges of the window being dragged.
This appears to be a redraw problem - with loss of a window handle somewhere(??)
I do agree, however, that this isn't something which most people would normally do - but it is, I believe, still a nasty bug!
Thanks, by the way for fixing the <pre> bug.
A propos of the Amaya document rendering I note that absolute positioning is still on the 'todso' list . Any time soon??
Keith Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1469544 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
When looking at http://www.rmll.info I noted that Netsurf had (correctly) rendered '&nbsp' in the header. I noted that there was an invitiation to refer the document to the W3C validator - which I thought I would do out of curiosity.
W3C validator complained "Referer header not found". Technically I suppose this is an omission rather than a bug, but thought to mention it!
K Hopper asgard@inspire.net.nz
issue.additional_information:
tlsa added a note on Mon Jul 3 20:31:39 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=826159
This is already implemented. Go to the Security section of NetSurf's Choices and enable the "Send site referral information" option.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1454181 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description: When browsing the W3C site as a result of a bug report on the Amaya list which pointed at the W3C CSS2.1 test suite (http://www.w3.org/Style/CSS/Test/CSS2.1/current/). I idly thought of the line-height bug I had reported earlier - so checked the last two in that group (t100801-c548-ln-ht-04-d-ag.htm - and the same with suffix 'xht' instead of 'htm'. Neither performed as they should. The only difference being that the first is an html 4.01 document and the second xhtml 1.1 - which uses CDATA sections - which, I believe, is an option for html 4. Realising that the line-height error is a work-in-progress item, the CDATA problem is another bug I believe.

issue.summary: Edit function broken in new hotlist
issue.description:
Selecting an entry in the new hotlist and choosing the 'Edit' menu option has been fundementally broken, and is now utterly unusable.
Basically, editing the URL has had functionality added to it which replaces all punctuation characters with appropriate hex codes - INCLUDING colons and slashes!
Hence, selecting an entry for riscos.info, going to 'Edit' and pressing Return twice causes the URL to change from:
http://www.riscos.info/index.php/RISC_OS
to:
http://http%3a%2f%2fwww.riscos.info%2findex.php%2frisc_os/
It is now impossible to edit a hotlist at all.
Please fix as a matter of urgency.
martin.bazley@blueyonder.co.uk
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3095552 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: Many redundant requests for the same image.
issue.description:
Examining my web server's logs I can see many redundant requests for the same image being made by UAs identifying themselves as NetSurf/3.0.

issue.description:
RISC OS 5.14, IYONIX 512 MB RAM., NetSurf r9506 My home page is http://www.buxtonweather.co.uk. This has a link to the Cat and Fiddle web cam http://www.cat-cam.co.uk. I followed this and then followed the link on the cat-cam page to another web cam at FlashBar http://www.flashbarstores.co.uk. Before it had completed loading the page NetSurf reported a serious error and exited. The log file is attached. This is the second time this has happened - but it doesn't happen reliably.
Andrew
Andrew.Pinder@tiscali.co.uk
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #2852186 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
The Museum of Bath at Work has a website, the URL of which has changed over the years. The old URL still works with Netsurf. http://www.paulbg.com/bathatwork/ However, the following new one given in their literature does not. http://www.bath-at-work.org.uk I get the error message "transfer closed with outstanding read data remaining." It seems to involve a re-direct to http://www.bathatwork.co.uk/ Both these latter URLs work OK in Phoenix, Oregano2 & Browse with WebServe on my RiscPC & Firefox on my PC so it must be a glitch peculiar to Netsurf. This behaviour has been replicated by another Netsurf user.
Chris Newman cvjazz@waitrose.com RiscPC 700 Adjust 4.39 Netsurf r8484 12 Jul 09
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #2820794 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
My browse history includes various wikipedia entries: ... http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Handey http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JÃƒÂ¸rn_Utzon (where Jorn has a lower-case slashed o) http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katamari_Damacy ...
If I use the auto-url complete to step through the history, the list terminates at the entry for Jorn. I can sometimes jump past it to the correct end of the list by using the page down key, but if I step through the entries a line at a time by using the up and down arrow keys, my Wikipedia history appears to end at Mr Utzon.
simon_smith*cough*zen.co.uk. Can't logon to Sourceforge at the moment. Not sure why.
NS version: 10/07/2009 r8452

issue.description:
Netsurf 1.0 or development on Iyonix 5.13 When visiting any https:// url one is faced with:
Page error
Sorry, NetSurf was unable to display this page
error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol
Try https://ibank.barclays.co.uk/ but is not isolated to just this website, facebook login gives the same error.
Seems to have stopped working just before the release of 1.0, no 'quirky' software loaded to cause a conflict.
james@maat.clara.co.uk

issue.summary: text lines overlapping, partially cut off
issue.description:
Text partially cut off - Netsurf seems to have a wrong Textsize in mind.
Netsurf Build: 28.03.2007 23:00
System: RPC with 80 + 2 MB Select 4.39 (Kernel 6.8)
Website: http://www.spiegel.de/
look at black titels above the red ones.
Further: go into a story:
e.g.: http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,474668,00.html
Text hard to read because there is no distance to left border.
Start a picture series ("Photoserie") e.g.: http://www.spiegel.de/fotostrecke/0,5538,20426,00.html
Picture titel lines (obove right) overlap.
Start a readers comment ("Leserbrief") (middle right link obove right of the story) e.g.: http://www1.spiegel.de/active/kontakt/fcgi/lesermail.fcgi?artikelid=474668
Text area too small to use.
and: (on all SPIEGEL pages but better to find on this small one) Bottom lines not readable.
******************************
besides this grumbling: Thanks for Netsurf. I like to use it. regards Frank mailto: f.wohlgemuth@sh-home.de
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jul 26 00:53:56 2009
This looks mostly fine now.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1690724 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: Quits when fetching pages on GoogleNews search
issue.description:
Quits when fetching pages on GoogleNews search
Version of NetSurf: 09 Oct 2006 21.45 Hardware and operating system: Iyonix 5.11 22 feb 06
The exact steps required to reproduce the bug:
1. <http://www.google.co.nz/
2. <http://www.google.co.nz/search?hl=en&ie=ISO-8859-1&q=Dick+Smith+dvd+recorder&btnG=Google+Search&meta=>
3. <http://groups.google.co.nz/groups?hl=en&ie=ISO-8859-1&q=Dick+Smith+dvd+recorder&btnG=Google+Search&sa=N&tab=wg>
4. on that page click: </group/nz.tech/browse_thread/thread/b5e9ebe8f0a14f23/9d17c531a027b681?lnk=st&q=Dick+Smith+dvd+recorder&rnum=13&hl=en#9d17c531a027b681>
result: Netsurf quits with error and generates a log. attached.
In fact even the top one of the entries on the no3 page will get the error and close down NS. Try this:
1. <http://groups.google.co.nz/groups?hl=en&ie=ISO-8859-1&q=Dick+Smith+dvd+recorder&btnG=Google+Search&sa=N&tab=wg>
2. click any ref /except/ for references to newsgroups..
Thanks.
Brian
-- Brian Adam Auckland NEW ZEALAND brian@adam.co.nz
issue.additional_information:
nobody added a note on Sat Oct 14 08:10:11 2006
Logged In: NO
Works fine now with test build 13 Oct. Thanks

Logged In: YES user_id=826159
I can't reproduce this. I think it might have been fixed on October 10th.
Please try a more recent build.

issue.description:
Netsurf Test Build 26 Apr 2004 14:00, RISC OS 5.05
# Full-size toggle on windows makes them as tall as the screen, ignoring users RISC OS configuration not to cover the iconbar.
# New windows when opened have transparent backgrounds, then 'remember' what was underneath them if moved while still waiting for document to download and render - very ugly. New windows should be immediately filled with some default background colour, then replaced with real webpage contents.
# Tab in url bar giving http://www. would be a very nice addition!
# I guess you're aware of the Forms issues, but briefly text-inputs don't display at nice width/properly (eg. email address input on mailing list page), textareas slow, have redraw flicker, don't place carret at last character typed when clicking somewhere to the right of last character typed on the last line typed.
# Submitting a bug report here with NetSurf crashed NetSurf.
# View Source cannot be used to view source from multiple pages - with one source open in a text editor, attempting to view a source of another page simply brings the first source to the front of the window stack (because it's opening a file with the same wimpscrap name) - should use unique wimpscrap names for sources.
# Can't download .css files (and probably other filetypes?), eg. http://www.w3.org/StyleSheets/home.css doesn't do anything, and neither does clicking the link to same given in the error message of http://www.w3.org/StyleSheets/home.csserror
issue.additional_information:
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Jul 4 15:50:21 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
Full size toggle now respects the CMOS configuration.
jmb202 added a note on Sun Aug 7 23:38:30 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
Second to last is fixed.
jmb202 added a note on Mon Jul 4 01:15:42 2005
Logged In: YES user_id=906191
I believe most of these are fixed. The first one needs to take account of the relevant CMOS bit - it doesn't appear to at present. The last two need some consideration as to whether it's worth doing anything with them.
not_ginger_matt added a note on Thu May 20 23:00:16 2004
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
Window background bug has been fixed. [rjw] F2 places the caret in the URL bar with "www." [zamez]
Imported from sourceforge bug #942644 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

Site is https://trac.assembla.com/ but I don't think you can create a throwaway account with the same https facilities. I'm unable to give away my account details but feel free to contact me to test NS patches or new RO binaries if necessary.

issue.description:
Hi,
Your browser looks really promising, at least when it comes to CSS rendering. Many real sites render perfectly or close to perfectly. However, the way you parse media descriptors is not forwards-compatible with media queries, so I made a patch to fix this. It's my first patch so it might need some adjustments :)
Detailed description: NetSurf currently just looks for substrings in the media attribute of <link rel="stylesheet"> tags, and this causes media queries with "all" or "screen" in them to always match. This patch makes the parsing compliant with HTML4 section 6.13 so extensions to the standard can be ignored correctly.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #2457197 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: nsgtk: horiz. scrolling, side buttons, history navigation
issue.description:
Patch for nsgtk to add history navigation via the side buttons on ExPS/2 mice and equivalents.
There is a configuration option "buttons_6_7_history" which controls whether buttons 6 and 7 (true) or 8 and 9 (false) are used for history navigation; if false, then buttons 6 and 7 are left alone and may be used for horizontal scrolling.
Since GTK always uses buttons 6 and 7 for horizontal scrolling, it has been necessary to create a new type of widget based on GtkScrolledWindow. This is needed to get at the scroll event early enough.
(I have a 10-button mouse. Buttons 6 and 7 are mapped to the scroll wheel, which can be pushed to the side as well as clicked and rolled normally; buttons 8 and 9 are the side buttons.)
issue.additional_information:
rjek added a note on Fri Nov 10 23:00:19 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=893271
I'd much rather that mouse clicks be customised in a more generic and elegant fashion than this, which feels arbitary and only scratches one user's itch. As such, I'm closing this patch request, and opening a new wishlist bug on the BTS for this functionality.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1488564 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
This patch modifies the way in which text input fields etc. are handled: the keypress handler callbacks are modified to return whether they've claimed the keypress, rather than assuming that if the callback is used, the keypress is automatically claimed.
This allows callback handlers to more selectively override other keypress-triggered functions such as window scrolling, e.g. cursor up & down can be used to scroll even though the focus is in a single-line text input field.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1675316 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description: This patch allows scrolling of the top-level viewport without having to position the pointer over one of the scrollbars. Both keyboard and mouse wheel are handled; with keyboard, scrolling may only happen if some other content-area input handler has not claimed the input.

issue.description:

Logged In: YES user_id=294680 Originator: YES
Reworked version, which also handles (and canonicalises) "./file" - specifically, anything beginning with '.'. This is a bit of a hack, since (a) it relies on GNU-extended realpath() and (b) arguably, better URL-is-local-file detection is needed.
I've separated out the flags and converted callers of url_escape() appropriately. File Added: file_url.patch

issue.description:
This patch fixes various warnings:
* missing or incorrectly guarded #includes - implicit declaration of gui_multitask() - implicit declaration of ... * char signedness warnings where char defaults to signed - broken UTF-16 BOM detection - broken CSS text transformation - UTF-8 -> UCS4 conversion * some minor format string warnings (parameter mismatch) * two missing-format-string warnings (possible crash) * some pointer->int cast warnings (64-bit platforms) * one implicit pointer->int conversion warning
It also converts some "can't check format string" warnings into "too many arguments" warnings. Hopefully, one day, the parameters for messages_get{,_ctx} will contain strings which are checkable as format strings, though this probably wants gettext.

issue.description:

issue.summary: Forcing NS to use a certain charset
issue.description:
When the title of a webpage contains a top bit char, NS assumes the page is iso-8859-1 encoded (and ignores the charset specification of the webpage).

issue.summary: Substitute space for %20 in download file names
issue.description:
When downloading files with encoded characters in their names (such as those at http://www.stairwaytohell.com/heartcore ), the local file name proposed by Netsurf substitutes underscores for percent symbols in the original name. Presumably this is because '%' is not valid in a RISC OS file name. As a result I now have lots of files on my hard disc named things like 'heartcore_20-_20the_20game_20-_20128kbps_20-_2004' (which should be 'heartcore - the game - 128kbps - 04').
When proposing a local file name, please could NetSurf decode characters specified in hexadecimal, where these are printable? I assume that the subsequent translation of spaces (ASCII &20) into hard-spaces (character &A0) is a separate issue.
issue.additional_information:

Logged In: NO
I'd like to show my support for this which is still an issue, usually with PDF files I download. epring
Imported from sourceforge bug #1496838 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
You seem to have closed my feature request wothout allowing me to repond.
Target="_new" is perfectly good html. i regularly use it and don't get any validation errors. It's implemented in all other browsers that support frames. Anyway if you've implemented target="_blank" it should be trivial to add target="_new". Don't be so dogmatic!
issue.additional_information:
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Sep 5 22:14:48 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
Moving to feature requests as the error is not with NetSurf but the page author.
bursa added a note on Tue Sep 5 21:15:25 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
The validator doesn't check the values of most attributes.
The HTML 4.01 specification states "Except for the reserved names listed below, frame target names must begin with an alphabetic character (a-zA-Z). User agents should ignore all other target names."
The list does not include _new.
http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/types#type-frame-target
Given the wording in the specification I don't think we should implement this without a really good reason.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1552913 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description: target attribute on an href anchor tag isn't working, at least with target="_new".
issue.additional_information:
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Sep 5 21:55:44 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
This is clearly an invalid target name, as defined by the HTML specification (6.16). http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/types.html#type-frame-target I would suggest you update your HTML accordingly.
minijem added a note on Tue Sep 5 19:57:03 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
I regularly use target="_new" and I don't get any validation errors. It's poerfectly good html! Anyway if you've implemented _blank it should be trivial to add _new.
Richard
not_ginger_matt added a note on Tue Sep 5 16:00:29 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199
The new frames code now implements target="_blank" ("_new" is not valid HTML, and as such is ignored.) As this may displease some users/developers it is optional and can be configured in the Content section of the choices UI (default is on.) Base targets such as <base target=_blank> are also now correctly handled.
tlsa added a note on Wed Jul 12 17:42:43 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=826159
Moved to feature request tracker.
I agree that it should be a user choice to open content in a new window and that current behaviour is fine, for what it's worth.
minijem added a note on Wed Jan 25 01:01:24 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=1432144
I appreciate your point, but I use target=_new (_blank is equivalent) when I link large images to thumbnails or text links with no surrounding html page. There is no navigation from the image other than the browser's 'back' function. Therefore I want the images displayed in a new window without having to tell the reader than he should do this by whatever means his browser allows. This may remove choice but it also removes inconvenience and the frustration of closing the window only to find that the parent page has vanished. Richard
bursa added a note on Tue Jan 24 22:51:02 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=453739
We don't currently plan to implement target="_new", because we think it would remove choice from the user. The user can choose to open a link in a new window by right-clicking instead of left-clicking.
Other targets that are not a frame in a current frameset are also treated as "_top".
Please let us know if you have any comments on this behaviour.
James
Imported from sourceforge bug #1412377 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description: There are sites where text cannot be read because of lack of contrast (e.g. white text on a white background). This is probably because NS can't handle the page correctly either because of a bug or a design limitation. It would be helpful to be able to revert to default colours as can be done in Oregano (Display - Use document colours).
issue.additional_information:
nobody added a note on Wed Apr 30 22:40:48 2008
Logged In: NO
No, you can't just ignore CSS - you have to ignore all colours (css and html) and just use the defaults. A very common fault with web pages is that the foreground colour is specified in the stylesheet and the background colour is specified in html. If the css doesn't work for some reason and the default text colour is the same as the specified background colour you can't read the text.
Richard (minijem)
nobody added a note on Wed Apr 30 01:00:13 2008
Logged In: NO
I'd like to add my wish for this to be included too. Perhaps it could just work by ignoring any CSS used by a web page, simply reverting to the defaults. The same effect can currently be achieved by saving a web page locally as HTML only and then re-opening that file from the local disc; everything appears in black, white and blue; but the problem with that is images and links don't display/work. epring
Imported from sourceforge bug #1528285 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: Display 'alt' text for image upon mouse-over
issue.description:
I would like Netsurf to display the 'alt' text for images (if any) when the mouse pointer lingers over them. I believe this behaviour is implemented by various other browsers (which is why I have come to expect it).
The simplest implementation would be to send an alternative reply to the HelpRequest messages sent by providers of interactive help. (Return the 'alt' text of an image instead of the standard "Click SELECT on a link to follow it.." help message.) I would be quite happy to load !Help in order to enable this facility, and this approach would automatically implement the user's preferred delay period and display font.
I don't think this would be a good use of the status bar because many images are also links, in which case the (usually half-width) status bar will already be full with the destination URI. Also descriptive 'alt' text would be too long.
issue.additional_information:
dsalt added a note on Mon May 15 02:38:49 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=294680
That would be "title attribute text", not "alt attribute text" - the former is intended for display via mechanisms such as tooltips, whereas the latter is a non-standard IEism.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1463118 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: back button to remember starting position
issue.description:
Problem:
Having followed a link from near to the bottom of page_a, to page_b, when using the 'back' button to return to page_a, the position on page_a is not remembered. eg:
On page file:///<NetSurf$Dir>/Docs/docs_en click on the 'DevelopmentÂ Progress' link near the bottom of the page, which leads to file:///<NetSurf$Dir>/Docs/progress_en
Now clicking on the 'back' button returns to the top of page file:///<NetSurf$Dir>/Docs/docs_en , not the starting point near the bottom of the page.
Suggestion:
When following a link, NetSurf should remember the position of the link on the page, and should return to that position, via the 'back' button.
Tony

issue.summary: Add chkspr utility to Full Save
issue.description:
A simple addition of the chkspr utility and a line in the Run file of full-save pseudo-applications would allow them to be renamed without losing the custom sprite that NetSurf has taken the trouble to create.
The utility, when invoked from the Run file, renames the first sprite in the sprite file to the name of the 'application'.
Thus it would not be essential to choose a suitable name instead of the default offered at initial save, but the pseudo-applications could be later renamed at will without losing the iconsprite.
Required:
Include chkspr utility in app directory creation
Add second line invoking "<Obey$Dir>.chkspr" to Run file
J. johnrw@ukgateway.net
issue.additional_information:
ericthelog added a note on Mon Jul 9 19:49:16 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1768670 Originator: NO
Tony's Boot method /is/ superior, but I think the utility should be provided and referenced within the saved page application, as it would be unreasonable to expect everyone to have the utility in their library.
The full-saved page should be complete in its own right. Tony has agreed in principle to this suggestion.
old_coaster added a note on Sun Jul 8 11:58:58 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1384902 Originator: NO
A simpler way of doing this is to copy the _file_ ChkSpr (utility) to Boot:Library:User, and then add a Boot file to each NetSurf full-save pseudo-application. The Boot file need contain only:
ifthere run:chkspr then chkspr iconsprites <obey$dir>.!sprites
An advantage of this is that the Boot file is executed immediately, upon renaming, so that the iconsprites command takes immediate effect.
If the Run file is modified, as suggested, it is necessary to open the full-save file before iconsprites takes effect.
Tony
Imported from sourceforge bug #1580902 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: Support for eSpeak program (Jonathan Duddington GNU)
issue.description:
eSpeak already provides speech support for other programs. The RISC OS interface is well defined. It is used by Pluto and StrongED.
See http://espeak.sourceforge.net/
As well as providing general access speech support to NS, it would also provide a useful checking tool for web pages, auditory checking providing additional checks of duplication, typos, grammar which existing checkers cannot detect.
NS already has the ability to select and save text: It would not be a great step to provide this text to the speech synthesiser module Speak.
John Williams johnrw@ukgateway.net
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #1580908 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
Problem:
A full-save application does not contain a !runimage so that, if the full-save is copied, the datestamp of the original full-save is lost. To determine when it was saved it is then necessary to open the full-save application and inspect the datestamp of the 'index' file.
Some months ago, this problem caused several hundred of my full-saves to be re-stamped with the date of installation of a new hard-drive.
Suggestion:
A full-save application should contain a !runimage, so that its datestamp will determine the datestamp of the full-save application. The !runimage could most usefully be a URL file, containing the URL of the page. See too my feature request 'full-saveÂ shouldÂ alsoÂ saveÂ theÂ pageÂ url' at http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=1365047&group_id=51719&atid=464315
Tony
issue.additional_information:
old_coaster added a note on Wed Jul 11 22:50:36 2007
Logged In: YES user_id=1384902 Originator: YES
A full-save pseudo-application now contains a URL file, giving its source url, so I would amend my suggestion, above, to read:
Suggestion:
A full-save pseudo-application should contain a !RunImage file, which could be of zero lenth, so that its datestamp would determine the datestamp of the full-save pseudo-application.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1594350 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: User text in forms to be preserved on using back button
issue.description:
After entering text in to a form and submitting it, many sites may give an error page, and assume that on hitting the back button will go back to the form page with the user entered text preserved. NetSurf does not support this, so all the user text is lost.
An example of this behaviour is this very site. If after typing in a long bug report and attaching a zipped log file, Source Forge decides it wont accept the attachment, you are just left at an error page. Hitting the back button leads to an empty form again and the bug report is lost. This will tend to put people off making bug reports.

issue.description: CSS 3 introduced an overflow-y property. If NetSurf could support this then it would make it usable with, for example, Lloyds TSB business internet banking for me once again. More info: at present when the Lloyds site gives a list (for example of account payees) the user can only see the top few entries and the rest is hidden with no way to see in the browser. The page is designed to show a vertical only scroll bar but Netsurf doesn't. The reason for this is that the HTML (a simple example attached) for a limited size element (the list, eg 90 pixels high) uses the CSS 2 property overflow:hidden (thereby ensuring Netsurf shows no scroll bars when the content exceeds the area available) but also the CSS 3 property overflow-y:scroll (which is intended to put a scroll bar in vertically). Web develpers have started doing this because before CSS 3 if they used overflow:auto then browsers would put in both horizontal and vertical scrollbars, whereas they prefer vertical only scrollbars, which they can now get with CSS 3. Ewen Pring
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3419529 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
The 'out of the box' default font size in NetSurf (10pt) is different from the default font size in the major browsers. See http://www.paperweightpress.co.uk/NetSurf/baseFont.htm for an example.
Since NetSurf doesn't support min-width yet this causes columns with widths specified in ems to be narrower than expected. When the column contains an image with a width specified in pixels, e.g. http://www.paperweightpress.co.uk/Books/Plays/Skulduggery1.htm, the image is cropped or overflows the column. (The other layout problems on this page are already on your 'To Do' list.)
Changing the default font size to 12.8pt (16 pixels per em) resolves the problem. Since all the major browsers have the same 'out of the box' default font size it might be an idea if NetSurf shipped with the same one.
Regards Alex Harding alex AT paperweightpress DOT co DOT uk

issue.summary: Hotlist/history should use Wimp icon highlight colour
issue.description:
A few months ago NetSurf was changed so that it no longer uses Wimp_PlotIcon to draw its hotlist and history windows. Since then, the configured Wimp icon highlight colour (a feature of RISC OS Select) is not honoured.
Instead, selected text is inverted (black background box), and the icons are apparently tinted towards white. The current icon highlight effect has an unfortunate resemblance to the Wimp's algorithm for plotting faded icons.
I have no doubt that there were good reasons for abandoning Wimp_PlotIcon, but I suggest that Wimp_ReadSysInfo 20 should be used to read the configured icon highlighting colours.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Fri Feb 25 18:53:06 2011
Not going to happen, as all the treeview stuff has moved to the core.
not_ginger_matt added a note on Sun Dec 3 12:34:21 2006
Logged In: YES user_id=999199 Originator: NO
Wimp_PlotIcon is still used for the icon sprite, so I'm unsure as to why you're getting this result. The text element is now plotted using rufl to cope with UTF-8 text strings and indeed does need to be updated to read the selection colour accordingly.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1585784 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
See mailing list discussion: http://vlists.pepperfish.net/pipermail/netsurf-users-netsurf-browser.org/2011-February/009951.html
At present, the situation with toolbar editing is as follows:
Clicking Menu over a browser window toolbar and selecting 'Edit toolbar' allows you to add or remove buttons. This change is immediate and permanent - it applies to that window, all windows opened (e.g. by target="_blank") from that window, and all windows opened independently in the future, including after quitting and restarting NetSurf. It does not apply to other windows currently open, or their descendants.
Editing a toolbar in any other window (e.g. hotlist, cookies) is also permanent (inlcuding across restarts), although in this case only one copy may be present at any time.
Adding or removing gadgets from a browser window toolbar (buttons/address/throbber) is not permanent - it applies only to that window and its descendants, not any new windows. For this to happen, the option 'Display->Save as default' from the main browser area menu must be used.
Adding or removing gadgets from a non-browser toolbar (in this case just buttons) is permanent, as above, and these windows do not have a 'Save as default' menu option.
This behaviour is inconsistent and needs changing to one or the other in both cases.
Personally, I don't like the current less than obvious position of the 'Save as default' option, and would prefer that option to be removed and everything to be permanent. As things stand, this would affect only adding and removing gadgets from the browser toolbar, and not necessitate the addition of a 'Save as default' option to all other windows.
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3189366 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
Sometimes when I've got several NetSurf windows/ services open, eg a download or two in progress and a page fetch or two in progress, I'd like to be able to temporarily pause or slow-down some of the longer running fetches to give priority to others. For example if there's a huge download happening it'd be nice to suspend that while grabbing a smallish page.
In my own version of AntiSpam I introduced a slow-down feature that allows mail scan/fetch to get less cpu time to favour other apps, and I find this very useful. In that app there's a progress window and in it I have bump arrows allowing a 0/10/20/30/40/50 /100/200/300/400/500 cS delay to be inserted into the main wimp poll loop. Obviously normally it runs with no delay at all.
Any chance of something similar, per window/fetch in NetSurf?
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Fri Feb 25 00:47:42 2011
No interest in 5 years, and would require major architectural changes. Not going to happen.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1539730 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
Could the estimate download time be made to change less. What I always do is damp the download speed:
downloadspeed = (downloadspeed*7+new downloadspeed)/8;
If you use this damped download speed, the calculation of the estimate download time will be more correct.
An other way of calculating the download speed is:
downloadspeed = total number of bytes downloaded/total downloadtime.
With kind regards,
peter@kitt.nl
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Fri Feb 25 00:49:22 2011
Done.
Imported from sourceforge bug #1554987 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.description:
I use AmigaOS 4.1 and NetSurf 2.7 Revision 11703
I notice a strange bahaviour using NetSurf's tabs, if you open a new tab that isn't related to the previews one (for example opening a new "blank" tab and then typing an address manually) the left arrow in toolbar permit to turn back as the page in tab opened was "linked" to the first one
I think that the normal behavoiur should be that each tab should have it's own history *only* rathen then share the history with the other tabs opened (the first tab in this case)
How to test:
- Open NetSurf Now the first page is www.netsurf-browser.org/welcome
Naturally in this first page the left and right arrows in toolbar are correctly ghosted
- Then now open a new blank tab from WB menu or with the addtab button Now if you go in this second tab you can see the same default page (www.netsurf-browser.org/welcome) but with the left arrow active, so it seems that this new page is linked in certain term with the first tab, but it's not or would not !
About this i receive a note from the AmigaOS4 mantainer:
>>> to create a tab you have to have a "clone" window (so the frontend knows where the tab needs to be created). There's no way of telling the core that this is a completely new tab which needs new history. I'll have to check the gtk version, but I suspect that has the same problem. >>>
Is it possible to support such feature in the future release ?
issue.additional_information:

On the GTK version, creating a brand new tab clones the currently-selected tab in its entirety (including the URL). Creating a new tab from the menu should open a brand new tab with new history and new content.

issue.summary: Load an HTML file which is file typed as text as HTML
issue.description: As per Oregano 2. I would like to be able to drop an HTML file which is filetyped as 'text' onto the Netsurf icon and Netsurf show it as an HTML webpage.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Sep 4 21:46:55 2011
Not going to happen. Treating text/plain as HTML is a potential security hole. It's hardly difficult to type the file correctly, anyway.
nobody added a note on Mon Sep 11 12:46:36 2006
Logged In: NO
Perhaps add this functionality on Shift-dragging to the Netsurf icon? And treat Ctrl-dragging as meaning 'View document source'.
nobody added a note on Mon Sep 11 12:42:04 2006
Logged In: NO
Further to the possible technical problems discussed on the mailing list that might make this feature awkward to implement, may I suggest SHIFT-dragging to the Netsurf icon as the trigger for this behaviour? That might save a lot of programmatic second-guessing. Possibly also allow Ctrl-drag for a related feature, namely Ctrl-dragging a file to the icon is treating as meaning 'View source'. simon_smith<cough>zen.co.uk

issue.description: Feature: A build.bat "script" that uses httpget to get sources (including all needed include files) and tinycc to build. Reason: Its a pain in... to download 300mb+ mingw/gcc build environmet, then countless libraries, just to find out your missing some include files..
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jun 10 10:35:08 2012
This will not happen, as such a script will be perpetually out of sync with the buildsystem that is actually used. There is extensive documentation in the NetSurf source tree with respect to building NetSurf for multiple platforms, Windows included.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3530739 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: NetSurf update needs to be easier
issue.description: I have installed NetSurf 2.7 from Ubuntu 11.10 repositories and like it, but after downloading the update (2.8) and working for two days with your Build Instructions I am unable to run it. Updating needs to be much simpler.
issue.additional_information:
jmb202 added a note on Sun Jun 10 10:49:02 2012
As a rule, we don't provide packages for linux distributions, as we leave it to distributions to decide which versions to ship. In practice, this means you're stuck with whatever the stable version of NetSurf was when the distribution was frozen. The exception is Debian unstable, which tends to pick up the latest stable release of NetSurf pretty quickly.
Imported from sourceforge bug #3470543 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013

issue.summary: Drag image works only from HTML
issue.description:
With the current implementation the elements can be dragged only if they are inside an HTML page, so for example it's not possible to drag/save locally a standalone image
Like that for example:
http://www.ppa.pl/images/news/NetBSD.png
(This link open inside NetSurf a plain PNG file)
issue.additional_information: Imported from sourceforge bug #3586243 on Tue Dec 10 18:09:51 2013
